reviews: Best Peruvian food in Boston. Have had many dishes in this restaurant both take out and eat in and have always been satisfied with all the dishesFrom soups, appetizers, main courses, deserts, cocktails. The music is so so buy it's an extra other restaurants dont have. Wish it was Peruvian music to set the whole peruvian experience but its a Puerto Rican guitar player.Update: They removed our favorite dish from their menu! Cau Cau. It was one of the best dishes.Update: Still great food best Peruvian restaurant. Prices are high for Lunch. No lunch menu so pricess are dinner prices. Great Ceviche!> I don't want to give you one star, but I have to.We wanted to try Peruvian food for long time and wait for the time that when everyone in family can go.In New Year day, I called to check they were open and to reserve the table for us. One man answered the phone and took the reservation. We showed up the time that we booked but restaurant door was locked. One man (with Black shirt) and one waitress sitting in the restaurant, when they saw us they just shake the heads (NO) That night was pretty windy and cold and we took long walked from car packing to the restaurant. All we had was two rude employees sitting their seats and shaking heads without a word or say sorry.> One of the best Peruvian places I've ever been to in Boston/Cambridge. Ambiance is great. Best part is that it does not have loud music or anything so ur experience will be really pleasant and peaceful. Food taste is great. We tried Sirloin beef tips, pulled chicken and couple of their rice dishes. Cant go wrong with anything on the menu. Street parking is also feasible. Serving size is reasonable. Service is good too. Must try!> First time trying out Peruvian Cuisine! We had Leche de Tigre as our appetizer, it's Ceviche with raw fish and shrimps in a cocktail glass, it's very good! Fish is very tasteful, I also tried dipping corn kernels into the ceviche juice and find it very good combination! We had Mar Y Tierra and Seco de Carne a la Norteña as our Main Course. Mar Y Tierra is grilled steak with shrimps on top then we opted for mashed potatoes and veggies on the side, I find the beef and seafood odd combination but it's actually good, changed my way of seeing things for sure, steak was cooked perfectly as how we liked it, the mashed potato wasn't bad at all, so buttery! Then the Seco de Carne a la Norteña is kind of a meh for me, my beef had a scattered texture and I can't seem to find what's it marinated in, rice was a bit undercooked but it has a good taste, will definitely give this another try!! Overall service was great, staff are friendly and food waiting time is average. Will def come back!> Delicious Peruvian food in a bright, friendly atmosphere. We came on Friday night and were able to get a table for two right away. The service was helpful and quick.The portion sizes were huge. We ordered one entree and one appetizer and that was already enough food for dinner and lunch the next day.The Piqueo Machu Picchu was excellent. The fried yuca was especially delicious. The chicharrones were harder than expected but they tasted great. The Bisteck a la Pobre was really good as well. The egg and rice were perfect. Just be warned, they cook the steak a bit on the rare side.

Who knew it would be so delicious. My brother and I took my sister to Applebee's as that is where she wanted to go. Neither my brother or myself expected it to be so good.Her steak was tender, juicy, and cooked just right. Yummy! My brother had a salad, orange something and he finished the entire large bowl. If u haven't been to that Location ur missing out.Hurry!> Long wait for drinks.   Restaurant was not busy and the waitress kept disappearing. She was not attentive at all.  Food quality similar to fast food.> Wasn't going to stop in as some of the reviews are unkind for this restaurant and I'm glad that I did. The place is clean with plenty of parking, our waitress was prompt and friendly. The hamburger that I ordered was literally one of the best that I've ever had, the fries not so much but they were still good. To make it even better was my boss took me here and I didn't have to pay as he treated me.> Would've given it zero stars but there was a cute baby at the table across from us which made this experience bearable. We were told it was a 15 minute wait and we waited for almost 40 minutes when there was only 3 of us and unimaginable amount of open tables. When we got to our seat it was clear why that was.. we saw 2 waitresses sitting at tables literally doing nothing. One waitress was sitting at a table on her phone and the other one was sitting at a table with two people she must've known just hanging out. The hostess paid more attention to us than our waitress did. In one hour the waitress came over twice. Will not ever be returning.> Eh, it's Applebee's.  Not fantastic food- and the pizza was raw, so my kid didn't eat anything but the applesauce.  The lunch combos are nice, but there is  a Panera bread right next to this place that has way better food.  Service was meh...(she brought out our food before my 3 year olds- rookie mistake!  Always serve kids first!).  It was overpriced for the food we received.  The atmosphere was ok.  Patrons were quiet- so it made things a little awkward.  I am just really less then impressed with this place.

I just ordered take out. The whole time eating my meal, all I could think about is the deserving review I must write. The courteous driver, the bag of sushi thoughtfully hanging outside the main bag that had my hot meal inside and the delicious food, I absolutely loved it all. The sushi was well prepared and delicious. The meal was fresh and I could almost identify the individual flavors. I must admit, this is not what I expected. It was just another night, rushing to get dinner. It actually made me happy. lolI will phone them with my gratitude as well.You must give it a try!> An Old and dingy place. Don't get fooled by the name. This is a Japanese name for an establishment that is NOT Japanese! Menu offers Japanese dishes and sushi, made in what looked and tasted like, a Chinese kitchen/ style.I ordered 5 different items, the only edible one was miso soup, I guess you can't screw that one up !Took home half of my food, only to throw it away in the bin.Did I mention staff shout and scream at each other as if they're at a football game ?!!!!> Disclaimer: based on an Uber Eats order.Look, man, if there's one thing that should be "safe" to order delivered is sushi (other than pizza, of course). There is nothing to become get cold or overly soggy. Alas, it wasn't a matter of temperature, but more so quality and consistency (texture, if you will).The salad was what I've come to expect from places like this. Nothing remarkable, but a nice fresh and crisp elements with a pleasant dressing on the side. The Wonton Soup was a fail on two levels, and it only had two levels to begin with. Level one: it was astoundingly bland. This isn't me being overly picky, all it would have taken was a bit of salt. If you end up getting this as part of a combo, consider adding some soy sauce, trust me on this. Level two: the Wontons were huge! Managing these large things, with a plastic spoon no less, is a skill that likely requires professional training. Yikes. For the two rolls I had requested the Futo Maki and Spicy Tuna (could be Spicy Salmon, I'm sorry, I don't remember.The Spicy Tuna was okay, the flavor was okay, and I had no problem flavor-wise. My concern with these is them being on the soft (maybe a bit mushy) side. I'm just more used to my sushi (maki, for those who're particularly nitpicky) having slightly more distinct elements, and not being one little blend. The Futo Maki went too far in the opposite direction. The pieces of vegetable inside were excessively firm, so much so that unless you eat the piece whole, it contributed to them coming apart. The little piece of crab leg or a small amount of cucumber did little to remedy the situation, as the crunch is more intense than an equal amount of potato chips!> According to the online order system the restaurant doesn't serve appetizers like others do so I had to order a 'dinner' and piece my food together. I got a chicken wing and boneless spare-rib dinner. They gave me ONE chicken wing! The ribs were skinny and fatty. They allow an add on appetizer and soup for free so I got crab rangoon..they only gave me TWO and wonton soup which to me any day of the week is kind of meh. I asked for extra duck sauce and they gave me 2 total, the tiny container kind, and I asked for at least 3 hot mustards and they only gave me two tiny ones..turns out I hardly needed any sauce because they don't give ya jack for portions. It also came with fried rice which was cold but ok. You would think that rice, crab rangoon, ribs, chicken wing and soup for $11.95 is a steal right? but once they add on the delivery fee and you throw them a tip and add a can of soda it is $20. I didn't need soup or a huge pile of rice what I wanted was rib chicken wing and rangoon but they hardly gave me any. Surprise ending: they included 3 sushi rolls. I can't stand sushi and I'm allergic to some seafood so I wasn't too happy that it was on my plate with my other mediocre food. Will order elsewhere next time. Wish I took a pic> Came here with my family and was seated fairly quickly. We did the hot pot and sushi all you can eat. The choices were definitely less than other all you can eat places I've been to. I was actually hoping for scallops and fish paste. Long story short, ordered whatever was on the menu and my dad ended up throwing up everything in the bathroom. Don't know if it was from the restaurant but even if it wasn't, I wasn't too fond of the cleanliness of this place anyway. I wiped my bowl with my napkin and dust/particles were on the napkin.. although the prices were reasonable, probably won't come here again unfortunately.

reviews: Something happened here,the service is MUCH better. We've been coming to Dedham since it opened and the service has been - meh. Tonight we sat at the bar and the service was really good. They were attentive, like leaning in towards you, and chatting you up. We got recommendations for dinner and beers. Our reaction was - what what what???  And it wasn't just one server or just once. Every bartender was excellent. For the reality check the food is pretty much the same. Some good bar food and other ok. The poke nachos were good and the chicken nachos ok.> 3/6/20 - Decided to eat at Yard House Friday. They don't have reservations the day you plan to eat. What they do have is call a head dining. Picked up my cousin at 7:30p. I figured it will take 1/2 hr to get there, so we'll eat soon after getting there. NOPE! We arrived at 8:05p. I guess everyone called ahead because the four of us were told that we had to wait 35 minutes. After 37 minutes, i checked it. NOPE! We were told that we had to wait 20 more minutes. About 10 minutes into that wait, our buzzer went off indicating our table was ready. So we thought. NOPE! "Sorry, that was a mistake, you'll have to wait a few more minutes". I came back to tell my group. The fellas took off towards the front desk. I heard "Nicci, there seating us Now". I don't know what they said, but there was an older women that seem to know what she was doing. Finally we are seated. After almost 2 hours really. The waitress came with water in a decent time. She was very polite. The atmosphere at Yard House is comfortable and fun. The portions are big. The prices are fair. And the food each time I've gone is good. Would I eat here again? Yes, but i wouldn't put up with what i did on Friday. I'd call the manager sooner. I'm there because I'm hungry people.Happy EatsF> This is a chain restaurant that is conveniently located in Legacy Place. We opted for this restaurant as it got some of the best reviews in the shopping center and also came up as a close match on Google to a restaurant we love in RI. We were impressed with the huge selection of draft beers. They had tons of familiar choices along with craft choices. We both tried a new beer and liked both of our options. Mark opted for the "vampire tacos" which had a cheesy crust over the flour tortillas served with Beans and spicy rice. He loved his! I got the abuela chicken served with street corn and spicy rice. I loved my meal too, chicken was super juicy and food was just enough spice. Also appreciated we were not rushed through dinner. We'll be back!> This place is a hit or miss on drinks. The beers are okay but the mixed drinks are not consistent. It maybe strong one time but not another time . They ran out of alot if stuff . The spinach dip was so bad. It look like poor ingredients and half effort. They came with thick deep fried house made tortilla chips. They were so bad. Pricy place for okay drinks and food. Service was great> This place was super delicious despite the hour wait. The service and attention were amazing. Drinks were delivered by any serving walking by the bar service area which was a delight, we weren't waiting for our server on such a busy evening. Marissa D was very attentive, answered any questions we had, helped us split our bill, and use the 'pay-at-table' device that wasn't cooperating lol. I tried 4 different tacos and enjoyed them all. We also had Parmesan encrusted pork, tower of onion rings, Korean beef and the halibut. I would definitely go back if we are in the area.

reviews: Boston is inundated with New American brunch fare, but Lincoln sticks out among them. The short rib poutine is a must, as are the french toast and burgers. One time I had the fruity pebble pancakes which looks amazing but were a total miss, the cereal glaze or whatever it's called was bland and too thick. Besides that though, everything I've ordered has been great.The vibe is alive and buzzy. Mostly the young professional crowd which is the norm for Southie. Wait times on the weekend can be long, put your name on the list in advance if you can't get a reservation.> I was so excited to try this place out! I had an hour to kill before heading somewhere else in South Boston, so I did some research and decided to meet a friend at Lincoln Tavern. The reviews were so good! And I've already been to Capo a few times, so I wanted to try something new. What a disappointment!My friend and I sat at the bar and ordered drinks. I got an espresso martini which came out with some kind of powder on top - a lot of it. Have you ever heard of the cinnamon challenge? Not good. I then ordered the margherita pizza and was saddened by the lack of flavor. I mean look at the pic... that's exactly what it tasted like. Bland AF. They didn't even offer chili flakes or parmesan to spice it up. I could have asked, but that leads me to my 2nd gripe...The bartenders seemed nice, but were absent. We got our order in right away, but then I had to ask twice for water. Then, our food came and no one stopped by to ask how the food was or if we needed anything else (like something to give the pizza flavor...). We were done eating when they thought to come by and see if we wanted another drink. No thanks.It was a Wednesday night at 6 PM and the restaurant was full, but not crowded (which it sounds like this place can get later at night and on weekends). Not sure what happened here because the same group owns Capo down the block and they have good food (come to think of it - their pizza was underwhelming too - my bad) and great drinks. How can Capo's espresso martini be wonderful and Lincoln's be so dreadful? Same owners - same block! I don't know. I'd like to give this place another chance. My friend did like his tacos and the brunch reviews are good. If I come back and have a better experience, I'll update my review. Until then "Meh. I've experienced better" sounds like the right rating to me.> I want to like Lincoln.The food has been consistently good, to be honest it's one of the best burgers I have had the pleasure of eating. Yet, the good food cannot undo the fact that every time I'm there I am transported to a college frat party. I've gone three times, all at different times of day, and without fail the place is jam packed with people loudly sloshing beer, yelling at the football games, and generally being inconsiderate of other patrons. The most recent time there was no different, except for the fact that the food was mediocre at best while the first two times it was excellent. I had the shortribs on top of a very salty truffle mac n cheese (could not finish it, far too rich) while my fiancee ate a burger that looked almost raw (she ordered it medium). Maybe try going at an off time, lunch on a weekday perhaps. If you want to brave a weekend then if sticky floors and screaming over your food is your thing, by all means go. We'll opt for something else next time.I really do want to like Lincoln, the food is usually great but the atmosphere is so unbearable that it ruins the meal.> Lincoln Tavern was one of the best brunch spots I've ever been to + it was a perfect spot for football Sunday! The food is above average and the bar has a nice vibe - there are TVs everywhere for you to watch the games. Our group loved it!We started with spicy wings and a plain pizza - both were fabulous. Our table got the steak burrito and burgers for entrees - also delicious. They give you huge portions on all the food so be sure to come here hungry!The service was good despite it being extremely packed for the football games. I definitely recommend making a reservation as we did have to wait a half hour for a table. Regardless, it wasn't an issue as the bar was a blast!Next time I'm back in Boston, I certainly will be heading here again! Highly recommend.> Lincoln continues to deliver my favorite brunch! Their hash browns call to me every weekend. It's always crowded so get there early. Get at least one of these when you go:- hash browns- spicy Bloody Mary- wheat toast- fruit bowl. It has a large variety and I don't know where they get their fruit buts it's always fresh, ripe and juicyOne thing I wish they had was fresh cream for the coffee. I appreciate the warm breakfast appetizer berry bread, so yummy!

Moldova is one of those restaurants you are unsure of trying at first passing glance. Its exterior isn't anything to write home about. But once you step foot inside the restaurant itself, the smells and comforts of their unique Eastern European cuisine wrap you like a warm blanket and insist you stay for dinner. You will not regret it! Their food is amazing, fantastic, glorious! I've had just about every dish here, and not one bad one exists on their menu. Give this place a try! It's truly a neighborhood restaurant that stands out from so many others in terms of friendliness, quality, and service. I am a huge fan.> The restaurant as such is good -friendly and helpful staff, quick cooking, reasonable prices, and quiet environment. I have been there twice and both times were completely satisfied. I specifically like Placinta cu Brinza si Verdeata (traditional pan fried pie with cow cheese and herbs) and Friptura de Miel (Roasted lamb, stewed in special wine and rosemary sauce, served with roasted vegetables).The only thing I really missed was "Buket Moldavii", very famous sweet vermouth style wine. It is most likely not imported to the States but I wish it were.Before going to the restaurant you may want to check Groupon, they sometimes have ones like $24 for $40 I used last time.And just FYI, if you have never had a chance to try Moldavian cuisine - it is sort of country style, rather nutritious than delicious, rather fresh than spicy, and rather affordable than fashion.> First time trying out some modern European cuisine!  (Also super glad they had photos because some of these menu items were quite a feat to pronounce...)Some items that I ordered:1) PLĂCINTĂ CU BRÎNZĂ I VERDEAĂ - $10 as of 7/2019Essentially pan fried bread sandwiched in between cow cheese.  Not bad but nothing mind blowing2) KEBAB DE MIEL - $24 as of 7/2019The lamb kebobs were fantastically flavored and very tender.  It didn't have a gamy taste at all and paired superbly with the potatoes and the hot sauce (make sure to ask for more since it really adds to the dish!)3) CUMA LUI GUGUĂ - $10 These sour cherry crepes were quite tasty.  Not overly sweet and a great palate cleanser.4)  Opera Cake - ~$10?  (It was a special and I forgot the price).A richly flavored chocolate cake.  It is a bit dense though so be mindful when cutting into it.> Wow! So good! Food tasted very fresh, prepared and served perfectly. Neither I nor my friend were familiar with the cuisine, so the flavors were new to us, and were a delight to discover. Service was attentive, atmosphere comfortable. Highly recommend.> I'd give this place a 3.5 if I could. The ambiance of this place was strange. Glowing reviews and I assume it's for the food which was pretty good but man was the service bad. It's sad because service can really make or break a meal. The waitress looked like she hated her life the whole time. Rarely came back to check on us when we wanted to order more. We were also very thirsty throughout the whole meal, asked for water about three different times and didn't get any more water until she got us the check. Earlier we inquired about the ingredients of the pumpkin dish but the waitress ordered it for us anyway which was strange. Either way I will say the food was nice. I particularly enjoyed the chicken sausage and the traditional pie with cow cheese! I just don't know if I'd come all the way back to Newton for the experience as the food didn't outweigh the mediocre service.

menu_dishes: Chile Con Queso, Taquito Bites, Buffalo Wings, Nachos Supreme, Nachos Idaho, Fajitas Nachos, Fiesta Platter, Camarones De Ajo, Tortilla Soup, Sopa de Albondigas, Sopa Azteca

reviews: I went to Acapulco's on a date for National Margarita day, so obviously a perfect place to go. Atmosphere is nice and there is quite a bit of seating for a large number of people to eat. We got a total of four margaritas between the two of us (Guava x2, Cucumber, and Blackberry). The Guava margs were by far our favorite ones and I would definitely choose that again. As far as food goes, they bring you chips and salsa to start which basically won my heart from the second we got there but for dinner he had sizzling fajitas and I had a taco plate and again, was very impressed by both. A plentiful amount of food so you will certainly not go hungry. Ironically, there is another location of Acapulco's in JP, closer to where I live, so I will get the opportunity to go.> The service was good but the food was nothing to rave about. All the dishes we ordered were doused with too much cheese taking away the actual taste. The appetizers and salsa were pretty good but couldn't say the same about the main dishes were not great.That's our first impression based on their veg options as I went with a few vegetarians to the place. Will have to check their non veg options to provide a proper review. Their bar was good though with good drinks and good atmosphere especially on game days for Pats, Sox, Bruins or Celtics.> The food is ok. Not the best but definitely had worst. No wait on a Thursday night as it was basically empty. It was freezing in there as it was 14 degrees out. It felt like the heat was either not working or they didn't turn it on high enough. The manager was wearing a puffy down jacket inside. It was so cold I used my fajitas as heat to warm my hands up. I hope they fix it soon. For my meal, I got the combo fajitas with steak and shrimp. Came w rice, refried beans, tortillas , guacamole etc. my bf for a burrito and it was HUGE. The waiter was really nice and was quick to bring us drinks and take our order.> Acapulco's is a fav local spot for my husband and I. We come here often, and we like the service and the food. For an appetizer, we get the jalapeno popper bites, and for entrees, my husband often orders vegetarian tacos, quesadillas or enchiladas. I almost always get the chile colorado with no beans because I don't like beans very much. All of the above paired with a few modelos and we're pretty all set and happy with our meal :)> 3/24/2019 - We scored First Viewing tickets to Shazam last night. It's worth seeing if you like DC comics. I'm a Marvel Girl.It's been a while, but after driving to 3 restaurants in Quincy Ma and them all being an hour wait, we decided to go to Acapulco's. It took too long for the hostess to come over to have us seated. Staff was pleasant. I decided on the Tres Amigos. I enjoyed very much. I had to ask for Cheddar cheese, Salsa and Sour cream, which they charged us for. Those should come with dish on the side. The guacamole did. And it's good. The fresh Salsa which they give us with plain, stale tortillas at initial sitting is tasty as well. I recommend this dish because it has Shrimp, Chicken and Beef. With all the new restaurants opening, they need to pick it up with decor' and more importantly cleanliness. There was bits of trash on the floor and it's grungy. A refrigerator case that greets you at the door is off with junk in it. Giving you an idea of the lack of care they have. The bar has dust over the bottles on the shelves. It needs a thorough cleaning, mopping and decluttering. New curtains wouldn't hurt either. Happy Eating. GO TO THIS RESTAURANT if you are in the mood for Mexican. My husband and I was celebrating our anniversary last night. Happy 22 years honey!!! Anyway, we could have gone anyway to eat. He chose Acapulcos. It never disappoint. Great area, great staff, casual dining and GREAT food. I had the 2 Combo fajitas. The potions are large. I didn't finish my meal. Ok, so we came here again because we like it so much. The Enchiladas Jalisco wasn't good at all. Too Me. I will never order again. I do like the warm chips and salsa, but we had to order a new batch. The first given was cold and stale. My husband's meal. He said that it must be the time we came. It was about 4P. He felt that the turn around time in the kitchen is better in the evening because more people are coming through the door. The food is fresh. And he didn't think his was that day. So they lose stars.

reviews: One of the best lowkey chinese restaurants in the Quincy area. My family and I have been coming here for years to do big get-togethers for Chinese new years and in addition to ordering takeout.The best item by far on the menu is the Fried Garlic Chicken. The fried garlic caked on top of the chicken gives a crunchy texture to the tender and flavorful chicken. The combo is just amazing and I get it everytime I come here. Some other notable dishes is the the sea conch with yellow chives and the seafood vermicelli. This time the veggies like the pea pod stems were pretty oily. Other than that more or less flavor was good.Overall its a really good place to go for real chinese food aka not americanized chinese.  Would definitely recommend you and your family come out here to give it a try!> I've been here 4 times before; I always get the fired squid; similar in style to Peach Farm in Chinatown.  It's pretty good and at under 11$ a great deal.The wonton soup was good too.In the past I was  not impressed with the ravioli.The grocery next door is worth visiting; it's like a trip to Asia.> South Garden is a 5 Star authentic Chinese restaurant located in Quincy, MA. Their food was incredible and was accompanied by a friendly and humorous waiter. If you're looking for a great meal, easy parking, and uninterested in heading into Boston, then this is the perfect place. South Garden maintains a highly busy dine-in and takeout service. Over a weekend trip back home to Boston I tried South Garden for the first time, and ended up dining in one night and getting takeout on my way to the airport at the end of the trip. Their half chicken coated in crispy garlic was tender, juicy, and paired perfectly with some white rice. In addition, we got the Pineapple Shrimp in Taro Pot which was an amazing spin on a mayo shrimp dish. The shrimp were large and the crispy and the soft taro pot was delicious. Another great dish we had was their ginger scallion lobster. The serving size was generous, and the plate was full of hunks of shelled lobster tails and claws. The standout dish that had all of us beyond excited was the live scallop with vermicelli and garlic. The scallops were cooked in half of their shell and covered in vermicelli and garlic sauce. This dish was absolutely incredible and I'd come back to South Garden again and again just to have this dish. I can't wait for my next trip back home to Boston to head back to South Garden for another great meal!> I been to china garden over the years . We had birthday party, engagement dinners and so on. The service is okay there . Can't expect to much out of a busy place. The food is a hit or miss. Some dishes will blow your mind and others will leave you wondering if you got ripped off. Today, we got the fish filet with vegetable, beef brisket with Malaysian curry, and peapods with garlic. The fish fillet was decent. The favor was tame. The beef brisket was underwhelming Have more cartilage than meat. Also the Malaysian curry was really watery and bland. The peapods with garlic was excellent. Overall, it's alright to eat here. I wouldn't go out my way to come back. It's pricy, my 3 dishes was about $53 .> I want to give an honest review without disrespecting this business. There was some high highs and low lows. So I'll start with the positives. Upon arriving, we were greeted by a very friendly host who also ended up being the same man who offered to pack our food at the end. We were brought hot tea which tasted like your average hot tea that you get served in traditional Chinese restaurants. We ended up ordering the vegetable fried rice and the braised duck with vegetables. The vegetable fried rice was decent but the veggies were a little too crunchy (specifically the celery). The braised duck was so delicious and tender! I loved the addition of tofu to the dish. It almost tasted like cheese which was a nice surprise for my lactose intolerant husband. The mushrooms and bok choy in the dish also tasted fresh and so flavorful. The braised duck was really good! Now, here's where things go wrong. I found two hairs in the braised duck that were definitely not mine because I don't have black hair. They definitely weren't my husbands because he's bald. :/ We didn't notice these until we reheated our food for our dinner once we were home. I don't know if this happened while our food was being packaged or while it was being cooked. Regardless, it made me remember that I felt something stringy in my rice and I thought it was just a string of celery. After finding hair in my food I'm certain that it was hair in the rice as well when I was eating at the restaurant. This is so disappointing and frustrating. I would never purposely bash a business but this is unacceptable and unsanitary. This may sound gross but I would be able to forgive one hair. But 3!? No. If anyone from the business reads this please tell your cooks or anyone preparing food to wear hairnets or better tie up their hair. Your food is so much better than this.

For some reason - the service is a bit slow...best to call ahead on your order.  Love their breakfast options - rice noodles, dim sum and pastries.> It's quite challenging for me when I was ordering some food here. I was lucky somebody helped me with Chinese translation. I got wonton soup, chinese fried dough with hot soy milk, and my friend got some sort of noodle soup. They were good enough to fill up my stomach. I would definitely be back for Hot soy milk and fried dough> I literally just came in for the fried dough that goes well with congee. It's really cooked well and crisp with loads of flavor. Of course it's greasy so double bag the item. Service is friendly!> As much as I love their food, the service here is so bad...The lady at the front is nice and all, but she refused to take my order. MULTIPLE TIMES I HAVE BEEN HERE!! When I want to order something that needs to be cooked in the kitchen, she will say something along the lines, "oh it takes too long to make. You should buy something that is made faster." I told her I can wait, I have all the time in the world today.... she just wont let me order. Why?!?!I use to come during my HS years for something quick. But I stop coming back unless everywhere else is closed and I want something specific from them(only if she lets me put in my order, lol). Today, I wanted 4 items, But I walked out with 1....> I have been here few times. Foods are good for quick grab and go. Today I encountered a worst customer services in my life from this store. I went in the store and asked for niu li show. Suddenly, the owner responded to us with very angry attitude saying that how hard is to make niu li show and how tough is to deal with customers only wanted to get niu li show. I am like what is your problem. I don't want to know how you make your niu li show. I just want to buy it. I can leave or eat other food if you do not have that. It's very unnecessary to express your complaint on a customer like me. Please leave your job or quit your business if you are not feeling good on doing it. I am always to be nice and this is my first review on yield. And this owner totally ruin my morning. Anyway I am eating in another now.

I actually didn't get pizza here but I did order a steak and cheese with veggies and the spicy fries. The sandwich was filled with meat (which is always good). The meat tasted under seasoned. Veggies were pretty good. The spicy fries weren't spicy but we were given a solid amount. Final take, it decent place but a moderate price. Expect probably around $15 for your meal.> It's easy to look past the somewhat cumbersome ordering, plating and paying process once you take your first bite of what could easily be some the the most scrumptious pizza you'll eat this summer.And yeah, it's summer and summer isn't pizza time but if you believe that lie then you should back to your keto, because ANYTIME is PIZZA TIME. /rantThe Arrosto ($12.50 for a sizable individual 'za) is a white pie with a garlic cream base, provolone, house-made mozz, house-made sausage, and soon-to-be-roasted red peppers and mushrooms. It's a flavorful dalliance that will have you feeling so good, so satisfied, you'll get the guilt pangs of a cheating louse if you eat anything else.And the char on the hand-stretched, wood-fired dough? The chew? I think the center could have used 10 more seconds in the furnace, but otherwise, perfectly done.Stubborn sodas (Pepsi's "craft" brand) with unlimited refills, and don't get me started on the picturesque, fully loaded cheesesteak I saw this guy start to eat as I was leaving. Made me want to turn right back around, even if it meant recreating that Alien scene.You know the one.> Everything was just okay... and if I'm being honest, tasted exactly like Papa Gino's. The pizza was very middle of the road. Ordering and paying is a little fussy and there are some kinks they need to work out.I made my own small pepperoni, sausage, and truffle oil pizza and tasted no truffle oil. Considering that it's a premium topic, and they charge per topping I was bummed out paying extra for nothing. The chicken tenders were very tender but other than the dipping sauce, had no flavor. And the buffalo chicken pizza again was just alright.When I think a build your own pizza place, Blaze Pizza is the pinnacle and crush didn't even come close.> Walked in at peak lunch time on a Wednesday, maybe 10-12 people at tables and one ahead of me waiting for a take out pizza. Stand there for 10 mins being ignored by 3 employees, one of whom seemed to be the manager on the phone taking an order literally right in front of me, saw me walk in. Not a 'hi, how are you're or a 'we'll be right with you'...I woulda settled for eye contact at this point.  Meanwhile someone comes in behind me, manager hangs up phone and asks if he can help them...my cue to leave. There are at least half a dozen other places to eat within walking distance. I will be working down the street for the next 6 weeks and probably would've come in here a cpl times a week with a better experience. Like I always say...no matter what you do for work...you either care or you dont...and it shows> I didn't know it was possible to make pizza that is burned on the outside and straight up dough on the inside, but Crush has succeeded at that.

menu_dishes: Aceitunas V, Almendras Marcona V, Dátiles con Jamón, Escalivada Catalana V, Pan con Tomate V, Queso Mahón V, Ostra*, "Fancy Taco", Boquerones, Jamón Serrano de Fermín, Chorizo ibérico de Fermín, ibérico de Fermín, Lardo, Jamón y Quesos, Croquetas de Bacalao*, Gambas al Ajillo, Pulpo Gallego*, Uni Bocadillo*, Cruda*, Trucha en Jamón, Kampi*, Tortilla Española * V, Maíz Asado* V, Setas y Huevos* V, Pimentos V, Patatas Bravas* V, Pimentos del Piquillo V, Brócoli Plantxa, Ensalada de Remolacha, Zanahorias V, Pato con Membrillo, Empanada*, Hamburguesas*, Txistorras, Asado de Huesos, Secreto ibérico a la Parilla*, Filete a la Plantxa*, Costillas de Cordero*, Hígado a la Plantxa, Carne Crudo*, Salchicha de Venado*, Paella Valenciana, Paella de Verduras* V
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No
reviews: This is one of the most popular restaurants in the city.Only reason I'm giving the place a 4 star is because they have changed their drink menu, and honestly almost all of their new drinks suck! They all taste like medication! But food is still great, every single restaurant has it's off days - though I've had a good solid experience here, their chefs are super moody on how they present the same dish on different nights. You'll see: Here's my favorites: -Bone Marrow: Honestly the mood of this dish, depends on the mood of the chef.. sometimes they give you delicious bread with oil on it and toasted sometimes they just give you basic bread. Sometimes it's fully garnished sometimes it's not... & trust me the toasted bread and the fruits make a huge difference! - Shrimp Gambas: This dish has never failed me! Pure magic! -Corn: Best Mexican corn you will ever have! - and of course the seafood paella: Which the richness of this dish also depends on the mood of chef. But it's usually good.> This restaurant is always packed; however, it's a little easier to get a table after 9:00pm.Pros: The food is pretty good. The grilled octopus, the pig ear  terrine, and the bone marrow are all good.Cons: The paella is also good just a little too salty after a few bites. Our server is not professional enough even though she is really nice. She touched the food with her bare hand when she was trying to adjust the food display. Another thing is the music  is really loud.Overall, the dining experience is still good.> The food here is really good. I love the seafood paella, croquettes, and bone marrow dIshes. But, what I don't understand is why the restaurant has to play such loud music. It's so loud that people are basically screaming at each other and adding to the already loud atmosphere. I felt like I was at a college frat party. Not sure if this is the vibe Toro is going for? This ruined the experience for me.> Love tapas bars so much!! This is my second favorite in the Boston area. The interior is pretty small, so you'll definitely be eating sitting right next to strangers. It also has that dimly lit vibe. For plates, my favorite of the night was the Roasted Bone Marrow. It came with nicely toasted bread and some meat on top to complement. So good! We also loved the Garlic Shrimp. It's super saucy in the best kind of way.  The patatas bravas is also delicious - pillowy with 2 different sauces. Can you tell I love sauce? In terms of meh, the service did seem a little rushed. They often came up to try and take a seemingly empty plate away. Like I still have 2 potatoes left; please chill I'll eat them eventually... I also didn't love the $16 fancy taco lol. I wish there was a neutral carb item wrapping all the fancy things together. Instead, it was just a bunch of expensive things slapped together aesthetically. The mulled one was also average. Not enough spice flavor and also not sweet enough. Kind of just tasted like hot wine tbh. Should have gone for the sangria.> I've been to Toro a number of times at this point and it never disappoints. Only 4 stars because of minor inconsistencies as their chefs rotate. Their menu is relatively small but everything is so delicious I don't mind ordering the same usuals items every time. It's almost always busy, but you can put in your name and leave your phone number so you can wander while you wait for a text. They give you a 10 minute warning so stay close! There's a nice park down the street in the warmer weather, or you can find a spot at the bar when it's cold. Our go to's are the paella, bone marrow, and street corn- MUST try!Salt cod croquettes- wonderful texture and love the aioli, but you lose the flavor of the fishGrilled corn- simply amazing. Generous with all of the fixings and cooked to perfection. Aside from Eloti (which literally only serves street corn), this is the best in townStuffed piquillo peppers- the peppers themselves are yummy, but the oil it comes in really makes the dish. Black olive honey in a beautiful olive oil, plus it comes with bread so you can sop of every last bitBone marrow- also a show stopper. The bone marrow is always rich with tender oxtail. Perfectly balanced with citrus to cut the richness and cleanse the palate. I love the crusty bread it comes with and (depending on the chef) will be wonderfully toasted and full of butter and garlicPaella valenciana- it takes a while to come out, so it's usually the last thing you eat. It's on the more expensive side, but even the half portion is very generous and packed full with seafood and meat. The rice is perfectly cooked- just enough chew left- and the flavors are amazing. It comes out piping hot, and if you like the rice at the bottom crispy, you can leave it for a bit and then scrape it up; if not be sure to keep it stirred!Churros- they only offer one dessert, and I'm not sure it's worth it- I'd personally much rather have another dinner plate. They're well done on the outside and have a pretty soft center, but they're so crispy they tend to fall apart. Not the best churro in the city but not bad if you need something sweet

cusine_types: Tapas/Small Plates, Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars
reviews: We went to Passports tonight for the first time since they changed owners. We loved the cocktails and loved the food. We had the drink special, stuffed dates, fried cauliflower, croquettes and chicas. Everything was great. We can't wait to go back and try more.> Hasn't been the same since they reopened.  I was hoping to come back to an even better experience but everything just went downhill.  From service, cocktails to the food.> Bummed.  We've given them four tries since they reopened.  Our last was last night and we ordered about 5-6 items off the menu all of which were mediocre at best.  Limited flavor, under seasoned and one item was so overcooked it was inedible.  Reading through the menu, everything sounds like it could be good, but the execution is not there. We really want them to be good and succeed.  Maybe we'll give another try a few months from now, but every time we leave we're disappointed so it's hard to go back and spend money on something we're not happy with.  Please take this as constructive criticism- we really want passport to thrive!> My wife and I love trying tapas places so much. Heard about Passport in Weymouth from friends. Its a nice restaurant, cool set up of the bar and dining area. It was busy when we came in so we decided to sit at the bar. No one was standing at the bar when we sat down. I could see there were only two servers working as it was a slow time during the day. Maybe after 5 minutes a man finally approached and greeted us quickly. He was vague and to the point. No warm welcome or overview about their food and drinks. My wife has a gluten allergy, so Im used to alerting the server/bartender about that right before we order and so I as usual. We ordered the steak fries, shrimp n stuff, mac n cheese, & roasted duck all GF I reiterated to him. He gave us waters to start off cause we were still thinking if we wanted an alcoholic beverage. After we ordered our food we kept a menu to keep looking at drinks, couple minutes later I decided I wanted a glass of wine. But I didnt see our bartender for another 10 minutes. Luckily for him no other customers came to the bar. But after the long absence I change my mind about even getting a drink. Our food came out pretty quickly, a nice young woman was bringing it to us. And I confirmed and asked her these are all GF free right? And she said no (her ticket didn't say it was GF) so she got the guy I believe I overheard the workers call him Eric to put in the order again as GF. I was ready to leave just cause of the bartender but we came all this way and we're hungry so we stayed. The food turned out to be delicious even as GF but the service from the bartender is the only poor review I have about this place.> Dropped in on a whim and had a lovely experience! The seared pork belly and the crispy Brussels were delightful. 10/10 will recommend!

Ghost Pepper Taco + Tequila Bar is a true gem of an addition to the abundance on new establishments opening in the local South Boston / Dorchester Area. Keeping with traditional sprits and authentic cuisine, Ken and company have add a fresh twist to a seeming played current theme in newly opened restaurants. Not taking away from similar venues on either end of Dorchester Ave or Broadway, but the times have visited other noted taquerias (or taco & oyster bars) the either has been too long of a wait to enter, or one bartender for an over crowded (and limited space) atmosphere and could barely fit in the door. Ghost Pepper has a modern vIbe with eclectic scene.... def will be returning there.> This bar is super cool, great decor and atmosphere. The service and a staff are great but the food was disappointing. The empanadas were overcooked and dry, the street corn lacked flavor and while the margarita tasted good...they had little tequila in them. They are fairly new so I'm hoping they just haven't found their groove. I'm planning to give it another try in 6 months or so.> I've been giving this place a lot of chances to change my mind and try different things on the menu but it's been consistently bad that honestly I give up and won't be coming back. The actual place is trendy, they have great music and the servers I've gotten have been great but the food and drinks have been disappointing over and over again. I've tried almost all things on the menu by now and honestly the corn is probably the only thing that is edible (on a good day). Steak was chewy, pupusas were dipped in oil and fell apart, tacos are blah, rice was served cold, chips tasted old, tres leches was dry, hard and tasted like it's been in the fridge for days, margaritas are ok - sometimes overly salted even when I would ask for no salt on the rim... I could keep going...I gave the place so many chances but the fact that the owner or whoever is in charge never even bothered to apologize or offer anything for their bad quality of food makes me never want to come back. Customer service should be a priority and it seems like they just don't care which is a shame because they have so much potential.> Two stars because the margaritas were great and the salad was fresh. The tacos came cold and the pork belly on them were old and stiff. Octopus was cold as well so we sent it back and they gave us guacamole on the house. Guac was delicious but chips were again, cold.Service was friendly but we waited over 20 minutes for our drinks and the place was freezing cold because of the draft from the doors opening non stop.They need to re-vamp the kitchen all together and focus more on drinks and comfort.> Came here with friends on a whim and am SO SAD that this place isn't on my side of town. Everything is so so good. I say this as a Texan native, so I know good food and I know good Tex-Mex/Latin cuisine. The octopus taco was a crowd favorite and the cocktails are a dream. Rudy was also our waiter and is a gem and a rockstar. Short version- go here. It is SO worth the trip.

reviews: My wife and I have had Brick and Beam on our radar for quite sometime but thought we'd wait until the new restaurant jitters calmed down.Last night we gave them a try and were extremely impressed. Great menu with a wide diversity of options.  We chose the Greek salad and house burger.  Really well presented and of a high quality.What really made our visit special was the service. Our server Kerin was extremely attentive, personable and professional. She constantly kept an eye on us without hovering over our table. A real pro.We excited to have a new option close to home and we look forward to trying more options on the menu soon.Great draft beer selection!Great place to watch sports as well!> Found this little place in Quincy while getting work done on my car across the street.First impressions: we arrived at 2:30PM and we were immediately greeted at the door upon arrival. Multiple TV's to watch and a very clean and spacious atmosphere.Drinks: I started with a really good Dark and Stormy and my wife had a stolie Punch which I thought was ok.Food. Starting with the General Gau calimari and the Mexican street corn....WoW Amazing. The flavors were all there, Up next was the chicken Caesar pizza and The B and B burger. Hands down the best Chicken Cesar pizza I've ever had I couldn't lie, My wife thought her burger was good but would definitely be better with BBQ sauce or something like that.Service: Our Waiter Christine was on point wit everything, she checked on us making sure everything we had was up to par. I have to say I'm impressed with this place.Closing: This place is a definite must try for anyone. A wide range menu to choose from a lovely staff. Keep up the good work guys we will be back> Very solid dinner experience! Big menu but not too overwhelming. Food was great, service was lovely!> Here i find myself at brick and beam. Another neighborhood resturant. This is my second time here. This time not so good. Ordered cod entree with mashed and blackened broccoli. Fish over cooked and had bones. Broccoli not blackened and barely cooked. Mashed ok. First time i got pizza.....maybe more of a cheeseburger amd pizza kind of place as oppossed to a full meal. Had nothing bad to say first time. I prob will be back.....just not for the cod.> Joyce and I dropped in for a quick dinner. The stringy onions rings were delicious along with the cajun shrimp. We had the pizza special. It was topped with roasted rep peppers,  eggplant,  mushrooms, and more. It also was delicious.  For desert we had the creme brulee cheesecake. Definately look forward to returning.

Great place great food -- the best Ethiopian restaurant in Boston -- the injera always freshI live a block away and eat here with my friends/housemates almost every weekendTry their honey wine made in house!> We came in this past Sunday around 7pm without a wait.  About six tables out of the approximate dozen tables were filled.  It's a small place and the tables and chairs are close to your neighbors.  We ordered one veggie dIsh and one beef stew dish.  We asked for very mild dishes.  Joseph explained to us there are about 14 veggies to chooSe from.  He chose  the mild veggies with one medium spicy level.We ate everything up.  It was delicious.  Everything tasted fresh, full of flavor, and all the dishes were mild except one veggie dish as Joseph had promised.  This was my second time here and I'll definitely continue to come here for their food.I believe it's street parking as i did not see any parking lots.> What a find in JP!We were able to find street parking around 5PM on a Saturday night and were seated immediately. We ordered: lentil saladVegetarian revenge for oneMisir WetGomen Wetyatakilt wettikil gommenshiro wet Yekik AlichaLamb - Yebeg tipsAll were fantastic and flavorful. I wish we had gotten a more spicy dish or spicy sauce on the side. It's a small restaurant with about 9 tables, so if you know that you're in the mood for Ethiopian, call ahead to reserve a table. The service was attentive and kind!> Blue Nile is a great local option. I came here on a Thursday around 6 and it was pretty empty at that point.The service was very friendly. Our waitress helped my friend and I decide what to order, and we were both pleased with our food. My friend ordered the chicken combo and I ordered the spicy beef combo. They came with a generous portion of injera to share. I'm not super experienced with Ethiopian food, but I loved what I had.I ordered the honey wine, but they have other wine and a beer selection. The honey wine tasted like persimmon to me. It was sweet, but still tasted fresh and balanced. As our time went by, the place definitely filled up, but our waitress remained pretty attentive. Neither of us could finish our food; we definitely overestimated our ability to consume the injera!Definitely recommend this place and plan to return.> Such good food and great service and warm reception! I'm eritrean (we eat a lot of the same cuisine) and came here with two friends from the area. Food was better than I'd expected-really good. We got the meat combo for one that came with veggie stews/dishes and added a meet entree which was very plentiful and all packed with flavors that complimented each other really well

I just started doing a vegan diet.  I thought I give these deserts a try and to my surprise I was blow away.  Delicious full of texture.  Will definitely be back for more.  Thank you so much for creating such a d elite!  Debbie MAuburndale, MA> Absolutely obsessed with Nique's cheesecake! I work a few businesses down from a store that sells slices of his cakes and I find myself buying a piece almost every day. I was also lucky enough to have an entire carrot cake cheese cake by Nique this past Thanksgiving... unbelievably delicious. Highly recommend!

reviews: Oh Yeah, O Ya is the best Sushi I have ever put in my mouth... Dumb expensive and worth every bite . Insane creations they got going on there. The sushi and the staff were outta this world. We got lucky enough to get in after a phone call and the time was at 930 pm....but we did it. And let me tell you....we would do it again. If you have been eating sushi all your life.... treat yourself to OYa so you can see how its really done. Small small small place. Getting in is the hardest part. But once your there prepare to be in for a treat. Everything was spectacular.  And the host was a sweetheart and our waiter was phenomenal....Epic night...can't wait to do it again. #BuddhaReview> Came here for a special occasion. We got the grand omakase, which was 21 courses at 285 per person before taxes and a fixed 20% gratuity, and sake flights at 65 for four glasses of the bigger end sakes. Quite honestly, I had really high expectations, but O Ya turns out to be little more than an old-time Japanese restaurant trying to cash in on the success of the NYC avant garde omakase scene.If I could use one word to describe our meal, it's "overkill". Each course was overly bombastic in its flavor, with one or two ingredients completely overwhelming the taste of everything else, including the fish. Isn't the point of omakases to highlight the fish? The pacing felt off too - by the time the richer courses were coming out, my stomach had expected them 3 or 4 courses ago, and we started feeling sick as a result. Far from enjoyable. However, desserts were absolutely delicious, and made for quite a pleasing end for the night. The one annoying part of our meal was when the hostess seated a couple (friends of hers) at the sushi bar next to us in a space for one, midway through our meal. I ended up getting bumped by his elbow every few minutes, which made the whole experience quite a bit less enjoyable.At $440 per person total, the quality of the food and the experience did not hold up. You can get better for cheaper at both No Relation and Pabu, which is where I'd rather spend my money.Highlights were the oyster, uni and sturgeon, ora king salmon, bluefin toro, ramen, onsen egg, A5 Wagyu, and black yuzu calamansi sorbet dessert. Service was pretty solid, but I'm pretty sure it was because of the 20% gratuity ‍You can do better than here. Would not recommend.> Simply amazing.  Worth every penny surprisingly.  Service and food are spectacular.  Make sure you tell your server what you don't like!  Everything was great on the tasting menus.  The Japanese steak cubes was the the best I've ever eaten.  Insanely delicious.Hope to return one day.> Slippage. When a restaurant that used to be top-notch has slipped in quality and attention to detail. O Ya used to be one of the best sushi restaurants in the US. But it appears that expansion of the O Ya empire (to Mexico and New York) and the addition of other restaurants in the portfolio (viz., Hojoko, Covina, and Roof) have diluted the experience and left the "mother ship" unsupervised. For example, we arrived promptly at 5:00 pm for our reservation, and we were made to wait several minutes while the hostess got her act together (even though there was only one other party to seat, who also had to wait while the crew got organized). If you're going to charge $285 for an omakase dinner, be scrupulously prepared. Here's the breakdown:Strengths:*Still has a high level of creativity*The Kumamoto oyster with watermelon pearls was excellent*The cuttlefish with cherry blossom, shiso, and smokey bonito also was a highlight*The Kagoshima A5 Wagyu seared petit strip loin was one of the best wagyu dishes you'll ever have, with a melt-in-your mouth texture*The wine list is particularly noteworthy for a sushi restaurant*The service was solidWeaknesses:*The hostess should be much more organized. Don't make people wait when they have reservations and the restaurant is empty*The menu is a bit heavy-handed with smoking and torching. It often overpowers the beautiful, simple power of fresh sashimi and sushi*Many of the dishes would have excelled if they had been more carefully sauced. Several dishes had the sushi resting in a puddle of sauce that had not been evenly applied*The on-line wine list should be updated regularly. Nothing is more disappointing than expecting an excellent wine to be in stock, only to be told that it no longer is*I detest restaurants (like O Ya) that automatically apply a 20% gratuity. Sometimes the service does not merit such a high gratuity; don't force diners to pay it if they believe a 20% tip is not deserved> It's hard to put into words all of the amazing flavors and textures my mouth experienced tonight at the 17 serving omakase dinner at O Ya. The meal is stunning. Each delightful serving delivers a unique flavor experience. The fish is fresh and absolutely melts in your mouth. The sauces provide the perfect compliment without overwhelming, and the presentation is beautiful! Our waiter was friendly and knowledgeable. It's not an inexpensive experience, but it's well worth the money. I highly recommend O Ya for that special celebration!

I feel like there's a lot of tasty Thai restaurants in Boston but Chalawan is the first that I've been to here that truly feels upscale. While this experience may come with a hefty price tag , I feel like it can be justified with Chalawan's impressive presentation of its food and its savory dishes. I don't think you can come to Chalawan and not order an appetizer considering how INSTAGRAM-ABLE  (and delicious) they are. My friend and I ordered the chicken betel leaf and the seared Alaskan scallop for our apps. The chicken betel leaf was an interesting experience. It has a strong lemon grass flavor with a bit of a mushy texture that is complemented by crunchy fried shallots. I would not recommend eating the actual betel leaf.The seared Alaskan scallop was every bit as delicious as it sounds. The scallop was seared perfectly, and I really enjoyed the garnish of scallion and shallots. I feel like this is going to be a must-order for me when I come back.For our mains, we got the red curry duck (with some roti canai) and the Singapore chili beef. The red curry duck was creamy with just the right amount of spice and kick. It was intriguing to see the combination of ingredients in this dish. I've never eaten a red curry with duck before much less one with lychee, okra, and eggplant, but it seemed to work. I was also glad that my friend and I both got rice for the red curry even though I'm kinda on a low carb diet . The rice was surprisingly good. It was warm and very sticky  which made it pleasing to eat. We also actually ordered the roti canai which came out fresh and hot and paired well with the curry (NOTE that it seems like they normally don't give you a curry/dipping sauce when you order the roti canai).The Singapore chili beef was admittedly kinda plain (like any nice beef dish you might find at a Chinese restaurant) but I still enjoyed eating it. The biggest reason you might not want to go to Chalawan is honestly the price. All the apps start to add up and even the rice costs $2 per person which is disappointing. I believe our bill came out to around $38 per person before tip All in all though, I think you get what you pay for. I would love to come back to Chalawan again in the future (perhaps on a fancy date) and try some of their other dishes.> I really enjoyed Chalawan but it was a bit tricky to understand what we were getting ourselves into.  Full disclosure: it was a rainy, icky Tuesday night and we were craving Southwest Asian food.  The Web site wasn't super helpful (and it was impossible to find prices listed to get any directional sense), so it was a bit surprising to us that entrees are about $30.  Totally understood but in that case we may not have gone on a rainy night where we just wanted comfort food (and instead dropped about $100).The food at Chalawan is delicious, nuanced, and fresh.  The food was a bit overpriced for what it was -- $25 - $30 for many of the entrees - again, it was impossible to know this before literally going into the restaurant.  Meanwhile, the "Vegetarian" menu on Chalawan's Web site is a bit lower ($15-$20) - just seemed misleading.> This was a wonderful meal. I really loved all the flavors, the presentation of the food and the set up of the restaurant were gorgeous, and the service was attentive as well.We started with the chicken betel leaf. It packs a flavorful punch, with a mix of herbs. It's really unique, and I highly recommend it.If you're getting a curry, I highly recommend getting the roti canai with it. The roti is wonderfully fluffy, and almost feels like it's made to be dipped.I got the red duck curry, along with jasmine rice. There's a lot of duck and a lot of curry. It's well worth the price. If there's extra curry, you can ask a server to pack it up and save it for another time.I recommend this restaurant without hesitation. It could be a really nice place for a date.> Overpriced and overhyped. Coming from NYC, I have pretty high expectations for Southeast Asian food. All the reviews say everything was delicious but my friends and I tried a bunch of their dishes and were only impressed with one: the Sumartra beef cheek rendang. Is it worth $32 though for a tiny portion? Definitely not.Given that there are not many Southeast Asian options in Boston as there are in New York, I can understand why this place gets so much hype. However, I wouldn't come back again because every other dish was either too salty (the seared scallop appetizer, priced at $4 EACH!), too sticky (the crispy comfit pork hock), or just flat out tasteless and mushy (the black sticky rice dessert).Save your money and go somewhere else.> When you ask the waitress how spicy a dish is and she says "well to me it's not that spicy", that's a good sign in a Southeast Asian place. Chalawan is perhaps the only Southeast Asian place in the Boston/Cambridge area that has an upscale, date-night feel with a variety of strong, beautiful flavors that does not shy away from the origins of their dishes. I would recommend making a reservation as the space is not huge. I ended up giving them a call to get my reservation because the online platform said they were fully booked. Overall, the service was very friendly and attentive, in a more dimly lit atmosphere for dinner, hence a nice-occasion feel. The rice is ordered "per person" and a waiter comes around with rice in the same fashion as one might expect with water, to fill up when they see you're running low. We ordered the scallops, chili beef, and red curry of duck. I like that the flavors were unique but did not feel hapharzardly combined. If you are wary of spice level, I would let the waiter know, as I get the feeling there is pride in spiciness here. There were many other options with intriguing combos that I want to try, so I'll definitely be back.

Great vibe, the cocktails, bar and waitstaff are superb! I would prefer more northern Italian dishes and more vegan, fish and more bianco sauces for the entrees and less red sauces. The grilled octopus serving was skimpy on the octopus 2 small slivers with a ton of red sauce. I would have preferred that it was more simply prepared with a lemon garlic and parsley sauce. The red sauce with cannoli beans was overpowering and it was prepared with hidden pancetta. I do not eat meat so that took me by surprise. The wait staff immediately took the item off my check and apologized. The menu is heavy on meat and pork  and red sauce preparations for the pasta. My entree was frutti di mare, again with red sauce, it overpowered the delicate shellfish and was too salty, and really did not let the flavors of the shellfish come through. The bread pudding dessert was amazing. Management should review and revamp this tired old school red sauce and meat ladened menu.> True Score: 3.75 Stars Oh that Carbonara!The restaurant is relatively new in Dedham but the menu and food reliably evoke its origins in Providence. In the large Legacy Place shopping "mall" They had no problem with us sharing lunch and divided everything. Arancini was an excellent appetizer. The servings are large enough for 2 to share. The sole concern was the tartness with any hint of sweetness in the marinara. The star of the show is the Carbonara, perfectly seasoned with a wonderful texture.  Service was excellent and this place does a nice job for what it is.  We will be back.Thanks> Similar to the Providence Federal Hill location, this location, service and food is absolutely the best! This sits in busy Legacy Place in the old Met Bar location and its funny I didnt realize it was connected to the Providence location but it is. The menu is a ton of delicious Italian dishes all, born out of creativity and all fabulous and tasty. The start to finish in this place is about service and it still contains elements of the Met Bar surroundings but it is unique in its own way. The service at each location is top notch and attentive and friendly and the food start to finish is what you would expect from a high end Italian restaurant, delectable. We ordered the calamari and beef carppacio to start and it was excellent and then on to the short rib gnocchi which was equally delicious and on to a molten chocolate cake which paired with gelato was awesome. This place is heaven on earth when it comes to fine dining outside the city and you cant go wrong with any dish! Prices are what you would expect and everything was excellent!> I really want to give this restaurant a higher rating but I just can't and here's the reason why...I was pleasantly surprised coming to this wonderfully decorated restaurant that had a really good vibe for a bar environment and a restaurant dining experience. It was very warm and comfortable and the people who work there were nice. So we sat comfortably in the bar area about 3 pm.I was actually excited because I was so pleased with the ambience and I looked at the menu and they had all the typical Italian dishes you would expect at an upscale restaurant. Unfortunately, the happy feeling took a turn when my daughter had a dirty fork... we took a picture of it.This was really bothersome so all I could think was hygiene and does anybody know how to operate a dishwasher?  There was something dirty in my water glass so we got a new one. I'm thinking, does the staff hate their job or are they plain lazy?  I couldn't figure out why we didn't get any bread so I had to ask for it. That came after my first dish. We ordered from the $5 bar bite menu which was a cauliflower and mixed in with figs and pine nuts which were absolutely delicious. We ordered two major pasta dishes which was the  carbonara and the fruitti di Mare. Unfortunately these two dishes had some lacking substances which makes them far from authentic Italian dishes:Carbonara- it was quite salty and even though the presentation was appealing after you mixed in the raw egg, it seemed that salt was added onto the pasta and I didn't taste the pancetta. I feel that it wasn't freshly made from scratch to get that automatic bacon taste blended into the pasta.  It tasted  pre-made.Fruitti di Mare- This was the biggest let-down for $31. I'm not going to lie to you...just was not worth the price... The tomato sauce had commercial high sodium taste that you would get from a can. None of this was freshly made. It was quite sad since you don't even taste garlic or parsley into this type of seafood dish.It appeared that the Seafood placed in the dish was pre-cooked and then added into the linguine sauce, mixed together and then placed on a plate. If this was fresh shellfish, then the juices from the mussels and clams and shrimp would have blended into the sauce. The shrimp was overcooked leaving a chewy taste. The calamari tasted commercially cleaned and frozen because it seemed like it was pre cooked too. The juices from all the shellfish should have been apparent in the sauce...not here. This was very disappointing. There were no fruits of the sea here.I did share my opinions with the server, Virginia. She was a very sweet person but it would have been good for her to communicate with the manager on site and had that manager do something about our meal. I would expect that response from a high-end restaurant. The meal was edible and the fact that we were hungry we just have to accept it but it was a huge let down from the cauliflower that set high standards for all of us. Finally, we had the tiramisu... That was home made and the presentation was fine.I absolutely hate writing low scores in a restaurant that potentially have the opportunity to be a five star restaurant.  The dishes need to match the ambiance in all seriousness. I am stating this point with the best intentions of true honesty because  I have eaten in a lot of Italian restaurants world wide and domestically and I even cook Italian at home. Feel free to see my other reviews on Italian restaurants here in Boston like Carmelina's in the north end. The issue I have is when you have a big upscale restaurant with fancy equipment and state-of-the-art architecture during a non busy time like 3 p.m., you shouldn't have a problem. The place was fully staff but I felt like nobody really cared. I don't know if I would come back to dine here but I'm sure this is a good place to have a drink at the bar.> I gave this restaurant 4 stars but I really want to give it 5 stars some day and right now from my experience I should probably give it 3 stars. The 4 stars are really for the service that they provided. We stopped on the way to Boston because we read the reviews on Yelp and it sounded pretty good. It was a lovely place and I had the absolute best Caesar salad that I've ever had my life. I have never had one that had actual anchovies on top and these were the white mild anchovies which were delicious. The beer and the wine were good. Our server Edmund was outstanding. I ordered the lasagna which was not to my taste at all. It was gummy and robbery and burnt on the bottom. My friend had the veal chop parmesan. It was a pretty good except that the pasta that it was on was al dente to the point of being way under cooked. We expressed our concerns to the server who was very interested. The manager came over and we explained that it was just not to our taste it was not the restaurant's fault maybe but just our personal preference. They insisted on giving us dessert which was plenty to make up for what they felt might have been a lack on their part. The manager came over again and gave us a gift certificate because they want us to come back and have a really good experience. I can't say enough about how I felt so special there.  They obviously want the customers to have a good experience and come back and we definitely will be back to give it another try and get those stars up to 5.

We (2 ppl) ordered the BBQ Sampler that came with Memphis Ribs and Smoked Caribbean Wings w/ Collard Greens, Cucumber Salad, Dirty Rice, cornbread and corn on the cob ($27 Total). The food was incredible the ribs were tender, the Caribbean rub was on point and juicy! My favorite side was the cucumber salad, I'd definitely come back just for it. The cucumbers were marinated in some type of oil or dressing that was really good. Great spot, vibrant atmosphere and good eats!> Ive stopped in today for a Combo plate. I was not dissapointed at all.. The Ribs and chicken was Very good... The Cornbread was moist and sweet, and the baked potatoe good... Service was Good and fast. Nice clean quiet place...> Great little bbq find on the south shore.  The food was really good.  We ordered ribs, chicken and brisket and for sides cornbread beans and cucumber salad.  We both grabbed a drink while we waited for our takeout and I think our total bill was $45 which I think is a great deal!  If your looking for bbq on the south shore I definitely recommend Tennessee's real BBQ> Not very good at all. I'm a BBQ fan but this spot was a great at best. Not returning.> Take me to another place, take me to another landMake me forget all that hurts me, let me understand your plan.- Arrested Development.   Tennessee's BBQ in Braintree has a motto. Real BBQ, Real Fast. It's an oxymoron if there ever was one. Hours of preparation are required.  Smoking meat is a day-long affair: a full day or more for a whole hog, less for smaller cuts.  Most often hickory, but also oak, apple wood, and wine or whiskey barrels are the raw materials that lead to a pinkish "smoke ring" just beneath the surface of the meat. The act of smoking barbecue has a certain Zen-like quality: minimalist, with an abiding awareness of temperature and smoke concentration. It is a meditation of time, smoke, and flesh that requires non-action as much as decisiveness.  Producing good barbecue generates meat that is falling-off-the-bone tender, moist, and smokey. Tennessee's does just that. I came for the meat but I'll stay for the sides. I got a two meat combo that came with three sides. Brisket and Beef Ribs with smashed potatoes with gravy, cucumber salad and macaroni and cheese. I had leftover meat. No leftover sides. The serve root beer on tap as well as regular beer. I chose the root. All that's left now is to lean up against a tree with a piece of straw in my mouth. Pull my hat over my eyes and hum the song to sleep. Tennessee....Tennessee.
