popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: Dorchester Vietnamese restaurants suck.  They're all so goddamn excellent I can't figure out how to review them.  Like Anh Hong is delicious, but so is Hien Vuong, so is Pho 2000 and Ba Le and all the others.  So how do I compare different degrees of excellent? Dorchester Vietnamese needs its own Yelp.Right, anyway.  Anh Hong has pretty good pho (not the best, I still opt for Hien Vuong) but it's main attraction that they take a food and then serve it to you seven times.  Fish, beef, they'd probably do pork if you asked nice.  The seven courses are all different, some involving burning your fingers rolling rice paper rolls, others involving burning your fingers cooking over an open flame.  Each course has its own interesting flavor profile and mechanism of causing you pain.  And there's seven of them.  It helps the variety that they're not just meat.  Like I said, rice paper sometimes, other times you try to shield your fingers with leaves of lettuce (it doesn't work).I don't remember the exact price, but it was roughly the cost of a single course at most other places.You see what I mean here? How do rate seven course of delicious for the cost of one course of mediocre (see: all of downtown)? It's not even fair.> Growing up this was my family's go-to spot for fried rice, pho, rice plates, smoothies, 7 course beef. In recent years it has gone downhill. Food doesn't taste the same. Really tight parking lotI wanted to take my boyfriend to authentic Vietnamese food. The server was not helpful in explaining the different courses of 7 course beef or the pineapple sauce that came with it. Not English-friendly. The manager was making fun of my boyfriend in Vietnamese to her employees, not 10 feet away from us. Iced passionfruit juice was warm on the bottom. Y'all are lucky we tipped the American standard 18-20%, not the normal Vietnamese standard, a couple dollars cash.> You can't go wrong with Vietnamese food in Dorchester. With so many restaurants to choose from it's really hard to try them all if you aren't from the area and distinguish which is the best. What's great about Anh Hong is that they have a pretty extensive menu. They offer the typical pho, vermicelli bowls, and rice plates that you can find at most Vietnamese restaurants but they also offer a lot more. I like restaurants you can go to if you are in the mood for food that is reminiscent of a home-cooked meal especially since my mom's cooking is 1800 miles away. You can come here for a simple meal and get a bowl of noodle soup, a fun meal and try the 7 courses of beef AKA bo 7 mon, or a comfort meal with canh chua (sour soup) and ca kho to (caramelized fish). Good food at cheap/reasonable prices easily win me over. The food here is pretty good and affordable. The muc rang muoi (salted fried squid) was tasty and definitely had a kick. I appreciate the amped up spice from all the jalapeno peppers. While it isn't my favorite, it does the job of satisfying my salty fried squid cravings. I got the banh hoi, dau hu ky, chao tom (steamed vermicelli, fried shrimp paste wrapped in tofu skin, grilled shrimp paste) to make my own spring rolls. It came with a bowl of hot water, rice paper, and a mixture of fresh and pickled vegetables. The chao tom was delicious and had a nice flavor but the dau hu ky kind of fell flat because there wasn't much shrimp paste inside nor was it tender or juicy inside. Nevertheless I was able to make about 4-5 solid spring rolls.> We decided to venture down to Dorchester because we heard that it was the spot for the best Vietnamese food in the Boston area.  After reviewing the Yelp reviews and menus, he chose Anh Hong, and it did not disappoint. I think he chose this place from the set course menu (which I don't recall the name of at the moment) but we ended up ordering more conservative (portion-wise) items from the menu when we got there.  The bulk of the menu includes different combinations of proteins, which you can get with rice, vermicelli, or "shaped vermicelli" (or something like that, I cannot remember the exact name) which is just noodles that have been cooked together and turned into..patties?  Think instant ramen when you're boiling it, before the noodles get super soft and fall apart.  The "shaped vermicelli" comes with rice wrappers and a bowl of warm water, because you're supposed to wrap your own spring rolls with them!  A little unexpected, but fun.  Also, the "fish paste" was delicious!  I was expecting something novel, but it was a yummier version of fish cake that I'm used to, skewered and fried. (Aren't English translations of Asian foods hilarious?)I'd love to return to try more things on the menu. It's also really close to Bambu, which is where we got some dessert after lunch.  Double win.> This is an excellent place to get some delicious Vietnamese food!  I've been coming here on and off for years and the quality has always remained consistent.Items we ordered this time as of 1/20:Dac Biet ($8.95) - Broth is great with lots of flavor. They don't skimp on the meat and vegetables either!Grilled Pork Slices and Shredded Roast Pork Skin ($9.95) - One of the favorite things I like about this restaurant is the quantity and quality of the pork they have here.  Some places deep fry the pork slices which makes it hard and chewy but here the meat is tender and really flavorful and with a heaping portion of pork!  The pork skin isn't bad though I wish it wasn't a cold side dish.Grilled Chicken Vermicelli ($8.95) - I was pleasantly surprised as to how delicious this dish was.  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the chicken was crispy and tender with an abundance of flavor.  I'm glad they used chicken thigh instead of the breast!Overall if you want some great Vietnamese food definitely give this place a visit!

cusine_types: Asian Fusion, Latin American, Juice Bars & Smoothies
reviews: Brunch was awesome. I highly recommend. Also, having eaten here several more times now, something to keep in mind-- the sauces and flavors in the specialty dishes are quite intense and can overwhelm the palate after a few bites. Might consider asking for amount of sauce to be lighter.> Little Pecan recently opened in Brighton Center and boy what a treat! They advertise themselves as being a Latin/Asian fusion restaurant as well as offering a fresh smoothie and tea bar.We have been twice now, once for brunch and once for dinner. We have done both takeout and dine in. For dinner, we ordered take out. I got their pad thai while my partner got the blood orange stir fry. The pad thai is not like traditional pad thai but is very sweet and includes candied pecans. Truly SO good. The blood orange stir fry was very fresh with chunks of blood orange and a delicious sauce to go with the rice. Not a huge portion, but certainly worth it's low under $10 price tag.For breakfast we dined in. I got the Farmer's Hand sandwich which is grilled sourdough bursting with bacon, a fried egg, avocado, arugula, griddled tomatoes, and a citrus aioli. It was so amazing and the flavors worked together. My partner got the carnitas hash which had huge chunks of carnitas and fingerling potatoes. They serve their free water with ice and adorable paper straws. The business itself is small but clean. They have changing LED lights, beautiful bathrooms, and cozy booths/benches to hanker down in to relax. Service was friendly and although we didn't order it, the coffee comes in very cute cups.Almost everything on the menu is vegetarian, although some dishes have meat or you can add meat in. Also, everything seemed to be under $10 which is great for Brighton. Again, not huge portions, but still a good value for your money. This will be my new go to spot for dining in the area.> Loved the banana foster pancakes and farm hand sandwich. The bananas were sweet and slightly crispy. The maple cinnamon butter was heavenly but I love butter so?> The zucchini noodle arrabbiata was wonderful. It was cooked perfectly. The 'zoodles' were thick and I loved the fresh taste of the vegetables. I'm in awe of this dish because I've never had it taste as good from other restaurants, and even my own zoodle recipes are nowhere near matched in quality. This place is very conveniently located near me so I'm anticipating more orders and looking forward to what else they have to offer.> Whoa. Brighton Center has a new king, and its name is Little Pecan Bistro. I don't always prefer the cute hipstery newcomers to the charming old time hole in the walls, but it's undeniable that Little Pecan is just devastatingly delicious. What is of particular note is the way they do certain American favorites better than most of the surrounding businesses. Both their steak and cheese sandwich and their fried chicken sandwich are among the best versions of either I've ever had, and competition for those two sandwich types is fairly strong throughout that two block radius. Luscious, colorful, dripping with flavor, served with fresh home made French fries. And the staff is very friendly and kind! Little Pecan has swiftly leapfrogged over the competition to become my favorite lunch joint in Brighton, which is no easy feat. My wife and I even felt that the food was stronger than that of some of the (notably delicious) high-end dinner places in the area, too!

I love coming here after ordering on the user friendly app, and even friendlier service. As soon as a get to the store, it's already set up for me and they just ask for my name and I enjoy. Avoiding the waiting in line thing is great.Oh, and this location is super clean, new and in a great location. I'm stickin' with J Mike's. Best sub shop around.> Not a bad sandwich... much like Jimmy Johns... lots of stuff stuffed in a small sub roll. Clean. Decent menus. Decent staff. Bathrooms are seemingly clean. The parking is kind of tight. Had the Italian and was ok. Had to ask for mustard and mayo... they looked at like I was crazy for declining oil and vinegar. Not a bad place. Better than a Subway.> I'm such a bread person and the French bread used at Jersey Mike's is scrumptious! It's soft yet crispy, exactly how it should be. This was my first time ever trying this franchise and I'm pleasantly surprised. I've never heard of this place until it came to my city. If I were to rate it on a scale I would say Subway, Deangelos, JERSEY MIKE'S SUBS, and then the local sub place I grew up eating. For a franchise, the subs taste like a mom and pop deli. Thats a big compliment! When I first walked in I noticed right off the bat how clean it was. The workers were very friendly and quick. They take your order, you pay, and then they call your name when your order is up. They have a simple and effective system for ordering. I ordered the steak and cheese and my husband ordered the chicken chipotle. We ordered two regular sized subs and each one was $8 and some change. It would have been cheaper to get the large sub and split it but we wanted to try each other's order. We both thought the steak and cheese was going to be our favorite but we actually loved the chicken chipotle sub even more. Whatever sauce/cheese mix is in there can be bottled and sold. It's so good and creamy! It's one of those subs that you'll regret eating later if your lactose intolerant. The steak and cheese had peppers and onions and I felt like it could have handled a bit more, but that's just personal preference. The proportion of meat to bread was great. The pictures don't do the subs justice because they definitely taste better than they look in photos. My husband and I will definitely be back!> Just had the gluten free Philli  steak sandwich and omg so good ! I love that they offer gluten free bread and buns because it's the only place in area that does it ! You just got a client for life !> This place is amazing. Super clean , VERY nice behind the counter and incredible full & fresh!!!!!

Crossing Nines is a great spot to spend a Sunday afternoon, or even if you want to have a low-key weekend night outside of the city.They have quite a few beers on tap and they have a full bar for liquor.  The inside is covered but it still feels like you're outside and they have TV's for the Redsox games.  They also do live music all the time.Outside has some of the better views overlooking Boston and they have a fire pit and a nice lounge area to enjoy the outside weather.Food is OK, if the food was great this would easily be a 5-star location as it's worth the trip outside of Boston to begin with.  It's not bad, I just think it could be a little better. Wings could be fried more, the garlic aioli heavily mayonnaise based and seems to be paired with everything, etc.4.5 stars> Golf, drinks, woman, sun, view of the city, driving range, drinks, woman... lolNot a bad place to hang out> Crossing Nines is a great spot! Great vibe, good drinks, even better view! Highly recommend for a date night or a girls night out! And Sam McIsaac is the best bartender there! If you go, definitely ask for her!!!!> Good view. Ok drinks. Turkey club wrap was disgusting and soggy. Menu says "pasta salad" as a side, it was rice? Took 1 bite and gave it back and the waitress said "you didn't like it?" I responded "no it was awful" and she just took it away and still charged us, haha. Save yourself and eat before or after coming here.> The live music is shit and so loud I can barely hear myself think. It's 6 pm on a Saturday. Send help.

Most important: this place is deserving of a higher rating than what it sits at on Yelp. We live in the area and eat here from time to time and order out as well.Generally speaking I've found the service to be good. When it's nice there can be a wait for a table outback on the patio, during which you can grab a drink and enjoy the outdoors. I agree that the food isn't always perfectly executed, but perhaps that's the difference as we enjoy it as a tavern rather than a gastropub. Food will be decent, a few things will be great, and a handful of things are a miss. We've often brought family and friends here all of which have enjoyed it. They did a great job with renovations and the inside aesthetic is interesting - old school belted fans, Americana, and a pretty charming industrial tavern aesthetic. They also do a consistent job of decorating for the holidays.Good beer and cocktail list, and an easy place to spend a few hours eating and catching up with friends, family, and neighbors. Favorites have been their kale salad, burger, crab rangoon dip, cauliflower, wings, mac and cheese, and pasta have all been favorites of ours.Good place to bring kids too - they're very accomodating.> Wow- What an incredible brunch at the Bowery Bar today! The service,  cocktails, and the food were absolutely perfect! Best burger I have had in a long time! Pomela Grapefruit Cocktail, Adult Coffee, Delicious Crab Ragoon Dip, and Incredible Steakhouse Burger!> Went for dinner with a party of four.  The cocktail menu is very good. Spinach dip app was delicious. Could have been "warmer". Baked in a dish with cheese. The dip was luck warm when it arrived at the table. Enough for 4 to share.  Shrimp cocktail was 4 HUGE shrimp. We ordered The following entrees... Lobster Mac & cheese , a chicken pasta dish (forget what it was) short ribs, chippy (fish and chips).  Tater Tots (they are VERY large and you get 8)  The food was good. The service was good. The wait time on food was over an hour- not good.  (3 stars) when server says I'm sorry your food isn't out, i think someone else grabbed yours by mistake but it will be out soon.  I would return when weather permits sitting on their large outdoor patio for cocktails. There are just too many other places that are much better for a good dinner.> Wouldn't go back here if my life depended on it. Go in at 3 on a Sunday to watch the bruins game. Whole side of booths are empty. Tried sitting us at a connected booth with a very uncomfortable chair with no view to the ttv for whoever was sitting in the chair. Asked for a booth was told no. They r for bigger parties. Yet I counted 8 booths open.... so instead of giving us a booth they rather lose the business.  WillNever be back.  Friday or Saturday I can totally understand them needing the space  not Sunday at 3pm!> Good thing I didn't check the reviews before I came (a rarity). This place is a block from a friend's house and 4 of us went to The Bowery Bar on Presidents' day to have some food a dranks. I'd like to go back, so I hope my good experience wasn't an anomaly.Since it was Prez day, we had the day off from work and met at Bowery Bar at 1 PM. The waiter was attentive through 4 rounds of drinks and lunch. I mean... I know that I had the root beer old fashioned (a little too sweet for me), executive mimosa (a mimosa with an extra kick), the pain killah (rum and goodness) and a french 75. If I had more than that, I don't remember (did I actually order the espresso martini or just thiiiink about it?). Lol! I enjoyed the fact that they have a large drink menu and Buffalo Trace in their bourbon selection. There are so many other drinks that I would try here!For food, I had the market cobb salad which came with chicken for $17. It was one of the better cobbs I've had. Plenty of good chicken, yummy bacon, egg and avocado. Despite drinking the entire bar, I still couldn't finish the salad. I'm thinking of moving to this area. If I do, I have a feeling this place will become a mainstay.

Traditional tapa service, delicious food, and pretty descent prices! Very beautiful atmosphere and the costumer service is excellent! We felt we had like two waitresses taking care of us and they even had one gentleman going around from table to table telling costumers about the history of their wine! Thought that was pretty interesting!One thing to note though: if you make a reservation, expect to be seated 30 minutes to an hour after the time you reserved, especially if it is a Friday or Saturday night because they are very busy. Ill still give them 5 stars because it was worth the wait and they let us have our first round of drinks on the house because we had to wait so long!> You cannot go wrong here. Everything they do is perfection. Even dishes I don't typically like, Barcelona can convince me to give it another go. The wait staff is among the best, professional, friendly, and generous staff. I can't recommend the croquettas highly enough. And be sure to ask your server for a wine recommendation. They all know what they're doing there!It's my go-to spot for a nice evening out. Great for professional events, a casual evening with friends (bar side), or a romantic date night for two.> Came on a Friday night and although the food was amazing the service was a little lacking. Granted it was a busy night, we made reservations and had to wait 20 mins past it to get seated since they were backed up and the place was CROWDED even though we came at 8:30 to eat. Bar area was packed and people were leaving their drinks everywhere. They sat us closest to the door even though a couple had left that spot earlier for the reason that it was super cold (by the window) and rowdy from people waiting and bar next to it. Food wise, our tapas came out fast but not the drink we ordered or the bread...? It was kinda odd and we had to specifically try and call our waiter after our cheese plate, chorizo and fig, and croquettes came BUT no drink or bread and oil that you usually receive first? Anyway, I would recommend all the food we got they were delicious!! White sangria delicious, Cheese plate, chorizo and fig, truffled bikini, croquetas, and paella. Honestly cheese plate was so big and the bread and everything quickly fills you up, the seafood paella was for one and was enough for the both of us.> My fiance and I decided we wanted to head into the city for a nice dinner so decided to come to Barcelona Wine Bar after hearing good things. We made reservations for 6:30pm but still ended up waiting for about 30 minutes passed that on a Saturday night. There was an event happening in a section of the restaurant so I am not sure if that type of wait time is normal with individuals who have reservations. Outside of the long wait time, the restaurant environment is a great place for a date night, group hang out, or even drinks after work!In terms of food, I had no complaints. We had the Spicy Eggplant Caponata, Jamón & Manchego Croquetas, Paella Mariscos, and Pulpo a la Plancha. I could not say a bad thing about any of those items. I'd order it all again and maybe double the croquetas. I realized 4 croquetas was not nearly enough after my first bite (FYI: I only had two, because I had to share with a certain someone). Paella was also great; the rice had lots of flavor and the seafood in it was delightful. Just be prepared to spend a little if you want to try multiple items. The Paella alone was $24.50 per person.> To start - 4 stars because I hate being negative and the food here truly is awesome but the service, wait times and organization need some work so just go in with your eyes open but your stomach ready for some great food. My partner and I have heard amazing things about the food at Barcelona.   All which are true - amazing food, good drinks, great time, etc etc. That said - we made reservations the day of to eat at Barcelona - 7:30 reservation on a Saturday night and arrived right before 7:30 and were asked to wait.  All normal.   7:30 came and passed, 7:45 came and passed and it was 8:00 before we were seated at a table - 30 minutes after our reservation - no silverware on the table. Throughout the course of the meal, we were served the wrong drink, had the wrong order dropped at our table and one of our orders forgotten by the kitchen. Service aside - the food here is delicious - the eggplant, seafood paella and croquetas are just a few of the items we ordered but the ones I would happily order again. Next time we come - it'll be tapas only - everything coming out of the kitchen looked absolutely delicious!

They serve mostly seafood. It is really good food, and they give you nice sized portions.> I'll start off by saying most food was actually really good. Some highlights were the French onion soup, cheese lasagna and Caesar salad with steak tips. Also the complimentary bread they give you is delicious. We did not enjoy the meatballs that came as a side to the lasagna at all. Staff was very sweet too. What really turned me off was how dirty the restaurant was. They have like a dark blue carpet and there was so much trash and half eaten bites of food on the floor, I had to consciously not look down or else I don't think I'd be able to eat my meal. It's really not that hard to just do a quick sweep after each table... you don't even have to vacuum each time. I'm talking chunks of bread with bites taken out of them on the floor.> Everyone in my party liked their food, but it wasn't the best food we have ever tasted.  The clam chowder, was good, but not great.  The fried fish and clams again were good, but not amazing.  The clams were a bit over cooked.  The Boston hot dogs   were a bit of a disappointment, as the beans and brown bread seemed out of a can.  I thought the cole slaw sour and not very tasty.  The prices, however, were fantastic, especially for seafood located across the street from the ocean.  The owners could easily up their prices to make more profit.  Eating here is a good value.  The waitress was very kind.> We stopped here before we checked in to our hotel. We ordered the New England clam chowder soup along with a grilled chicken & roasted peppers sandwich. I have to say the soup was phenomenal, one of the best I've had in a long time. The sandwich was a bit on the dry side. They should have added some mozzarella. My son had a personal pizza which was huge we had to take the rest to go. Nice size portions and free Wifi.> First I want to say that I have been here numerous times and each time I've had excellent experiences with both their food and service...until tonight. This review is entirely based on service...or the lack thereof! First time in the bar and I waited briefly for a seat. Here's the problem... once I sat I waited for nearly 10 minutes before even being acknowledged. It was as if the bartender just did not want to look at me. Now, keep in mind there are only about 12 seats at the bar and they weren't lined up at the bar. In fact, as I sat down, there were three seats that opened up.Once the bartender finally acknowledged me, and, thankfully wiped down the bar in front of me and gave me a menu, I waited another 10 minutes before I called it quits and left. I mentioned this to the hostess on the way out and she apologized, but, seriously, no need for anything like this. Is it too much to say,,"Hi. Be right with you."? A really disappointing, aggravating and frustrating experience.

People will have different opinions of No Relation and I think it really depends on what you compare it against.Comparing No Relation to omakase places in NY or California you can say it is below your expectations. There are obviously more traditional ones with Japanese chef and higher quality ingredients in NY. But comparing to existing omakase places in Boston, it is actually not too bad. My coworker went on a Tuesday night and we booked a month in advance. I had to change reservation a week prior and the manager was nice enough to accommodate the change which is great. We had our meal a year ago at 95 dollars per person but it seems price has increased quite a bit. But at 95 it's really worth it. Paired with sake, I think the sushi tasted good, although a bit too much sauce and rice tasted vinegary. The rice came from an instant pot instead of making batches with bamboo or wooden materials. I haven't been back since because I do believe NY ones are better. But if you are dying for an traditional omakase in Boston, this is probably the best one to try.> I would like to start by saying this that my review is based on my expectation of a bit more traditional experience. It would probably be more of a 2.5 star if that was an option.I am Japanese, but pretty much been in the Boston area my whole professional life so I've been to many of the better sushi places in town. If you are going here, I'd recommend going there with the understanding that this is NOT traditional omakase. Probably because Colin's put his spin on it, which I can appreciate fusion in it's category but probably not they way it was presented.The unfortunate thing about this experience was that the fish was fresh but because he tries so hard to be "unique" he combines some of the ingredient together and the subtle flavors of the fish gets lost/compete with each other. As an example, the Uni was combined with another Shima Aji. I actually tried the Uni a little bit by its self. It was amazing! But with the Shima Aji and the Aji amarillo + Maui onion, you cannot enjoy the Uni's subtle flavors (I love uni, but I feel none of the boston area sushi or fish market delivers at a consistent rate. We even ordered Uni that was from Japan once and I'd say that was the only time I appreciated within the last year. I was really hoping to enjoy some Uni just as a gunkan-maki here) They also use some red vinegar for the sushi rice that a) looks strange as the rice looks pink (sushi should also be enjoyed with your eyes and I think the white rice really lets the fish stand out), b) was wetter and more vinegar tasting than it should be - each grain should still be able to stand as it's own and enjoyed. Someone else also mentioned this but - there is a lot of yuzu added. Perhaps have yuzu salt on the side for people who choose to put it on to enjoy for some of the dishes. Also the a la carte at the end was ok - I agree, it feels a little forced. If you actually want people to order a few more of their favorites maybe lower the price.... I'm all for nice fancy prices for delicious food but since this reservation requires you to pay in advance and say it's "All inclusive", perhaps you can provide a little more option or flexibility in the price point at the end. OR just include it as the "Omakase" actually means. Just saying.. The experience as a whole, was nice - but that's about it for me. The ambiance is nice. It was a year end meal for my husband and I. My husband, who grew up in Maine and has been to Japan with me before, did say that being able to talk to the chef Colin like that was kind of cool. We did do the beverage pairing which is another $60 but well worth it since they'll give you sake and wine ever 2 course. The sake served was good, but nothing top shelf based on my research. If you haven't been eating sushi for a long time or looking for instagram worthy dinner and you have some extra cash, go for it.> No Relation has been on my radar ever since I heard about this place.  It's in the same family as Bar Mezzana (also on my "to try" list) and I have to say that the sushi options in Boston have noticeably improved since I first moved to Boston many years ago.  No relation has a thoughtful omakase menu with fish sourced from all over the world.  Quality is fresh.  My dining companion got to pop his caviar cherry (it was an add-on), and I got to try an uni tasting (also an add-on). The small space is well thought out and beautiful.  There is a map behind the sushi bar that has flags for where the fish was source from. One thing though- the consistency of the rice was very off.  Like...mushy?  Not sushi rice?  I don't know, but the rice (it comes with almost every bite, it matters!) was what kept me from giving this place 5 stars. Photos on instagram.com/letseatwit…> This was a fun experience, being in an intimate environment with the chef and presented with 14 yummy courses. We had the 6pm reservation but started 20-30min late because someone was late from the other party, so please plan ahead to arrive on time! The chef was nice and ended up starting the rest of us first, then had to catch up the other person and her friend once she got there. It's not a traditional omakase; the chef incorporates interesting twists on flavors and different types of sauces such as cherry blossom, brown sugar, yuzu, etc, so if you're looking for a simple traditional omakase this may not be what you're looking for. Some pieces really wow'd me and melted in my mouth, yet others weren't my favorite but still was good and worth a try. Note, I did feel a bit pressured to order alcohol or more pieces a la carte at the end. Make sure you're aware that it's inside the restaurant Shore Leave!> Hopped in here to experience this little hidden gem as an early birthday treat for the hubby and it was a voyage for our taste buds!  We're always on the hunt for a unique Omakase experience and this was no different. They carry a reasonable amount of fish sourced right from Japan and some of our favorites that night were the chutoro, yellowtail, kohada and of course, the add-on option of otoro.    Now many people have a certain fondness for a particular style of preparation so if you're not open to a little bit of creativity with the rice, you might find it a bit eccentric.  They had varied recipes for the rice used for many of the nigiri.  Me on the other hand, I love any preparation of sushi that melts in my mouth - period.   So leaving it up to the chefs and being totally surprised and bewildered (in a good way) only adds to the experience. Very exclusive and very intimate with only 9 seats available so definitely book way ahead of time if you're looking at a weekend slot!

Daily catch was amazing! My only regret was not ordering the calamari. Small but cute restaurant that seats around 22ish people at a time. One server with impressive customer service skills. We got the linguine + claims and absolutely loved it.> Like waiting in absurdly long lines? How about burnt garlic? Great, this is the place for you! For appetizer, I started with the "World Famous Fried Calamari" because how can you not with a name like that. And found it to be extremely...OK. It really was good...but fried calamari is always pretty good. The marinara dipping sauce has just the right amount of spice to give a good kick.The pastas...where to start. Don't get me wrong, I like garlic. I would have loved the generous amount of garlic they put into the pastas. Unfortunately, said garlic was so burnt you couldn't taste anything but acrid bitterness. This was both in the aglio oilio with the squid ink pasta and the shrimp and scallop pasta. Seeing as how I waited an hour in line (having gotten there a mere 30 minutes after opening I might add), getting burnt garlic pasta was very disappointing. I will not be putting myself through that torture again!> Decided to go here from a friend's recommendation. We went there during weekend day around 6 and there was a little line. The restaurant is very small with limited seating so it could take time to get table. Service 5/5 very attentive and fast serverDeco 4/5 the seating is a little cramped from limited spaceFood 3/5 I like the Mussels Siciliano the most out of all 3 dishes that I had. Overall the mussels seemed fresh but there are some that smells weird. Calamari, i was so excited about this but it was a total disappointment. The batter was pretty soggy. The anglio pasta is a bit salty but it was not that bad. I had better squid ink pasta somewhere else. So for the prices and the taste of the food, this place is just okay> Last night in Boston and I decided to close it out at the Daily Catch.  I'd been there before and had the Aglio Olio, which is ground calamari with black pasta.  Very good. This time I got their specialty: the Lobster d something.  This dish has almost everything seafood in it:  lobstah, calamari, shrimp, clams, and mussels.  I love all of these generally.  This had the potential to be really great but fell short because it wasn't seasoned very well.  Definitely not worth the $60 price tag for taste but not bad for quantity.This place is small, but there seems to have steady foot traffick so I would advise going when they open (or within an hour or two of opening) if you are able to and want to avoid waiting.> I had heard of the Daily Catch location in the North End, but was surprised and thrilled to learn that they had a location in Brookline near my Airbnb. So after a movie at Coolidge Corner Theatre (I really enjoyed my Brookline experience), I walked over for solo dinner at the Daily Catch. I knew it was popular and that there would be a line. There was. I got in the line around 6:30 on a Saturday night, and around 7:30, I was in. So, yeah, be prepared to stand outside and wait. Why are you waiting? They have SEVEN tables. SEVEN! (Three four-tops and four two-tops, I think.) One chef, one dishwasher, one waitress, one busboy (I think). It's TINY. Tiny, tiny, tiny. So, after I got inside, I was hungry and ready to try some of what makes the Daily Catch so talked about. I ordered wine to start, because that's how I do dinner. Then I ordered the  stuffed calamari as an appetizer (stuffed with "Sicilian stuffing" - pine nuts and raisins, and served in a red sauce). Filling? Great. Sauce? TO DIE FOR (I sopped the leftover sauce up with my bread so I wouldn't waste a drop). I found the calamari itself maybe the slightest bit tough, but still a very good appetizer. At $12.50 for two pieces, it was a good appetizer for me, since I was eating solo. Then I ordered a half portion of their black pasta (which you can order as aglio e olio, alfredo, or putanesca). Their house-made squid ink pasta was great. I ordered it aglio e olio (ground calamari, olive oil, garlic, and parsley), and it was great. It's served in the pan, which was a fun, rustic touch, and probably cuts down on dishes for such a small place! I loved that they offer their pastas in half or full orders! Perfect for a solo dinner so I could get an appetizer as well. After another glass of wine, I ordered a slice of their cake to go. This was the least successful thing I ordered at the Daily Catch. Way too sweet for my taste. But the rest of the meal was fantastic. And the service was great. And the atmosphere is great. It was just a really good meal. Great coastal Italian. If you like seafood and Italian food, check out one of their locations (I suspect that the North End location has even longer lines, though)!

reviews: My husband and I eat here often. The food is delicious and Joel the owner/manager really cares about his restaurant and his customers. Prices are very reasonable. Great soups, wonderful chimichangas, delicious meats and flavorful, generously portioned soups. We have tried many items on the menu and loved them all. The restaurant recently got a liquor license and the drinks are great. I loved my sangria! My only criticism..wish their salsa was chunkier It is everything you would expect a neighborhood restaurant to be. Service is friendly, but can sometimes be slow....so watch the Latino soap opera on the screen (no sound) and try to figure out what is going on while you wait!> I had seen this place when looking for Mexican food near Malden and the reviews really caught my eye. So we decided to check it out for lunch one day. Great little spot. The staff was warm and friendly. We started with complementary chips and salsa and we ordered a pupusa which was warm and delicious! Then we ordered our main dishes, my husband got the molé chicken dish and I got chicken enchiladas. Everything was fantastic and I can't wait to come back! You definitely should check it out!> After 5 years in the Boston area, I can safely say that I have found the best Mexican / Latino food place in the greater Boston area! Joel puts so much love and attention into each plate and it comes out in the combination of flavors! Everything is so FRESH! Their chips and salsa taste like your grandma/ mom made them. Their plates are portioned extremely well and the taste of EVERYTHING is to die for. The restaurant itself stays true to the character of a real Mexican/Salvadoran restaurant and you feel so at home eating the delicious food. Malden is so lucky to have this place!!!! Definite recommend!!!> Get the pupussas!! Great quesadillas, tacos, and salsas. Friendly service, fantastic prices. Small space that seemed to do a lot of takeout.> This cozy little place has amazing food and excellent service. We had the chicken Milanese and the steak, both dishes were really good. We are definitely coming back.... highly recommended..

I had never been to Roslindale before, but live nearby in JP, and Sophia's Grotto came up in my search for new local gems. I came for dinner with my boyfriend early on a Friday night, about 6 PM. First of all, the surrounding area is so charming with the brick patio! We were seated immediately. Its pretty small inside but I really liked the vibe, very cozy. Service was great, no complaints. Food was delicious! We started with calamari. For main dishes, I got Sachetti, which was ravioli with cheese, prosciutto, and vegetables. Very tasty, but I preferred my boyfriend's pick, which was pesto pasta. That was phenomenally rich. Our cocktails were also delicious.I would totally come back here for an intimate pasta dinner when I don't want to go into the city, and plan to come back in warmer months so I can experience the patio!> Good food, beer options, and friendly staff. Very small place during the winter without the outdoor seating. We went with as a party of 5 without a reservation on a Saturday night at around seven. The host informed us that because we were 5, it'll require a seat at the end of the booth, and there's only one booth that'll support that. As a result, the wait would be around 90 minutes. No problem, we got some drinks at the bar. They had a great selection of beer, including Maine Beer, which is always nice to find. I ordered the mussels and they were delicious; I'd definitely get them again.The ambiance was cool - tucked away behind a building and felt very secluded, dim lights, good setup overall. I definitely recommend checking this place out for the food alone.> New favorite. Great menu attentive service welcoming atmosphere delicious food and beverages. Enjoyed every aspect. Highly recommend. Can't wait to return and try other selections.> I can't even begin to tell you how much I loved this place. A true hidden gem. Very warm, cozy and very welcoming. We were looking for a Saturday noon adventure and found this place. Found with a chalkboard sign in a brick sidewalk. The menu speaks for itself...a little pice is a trattoria from Italy in Roslindale The Torino pizza is a must. I got the baby arugula salad with prosciutto and I added shrimp. We cleaned our plates. And a pumpkin martini... Maybe two, to finish. Joe the owner a Caroline the bartender made use feel so welcome.  I can't wait to go back.> Wow- what a gem! I was given multiple recommendations to try Sophia's Grotto, and I'm so glad I did. We made a reservation to dine here on Valentine's Day, where they had a special menu. This menu featured a lot of what was on the regular menu. We enjoyed a caraffe of the Chianti, patatas bravas, and stuffed artichoke hearts to start. The potatoes were cooked till crispy on the outside and soft inside, in this delectable tomato and horseradish aioli sauce. Perfectly spicy and well balanced. The artichoke hearts were out of this world delicious. A well cooked artichoke wrapped in crispy prosciutto filled with soft warm goat cheese. For entrees we had the 8oz filet and rack of lamb, both served with mashed potatoes and asparagus (I substituted green beans with asparagus). All three components of our meal were outstanding and could stand alone. Everything perfectly cooked and well seasoned- wow. For dessert (although we were stuffed!) we split a piece of chocolate mousse cake. Deliciously smooth and rich chocolate mousse on a thin layer of chocolate cake. The service, decor, and music all great as well. It's a small restaurant of maybe 12-15 tables and has a lot of heart. Can't wait to come back and make recommendations here of our own!

Impressed with real Izakaya style food experience in Boston. Many Bostonians would agree with me that it is rare to find good affordable Japanese pub style restaurants, especially in Boston. I was hesitant to try this place as my experience with their chain in Allston-Brighton few years back. I decided to give it another try after I heard they recently moved to Porter. Boy I'm glad they move closed to my house! We ordered sushi combo, some special sushi(tuna, snapper and etc.), Suguyaki Okonomiyaki, Ika yaki and of course a glass of cold Asahi beer  sushis were surprisingly good, probably better than sushis from most of sushi restaurants in Boston lol Ika yaki was perfectly cooked and Okonomiyaki was pretty good, but I would've wanted it to have more toppings like I had ones in Japan. I'd definitely recommend this place and keep in mind that you probably need to wait at least 30 minutes if you are coming here on weekend nights. We waited about 40 minutes on Saturday night, which wasn't that bad. I believe that you can put yourself on Yelp waitlist, so utilize that! My dumb self forgot to do that and had to wait more :P> Ittoku is a japanese restaurant that specializes in small plates that are more for family style sharing than individual dining. It is on the pricier side as well so sharing is optimal.All the dishes are great but the standout dishes to me were the beef tongue steaks for starters. The flavor is incredible and the meat itself is wonderfully tender. Next, the mantaiko (?) Pasta was a special but delicious. Its like a cod roe creamy pasta that was lighter than expected but refreshing compared to the umami of the beef tongue. Pass on it though if you dont like fishy taste for obvious reasons. Okonomiyaki is huge. Very different dish but I wont say it's a must. Yakisoba wrapped in egg is a good dish but also nothing incredible. Grilled squid is a large portion and tastes great. Really cool seeing the whole squid. Skewers were also great, loved the gizzard and pork bellyThese are just a few dishes that I had that stood out or are pretty hyped here. Definitely a place to visit> I was so excited to try Ittoku but was unfortunately pretty underwhelmed by the dishes we ordered. I felt that the prices were pretty steep given the amount of food in each order - the salmon ikura mini don ($7) contained only two pieces of salmon and a pretty small serving of ikura. The carpaccio and house okonomiyaki were ok, but I wasn't particularly impressed especially given all the rave reviews I'd seen. Even so, the lively atmosphere made for a pretty positive dining experience. Would definitely be open to giving this another try!> I have to say I liked Ittoku way more when it was still on Commonwealth. Now that they have moved, their price also went up dramatically compared to what they used to be. Very disappointing to say the least. Here are examples of disappointment:1. Skewer Price and Quality:  my favorite skewer used to be chicken skin and chicken tail. Before it used to be around 2 dollars per which is reasonable, so they have doubled to 4 dollars each. Think about it, for 8 dollars you can get a good lunch, here you get two skewers. They have the 5 skewered for 13 dollars deal for mix and match, but they will you chicken gizzards instead because it's so much cheaper. 2. Price in General: My girlfriend and I spent 40 dollars each for the meal and we weren't even full at the end. Where as before 30 dollars on average can be satisfying, now it's 50 or 60. Most dishes the prices went up by at least 2-3 dollars, inflation don't even increase that fast come on.3. Portion: they have drastically reduced some dish portion as well. For example, omusoba which was a stable on the menu, they used to serve you entire portion wrapped in omelette but now they are cut into smaller pieces.I used to go to Ittoku every month or so, now I don't think I will be back. Sugidama Izakaya by Davis Square is much better from both price and quality standpoint.> Thank you so much for opening in these difficult time. Take out is the only dining option but the food quality is still super impressive! Hang in there! Can't wait to dine in when things are back in normal.

menu_dishes: Marinated Olives, Grilled Shishito Peppers, Crostini, Salumi, Formaggio del Giorno, Beef Carpaccio, Burratini, Octopus Salad, Mixed Green Salad, Spicy Tomato Soup, Prosciutto Wrapped Monkfish, Branzino, Squash Risotto, Roasted Half Chicken, Pork Chop, Wagyu Sirloin Steak, Garganelli, Spaghetti Allo Scoglio, Potato Gnocchi, Agnolotti, Strozzapreti, Tagliatelle, Heirloom Carrots, Herb Roasted Fingerling Potatoes, Broccolini
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: Intimate | Bright | Half-ChickenINTIMATE: The Resturant is small. It has about 15 tables ranging from 2-4 people with a "bar seating" set up. There is no music in the Resturant so it's the ideal spot to have conversation. While the restaurant is small, it isn't noisy. BRIGHT: The entire restaurant has white table tops and the walls are painted white which really elevated the overall happy vibe people exude while they are in the Resturant. From Watching HGTV, I know the extra space perceived in a white kitchen as well as how much more calm and soothing a white kitchen is. HALF-CHICKEN: I had the half chicken which was really well done. It had a light crisp exterior and a very juicy interior. It came with fingerling potatoes and greens. Overall the dish was very filling and I would get it again. At the same time, if you aren't "that hungry" look at another plate unless you want lunch for the next day. Pro tip: definitely make a reservation between 6-8:30pm. This is a popular spot. Pro tip: grab a drink downstairs at their sister bar "drink" to either start or end your night.> Really good food, but a bit pricyWe went to Sportello as a part of Dine Out Boston 2020. Unfortunately, that Prix fix menu didn't really appeal to anyone in our group and we ordered off the normal lunch menu. The food was really good (I had the Roasted Half-Chicken) and the service was excellent. However, our bill (with a drink) came out to over $50 a person which is a bit pricy for lunch.> In early December, I dinned with friends and former coworkers at Sportello in Boston. I had eaten here multiple times previously when I worked just down the street, but now that I had been out of the city for a year, I thought a visit to an old friend was worth it.  And as a result, a Yelp! Review.  The staff is always accommodating and knowledgeable about the menu.  From recommending wine to offering opinions on their favorite dishes, it is refreshing to hear the staff take a stance vs. feeling like they have never tried anything on the menu before.  For pasta which is made in house every day, you can't go wrong.  The gnocchi were thoroughly enjoyed with infused lobster and the tagliatelle with bolognese meat sauce was probably the best tasting at our table.  The squash risotto was tender with hints of brown butter and parmigiana.  Meanwhile the pork chop was also juicy and cooked to perfection.  We didn't save room for desserts, but we were certainly tempted by the cannoli and coconut cake offerings.  I missed you old friend, and am already looking forward to my next visit.  I recommend Sportello when you are in the Financial or Seaport districts of Boston.> My boyfriend and I had received many recommendations for this restaurant so we finally got around to trying it. We had a reservation at 8:30pm and were sat at the swanky bar. The atmosphere was very chic but a quiet and a little stuffy for my taste. The menu is a bit confusing, it includes a "let us cook for you" section and a la carte but it's not clear what this means. We figured our waitress would explain this to us but instead after having to flag down a different waitress to order drinks and then once our original waitress approached us again she pressured us to order right away and seemed annoyed when we kind of fumbled around the menu. We ended up ordering the Tagliatelle, duck and side of Broccolini. Each was very good but in truth way too expensive for what it was. It was fun to try because it's been considered a hot spot for about a year but I won't be returning.> Best pasta I've had to date! I got the potato gnocchi and it was heavenly. The gnocchi just melts perfectly into your mouth. It was an exquisite blend of flavors with truffle infusion, mushrooms, peas, and lobster. Highly recommend! The food came out incredibly quick and I was surprised to be able to be seated immediately despite my entire party not showing up yet. Got the melon and vanilla ice cream with espresso poured over it for dessert. I would skip just because it was two scoops with ice cream with an espresso shot layered over it for $10, cost benefit analysis does not add up.

I am not good at English so all I can say is tasty.The shrimp soup has rice in it, spicy and rich, perfect for a cold winter night. The free bread might be for dipping in but I was too hungry so I just ate it. It was crispy and appetizing even without the soup. The serve of the soup is just right for one person. I feel lucky I walked into this restaurant.> Havana oOo nana! This mom and pop restaurant is my first Cuban cuisine experIence and I am impressed already! The wife (hostess and waitress) is super hospitable and the husband (chef) is reserved but nice. The Grilled Skirt Steak with  Chimichurri sauce came out sizzling and the taste, phenomenal! A must try if you're in the area!> This place had great service and friendly staff from the moment we walked in. When you first sit down, they bring you garlic bread, which was a nice touch because I was starving (but is it a Cuban thing? Not sure) We took yelp's recommendations and got the Cuban sandwhich (which had two different kinds of meat, cheese, pickles and mustard) and the beef with the creole sauce. I loved the beef plate; it had peppers, rice and beans and the sauce it was soaked in was delicious. The "salad" was a little unimpressive with the ice berg lettuce and a tomato, but didn't take away from the quality of the main dish. The Cuban sandwhich wasn't my favorite (mostly preference of the things on it, not a reflection the quality) but I loved the plantain chips and the sauce that came with it! Will be back to try more!> Came here for lunch  and decided to try their cuban sandwich. So far I've enjoyed all the cuban sandwiches I've had in Jamaica Plain while I can't find any decent ones in Cambridge! At Old Havana the sandwich comes with freshly fried plantain chips which were also very good. What I really enjoyed about this place was the friendly staff and great service. I definitely need to come back and try one of their entrees.> Ive now eaten here twice, the service is very friendly and its a nice place.  The food is a bit too salty for my taste and the over all quality and flavor is mediocre at best.

Wow! Wow is all I can say about this place.  We had six dishes and each one was superb. The wild mushrooms in escabeche were delicious  -- served with a perfectly cooked egg, the mushrooms were swimming in an incredibly rich, velvety and complex sauce.  The roasted beet salad with fried almonds, sheep milk orange and mint was perfectly seasoned -- fresh and excellent.  The wood roasted mussels were equally delicious.  With bread, we soaked up every last bit of liquid.  The wood grilled sweetbreads in verde sauce were wonderful served with a wood grilled lemon.  Every dish was different, perfectly seasoned and a gustatory delight.  I'm from San Francisco where good food is everywhere but I can't wait to go back to Watertown's La Bodega.  This place is an absolute gem and the service tonight was great.> I think I'd have to give this place another try to see more than 3stars. The ambience and decor is very warm and stylish. But, my experience with the service was out-right terrible and the food was mediocre at-best. Wine selection is limited. Food menu nothing to rave about. We ordered 2 glasses of red and a few tapas. Server stopped by 40min later asking how "everything" was. Then realized we hadn't received anything. We watched as she scurried to the computer and entered our food order. It was apparent she had forgotten to enter our order. Upon her return she mentioned the printer in the kitchen wasn't working. How she knew that is beyond me, because I watched her the entire time and I did not see her speak to anyone or enter the kitchen. We eventually received the the mushrooms and roasted peppers first. They were just ok. Mushrooms tasted like beef stock. The paella was a sad joke. Took a couple bites and left the uneaten plate on the table. Server removed our plates, handed us the bill and didn't even offer dessert. Not a single item was comped. I hate leaving negative reviews on service, because I get sometimes people have off days. But, how else can staff improve without feedback?> Such a vibe. I found this place and just had interest so went on an easy wed. I will def be back  on a weekend for a fun night. its a tight space ( think glass greenhouse and old school town car had a baby) impactful minimal decor. Great tapas bites..something for everyone--seafood and cheese for me , meat and cheese for the husband. Nice wine lists. Cool craft cocktails it seems ( smoke infused manhatton) i will be back for the entire dessert menu - There fb and info is a bit hard to find,  but if possible I would try to make a resy. Oh and shout out to the sweeet lady who was hosting, but may be more involved on the back scene. She was pure passion and pride.> Love this tapas place in Watertown. They have great cocktails as well. The fideos is our go to dish here. Can't wait to come back. There is an ample amount of street parking.The layout is a bit weird since they have 2 sections (the bar and then a streetcar section).> First trip to La Bodega. Very happy with the experience. Friendly servers and a really unique atmosphere that has a very cozy smell that after ordering my drink I realize where it comes from. The Senator Car was a smoke infused bourbon drink that was amazing! Would go back to just explore the other beverages on the menu. Understanding that tapas are small plates the portions did seem a little on the smaller side compared to other tapas places I've been to. Ordered to share the wood fired mussels, empanadas (favorite item ordered!), wood grilled broccoli, roast chicken. Will go back for sure to try other menu items before making final call on this place.

This place is pretty cool. We had made a reservation but the place is pretty big with seats at the bar as well. The food and drinks were delicious and our server was attentive. We got the chicken liver parfait and the duck for starter and both were amazing. We then got the mussels and the fries and the fries was really good but the mussels were just fine. They were still good don't get me wrong but everything was amazing up until that point so we had the same expectations for the mussels.I would definitely go back and try some of the other things on the menu> Yes!   Was told this place was an amazing and it didn't disappoint!Started with the cheese puffs, escargot and the cheese... wow!!!For a main, couldn't resist the Le Burger.... Le Wowwwwww!  So good. Mussels and the tagliatelle also on the must eat list. Thx Boston for my little trip to France !> Our dinner last night was one of the best meals we've have ever had (there were 4 of us)  in Boston (we are from NYC). We had the double Duck Confit appetizer, gougères, Mussels, Beef Borgionon, Poulet Chasseur and Steak au Poivre. They were all completely authentic and incredibly satisfying and delicious. The Cabernet Sauvignon was perfect and we had several glasses, as was a cocktail my husband ordered and I cannot recall the name.  For desert we tried the chocolate mousse, we were split on that, some loved the salty addition and the dark chocolate nibs some didn't. The creme caramel was also a little underwhelming but nice. Be careful though the bread is to die for and when you run out, they charge 1.00 a slice which seems a bit cheap but believe me they are doing you a favor and helping to leave room for the food. The atmosphere is très Parisian and very comfortable. Even though totally packed, not terribly noisy. The severs and especially our waiter were so attentive and charming while carrying huge cast iron dishes, and pots.  Really sweet people including the lovely hostess.The only complaint was the male bartender. He was so incredibly rude and unwelcoming that we nearly walked out the door before our table was ready, So glad we didn't. it's too bad, the experience would have been 100% perfect if the bartender wasn't such a DB.> Celebrated NYE here and let me tell you it was the best meal of the year! We started off with some cocktails and then ordered duck confit, (so tender the meat fellRight off the bone), chicken liver parfait and onion soup. Everything was excellent we couldn't wait to order the main meal. Perusing over the menu where everything looks phenomenal, but also thinking the appetizers did fill us up a bit, we ended up splitting the Beef bourguignon.  If you have never had this dish, I highly suggest coming to Bar Lyon to check it out amongst other incredible dishes. For desert we had macaroons and a custard (similar to flan). My new favorite French restaurant and I know we'll be back to taste some other dishes as well. Also, I forgot to mention parking can be difficult, but definitely worth every minute of it.> I have to give 5 stars because the service was phenomenal. We came here slightly underdressed but were greeted with top notch service which continued throughout the night. Gougeres: absolutely delicious. These cheese puffs were so light but so flavorful, finished them almost immediately.Chicken Liver Parfait: don't know what we were expecting honestly. Neither of us have had chicken liver before but wanted to try based off other reviews. TIP: do not order chicken liver unless you are a fan of chicken liver. Bread that came with it was fantastic, but maybe our taste buds are not sophisticated enough to enjoy the liver part. Either way, not the restaurant's fault. Le Burger: oily. the bottom bun was soggy and soaked with oil from the first bite, and both our burgers continued to drip and almost fall apart as we ate them. We asked if this was typical and they said yes, but offered to make another one without a mushroom layer above the bun, this slightly helped but it was still very greasy. The pork belly was tough. A lot of heavy, intense flavors in one burger.Overall: food ranged from okay to amazing, I would like to try other dishes in the future. service deserves more than 5 stars - so accommodating, understanding, and welcoming.

I love the family feel of the place and the decor is so neat. The food is super simple and so delicious. The steam egg is worth getting! Everything was great, I really enjoyed my Taiwanese sausage rice plate and my partner had the pigs feet.> 3.5 starsDolphin Bay is a fairly simple restaurant with affordable menu items. There are many tables inside and the food comes out quick so it's likely that you won't have to wait a long time. The staff is friendly but it was also hard to get their attention for small things such as more water, napkins, or to pay the bill.I ordered a ton of stuff from their menu and found most of them to be pretty good. However, I did have some comments.- Oyster omelet: don't order this. It was way too gooey and starchy.- Dan bing (egg pancake): very simple. It was just an egg wrapped in a scallion pancake but I wish the scallion pancake had been crispier and flakier. - Bean curd / appetizer combo: I wish the bean curd had been cold instead of warmed up. The braised egg is tasty but not worth buying on its own.- Small pork rice: uneven ratio of minced pork to rice. There was too much rice and it would have been fine if the minced pork was saucier to coat the rice but it wasn't.- Popcorn chicken: delicious! Super crispy.The noodle dishes have lots of noodles in them. It's good since it will definitely fill you up, if the appetizers hadn't already. However, I do wish there were more ingredients/toppings. The braised beef noodle soup only had a few pieces of beef shank and tendon. As they were bringing it over, it was also spilling everywhere which the staff just laughed at and didn't apologize for. Overall, it's not a bad place given the prices and their rich/noodle dishes are definitely filling. However, the service could have been better. Also, some of their items are noted as spicy but they aren't spicy at all.> Good food, not the best experience. 3 of us ordered the wonton soup bowl, the waitress somehow took it as all 3 of us would share one bowl.. So when everyone's food came out, two of us did not have anything and we had to check back with her to find out she put it in as one order. Her response to us saying we ordered 3, not 1: "oh". in the most bored voice.Really? I would expect she would've double checked when she was taking orders if she was confused, because I would be confused if 3 adults planned to share one noodle bowl while everyone else at the table ordered their own dish. We each ended up ordering the spicy wonton noodles after tasting the wonton noodle soup, as it was kind of bland. The spicy one was very tasty and I would definitely get this again. However, it took around 35 minutes to come out after everyone else's food had already come, and by this point they were all done eating. Also tried popcorn chicken rice dish which was a good size and came with steamed egg which was very delicious. The jasmine green tea drink was cute but very mild tasting. Probably wouldn't get it again.Overall the food is good, the male server was very efficient, but the experience wasn't the best as I basically just watched everyone eat for the entire time and then finally got my food and they were forced to watch me eat.> Decent portions. Affordable prices. Good choice for cheap comfort food.Things to order:Beef stuffed pancake (yum)Popcorn chicken (crispy, but the "hot" is not spicy at all)Spicy wontons (meh, more sweet than spicy)Small pork rice ($4.50 - good to try)Things I would skip:Oyster omelette (super gooey, dislike the sauce)> Having spent a lot of my childhood eating food in Taiwan, I am often skeptical of Taiwanese restaurants in the states. I was pleasantly surprised by this place! Cute decorations but there is usually only one waiter/waitress so the service is a little slow.Shaved ice: great for a hot day and it is HUGE. You can choose up to four toppings and they have many fruit options. The toppings are placed on a giant bed of ice which is sweetened with brown sugar syrup. Definitely shareable between 3-4 people since it's such a large portion.Beef noodle soup: the broth tastes very authentic! They give you the option between having all meat or a mix of meat and tendon. The meat is very tender and practically melts on your tongue. Taiwanese food is not spicy in general but you can ask for the noodle soup to be spicy, and they will add more chili peppers to the soup. The portion of noodles is pretty large, so this is good for sharing or if you're hungry. San bei ji three cup chicken: chicken sauteed with basil, ginger, and garlic. I couldn't figure out if it was a mix of white and dark meat or if the dish also includes pieces of pork. Nicely seasoned and a great option if you want chicken but don't want anything deep fried.Chicken cutlet with rice: chicken is very crispy and has similar seasoning to popcorn chicken. The outside is crispy while the inside stays moist and tender.Minced pork rice: tastes authentic and reminds me of what you can get at street stalls or night market stalls in Taiwan. The menu in general is very shareable even if it's not "family style" so definitely a great place to check out if you want to try a diverse menu.

After a fun and fabulous night at Ryan Landry's gold dust orphans show up on the third floor we wandered down to find the basement  kitchen. Our first time around we almost left - the door is unmarked - but I'm glad we didn't. This is a place straight out of my Indiana childhood (where Poles and eastern Europeans were plentiful). All the food is homemade. From scratch. It's essentially the kitchen of the Lithuanian cultural organization,  and feels a bit like being in a very friendly VFW. The president of the club came over to greet us and to make sure we felt at home. The regulars were sitting by the bar watching the Pats game.  We had the stuffed cabbage and the kielbasa dinner. The borscht soup at the beginning was absolutely delicious.  The evening and the meal were perfect in every way.> Great place!!! Everything was soooo delicious!!! You definitely need to try traditional Lithuanian - Cepelinai!> The staff and other patrons were super-friendly, the food was homemade and wonderful, and the place has a very simple, yet comfortable atmosphere. The stuffed cabbage was hearty and accompanied by great sides, the borscht was served hot. I want to go back and try other dishes.> If you like Lithuanian food, you're gonna love this place. And if you don't like Lithuanian food, you're still going to love this place. And if you don't know what Lithuanian food is, you're going to love this place.> Amazing food. Some of the best flavors if you like Lithuanian (or Polish, or Russian - some overlapping geography over time in that region). Most of the conversation around me in the restaurant was in Lithuanian. Cold borscht and potato pie were among my favorite dishes on the menu. Service is limited as it is one waitress for the whole place, but the food is well worth the wait. Almost like Mama's, but so delicious and Mama didn't have to do all the work (or the dishes)!

menu_dishes: Burrito, Taco, Enchilada, Quesadilla, Tostada, Torta, Taco Salad, Taco Plate, Bowl, Kids Quesadilla, Kids Burrito, Kids Rice and Beans, Pico de Gallo, Pico de Pina, 2 oz. Guacamole, 4 oz. Guacamole, 4 oz. Salsa, Cheese, 2 oz. Sour Cream, 4 oz. Sour Cream, Tamales, Chips and Salsa, Elote, Horchata Juice, Passion Fruit Juice, Jamaica Juice, Mexican Jarritos
popular_dishes: No, No, No, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No
reviews: Stopped in for a quick dinner the other day. I ordered a papas con chorizo tostada, a papas con chorizo taco, and sour cream on the side. Food came out in just minutes. Loved the papas con chorizo filling! It was very flavorful. Other filling options available: roasted pork, beef tongue, veggies, carnitas, shredded chicken. The handmade tortilla they used for the taco had a soft and fluffy texture. It was filling and pretty unique (at least compared to tacos I've had at other places). I didn't look closely enough at the menu to see that both the taco and tostada did not come with cheese, so I didn't order cheese as an additional topping. Not a big deal though. I'll remember to order cheese next time! This is a delicious spot. Definitely plan to be back.Taste | 4.5Atmosphere | 4Presentation | 4Service | 4OVERALL | 4.5> Service was fantastic! Called about a misunderstanding with the order (an item got left off of the order) and they were incredibly accommodating and made the item right away for me!Would definitely recommend to a friend (quick, reasonable price, good quality, great service)> Working in south end of Boston one night and started to search for that one great Mexican joint. Finally found this place which caught my eyes with the name like street food. It's a small take out place with high seating and a couple tables. Seems like most people comes here for the quick take out. I ordered the grilled chicken burrito and the burrito bowl with carne asada and guacamole . The only negative star I gave to this place is the extra charge of $2 if you order with carne asada. Every other meat options is no charge. I wanted to give it a 3 stars for that but the good rice , flavorful meat and beans changed my mind . Oh and the homemade sauce was excellent. This was as street as you can get and good authentic Mexican food.> Got a chicken tinga burrito with sour cream and guac. Really yummy and filling but a little expensive. Over $12 for a burrito seems a little expensive but it was very yummy. If I upgraded to a more premium meet it would've been $15 which is nuts!> This is a grab n go (or dine there) but its self service and the seating is limited, so its not ideal for large groups (4+). But the food was yummy! My friends got the taco plates, generous serving size, my bf got the burrito, packed beautifully so it didn't crumble as you bite into it. The al pastor (pork) was delicious, slightly fatty in all the right places. I love me a good quesadilla so I went with their suggestion of the chicken, and boy was that not a wrong suggestion! The meat was so juicy and packed with flavors and I just loved that they stuffed the quesadilla with so much cheese! I even got guac too - they have some selection of hot sauce on the tables as well as their own homemade one - which, in my opinion, not that spicy. Overall, great quick Mexican food, the line can get a bit long, but they are relatively quick with the food prep after you order. I love that there is outdoor seating, so I will definitely be back when I have a Mexican food craving and Chipotle or Qdoba just doesn't cut it.

This place  was just as what others wrote about on Yelp. Seafood, bread, steak, soup, everything were fresh, and cooked just right with the right taste.  My wine: Summation, Kendall-Jackson, Vintner's Reserve, was mm mm good!Afterall, for the price, freshness, and dining experience, this restaurant will definitely be re-visited from time to time.> The name needs to be  changed from Cafe de Paris to The Cafeteria.  The is NOTHING French  nore European about this place.  Just another hodgepoge of a menu the American restautants default to.  Pot Stickers... How French!> Wow rudest waitress I have ever seen. We walked out after she barked "can I help you with something?!" I replied " We would like at table please" she motioned wherever you want. Whole place has a bad vibe. Maybe because we were 50 years younger than average clientele. Anyway terrible service.> Came here for a business lunch.Informed my server that I have gluten, corn, and nut allergies. She nodded and offered me the gluten free menu. I decided to order off the lunch menu as the gluten free menu only offer entree size dishes and I wasn't that hungry. Asked for the cedar plank salmon without the glaze and a side of vegetables with nothing on it.Everything tasted fresh, good and fine till I find a stray orzo at the bottom of my vegetable side. Needless to say, Liquid Benadryl came to my rescue as my tongue begins to tingle, and throat starting to swell. Had to take my medication for my cramps - thanks to celiac. The whole time I sat there, I was worried the allergic reaction might turn full blown and I'll be covered in hives with desperate need for my epi pen jab and an emergency 911 call.All that drama which I wouldn't want during a business lunch meeting. I would highly recommend for the owner to take note on retraining the kitchen staff and server to properly serve and handle food for patrons with severe food allergies.> I had been wanting to try this place for quite some time and this afternoon I finally got to have lunch there. The atmosphere was very nice, the dining room was immaculate and the menu has plenty of dishes to pick from on it. Here you'll find appetizers such as fried calamari and shrimp cocktail. They also have some nice salads, pasta dishes, burgers, seafood, steak and chicken so there is definitely something for everyone here. I opted for the sirloin tips which came with potatoes and vegetables on the side. I also ordered a side garden salad. The sirloin tips were absolutely delicious and were cooked to my liking. The portions were great. The salad was very good and was a very nice addition to my lunch. The bread that was served to me was hot out of the oven and the dipping oil that came with the bread was the best dip I have ever tasted. My waitress, Deborah, was very good and handled all of the customers in both the dining room and at the bar which I found very impressive. I really enjoyed everything, I'm glad I finally got to try the place out and I know for sure that I'll be back. I wish I had tried this place YEARS ago!

Well crafted drinks, nice food selection, and a great selection of gelato flavors.  The staff is knowledgeable and friendly.> I come here for the Vietnamese coffee. It's always something I enjoy. Like most places, they do go heavy on the ice which is understandable. The cup isn't that big so I'd tell them to not put too much ice  so you have more coffee to enjoy. The inside is also a great environment to have 1-on-1 conversations or to just do some work.> Quaint, modern cafe with a tiny but mighty salad and sandwich menu for those savvy to savory. Coffees available, because cafe means coffee. Duh.If it's not plainly obvious, gelato is the star of the show here. Firstly, you'll discover some combinations ne'er-before-seen, and most score high on the temptation-o-meter. Went big scoopin' on Oh Henry!, a hazelnut peanut chocolate mix with cone pieces stirred in. Dug it.The sweets left a stronger impression than the saltimbocca sandwich special (turkey, prosciutto, provolone, arugula) which was fine, but a bit bland.Fast wifi and available seating, which has seemingly become a valuable commodity. But don't go there to work. It's MY office.> Decent gelato. I got the tiramisu and caramel in a cone. The cone was super stale. And I wouldn't recommend the tiramisu (personal preference), but the caramel was so good. The atmosphere of the shop is great for meeting up with friends.> Ordered bagel ham egg and cheese with avocado  and I got this.. order was taken wrong so ham was not added. Also instead of fresh avocado it was canned guacamole and toasted to black and sour. Really the first time seeing toasted guacamole which is pretty harsh in flavor. They remade me a new one with only ham egg and cheese which tasted ok.

Wow, this place just popped up out of nowhere! It's such a cute little place and I don't know how they are able to make everything on the menu...seriously, the kitchen is smaller than the one in my apartment! LolI ordered the pork burrito and it was amazing! Tasted like it had a little cinnamon and pineapple. Hands down the best carnitas style pork I've ever had. They have a bunch of sauces too and my favorite was the tomatillo chimichuri and the avocado crema.Highly recommend!!!!> This is a wonderful new restaurant! It's a bright friendly space and the manager is the man. Try the plantains!!> We grabbed some lunch from Sombrero Chiquito today (thank you for being open during the quarantine!) and were very happy with it. We live close so have been curious and waiting for this place to open. It is super cute and colorful inside with very friendly service. We got spicy chicken rice bowls and plantains + chips & guac on the side. The food was much more authentic than we were anticipating and tasted great. The portions were huge, and he even cooked the plantains fresh for us. Definitely better than most mexican fast casual places. We will be back!> Popped in here for a quick dinner. I got a beef salad bowl and my husband ordered a pork rice bowl. We also got an order of plantains on the side and everything was delicious! It's not what I was expecting, the flavors were so much more unique and fresh than your average Latin fast casual place. I'll definitely be coming back to try their other menu options!> Really good New Mexican spot in the neighborhood. Got the burrito bowl with Mexican corn on the side. One of the better bowls I've had in a long time. Highly recommend!!!

First time coming here, and I'm really impressed. I came here for lunch, and i actually did not get greeted for about 10 min. I just stood at the front door, looking around waiting for someone to come.  I ended up sitting at the bar. Shane was our bartender and although he was fairly new, he was really nice and attentive. I had the shrimp tacos. The tacos were really great, however, the tortillas were a little tough, and they had two of them. It was a lot of dough to get through, even when i just ate it with one tortilla, the taco immediately fell apart. So i ate it as an open taco, which was fine because the filler was incredIble.I had a sangria before i had my coco loco drink, and it was pretty good. But the coco loco was a homerun for me. I would absolutely recommend anYone to order that drink if you like tequila and coconut. The atmosphere was super chill and relaxed. I really enjoyed the music and cleanliness. I will definitely come back, and I'll recommend friend.> We went for Saturday night drinks and Sunday brunch and I was pretty happy with both! The bar and restaurant had good music, drinks, and atmosphere on Saturday night. There were a lot of people having a great time. Sunday brunch was pretty good as well.
