It seemed pretty busy so some of the food took a while to come out and the waitress was split between a lot of tables, so it took her a while to come back to fill drinks. Overall the food was good as well, I had the breakfast sandwich and was pleasantly full by the portion. I saw someone get a breakfast pizza, and it looked amazing as well.> Great little hangout. "Where were you in my drinking days Lucy!" Lots of TV's to watch sports. Good menu. I had the Lucy burger, medium rare. Cooked perfect, good flavor. Big burger barely finished it!> Went to Lucy's for a Saturday brunch. Fun sit down style environment - was pretty crowded. Solid menu variety and reasonable pricing. Mimosas were great. Wings were really good too. Would definitely come back!> I remember when this was a blockbuster !  It's so amazing to see how beautiful the place is and it's in Dorchester. I met my sister in law and my sis there last night for dinner.This is a perfect spot for date night, watch parties and just catching up . I love the open layout and the brown /wood/rustic decor. The drinks that I recommend are the Painkiller and the Moscow mule. The cosmo was too sugary.Omg - the calamari with hits of okra was Delicious ! I also, the buffalo wings were tasty. I'll be back when I'm back in town. I'm not a fan of the complimentary valet. So the place needs self serve parking.

menu_dishes: Mozzarella, Bruschetta, Antipasto, Caprese, Calamari, Peperoni Ripieno, Shrimp Scampi, Melanzane Ripieno, Gnocchi, Ravioli, Lobster Ravioli - Matriciana, Bolognese, Vongole, Pasta Al Forno, Calamari, Pollo Marsala, Pollo Saltinboca, Pollo Parmigiana, Pollo Carrozella, Pollo E Melanzane, Pollo Bracioletini, Vitello Marsala, Vitello Carrozella, Vitello Saltinboca, Vitello Parmigiana, Vitello E Melanzane Parmigiana, Vitello Bracioletini, Melanzane Parmiggiano
popular_dishes: No, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, No, Yes, No, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: The restaurant is very small and the food is delicious so a wait is inevitable, unless you happen to get lucky like I did. I ordered a half sized appetizer - stuffed eggplant and a half order of the lobster ravioli. I honestly have no idea how I would have finished a full size of these dishes. I saw other people's pasta dishes and I swear they got served a bucket of pasta. If I lived in Boston I'd order the full sized dishes and then feed myself for at least two more meals. If you're visiting you may just want to ask for half size. I'd like to add that the service was great too. I was in a huge rush (realllllllly pushing the limit on getting to the airport on time) and they accommodated me accordingly. I'd definitely come back.> Finally tried the famous Rino's after hearing about it for years and listening to my friend describe the massive portions.On his suggestion, we ordered a dish that he couldn't remember the name of and I can't remember the name of. It was basically a fettucine dish with cream sauce, chicken, asparagus, sun dried tomatoes (which my friend raved about), and mushrooms. True to his proclamation, the plate was huge and it was good that we split it because we still had plenty to take home with us. The garden salad and bread were so so. Admittedly, I would have expected better for the bread but you don't come here (or wait) for the bread. By the way, we were told it would probably be a ten minute wait on Friday night around 8 pm so we stopped by Kelly's pub for a drink. While we were eating, we saw others waiting for probably an hour. That said, apparently, you can make a reservation ahead of time. We also shared an appetizer beforehand. I think it was the caprese which we probably should have finished before leaving. The tiramisu dessert was wonderful. As my friend described it, it was light, which is perfect for a heavy, rich dinner. We easily finished that and being a dessert lover, I wish it was as large as dinner.> Great Authentic Italian restaurant.  So worth the wait. Called ahead and waited for them to call us to let us know table was available. Hung out at Kellys Square Pub (Fantastic Pub) until our time. Every thing we ordered in our party of 9 was dynamite. The Lobster Ravioli that we were  told was out of this world was just that... the Frutti De Mare in white sauce and red sauce....knocked outta the park. Al The apps... we had Calamari, Stuffed Eggplant, Mozerrella balls/sticks all made to perfection. All the homemade pasta insanely great....gnocchi, pappardelle, penne....all was phenomenal.  You want great Italian food without having to go to the North End....this is your stop. Service was out of this world also. And on top of all this the price was right. With what they are kicking out of that kitchen you would expect to pay those insane North End prices but not here. This is top notch and we cant wait to come back. A++++#BuddhaReview> This place is soooooo good!! Italian food just like in the North End. The lobster ravioli is the best we've had in Boston (and we have had a lot of different places' lobster ravioli!). Generally a line to get in so plan accordingly...or get take out! YUM!!!!> Another FIVE STARS! Had the same...calamari app, shrimp scampi and gnocchi with broccoli rabi and shrimp. Soooooo good.

If you are looking for delicious Vietnamese subs , cooked foods- porkchop rice or noodles, coffee, or Vietnamese desserts, this is place to stop at. It's a small shop frequented by locals and other visitors. Everything is made fresh and packed on the spot after you order.   The top three items I like getting there are: 1) the cold cut banh mi sandwich 2) Thit nuong- the rice noodles with various sausages and cold cut meats 3) pandan jelly (sold in the mini styrofoam tray) in front of the food counterAside from the prepared foods, there are so many other desserts and snacks you can find around the shop. Depending on what time you go, sometimes there is a long wait. The line wraps around the food and goodies so you have time to browse and check out their selection :)> I would give this place 6/5 stars if I could - SO GOOD. Hands down, the best banh mi I have ever had in my life. I ordered the BBQ beef banh mi ($5.49) and a lychee smoothie ($3.99) thru uber eats ($1.99 delivery fee), and wished I had ordered another one. Prices are unbelievable for what you get, and the taste is unbeatable. The bread was crispy the way a baguette should be (should make a mess when you bite in, and this one def did), and the fillings (adequate amount of BBQ beef, cilantro, carrots, jalapeños that add a kick, pickled daikon) brought joy to my day. The lychee smoothie was sweet (can add boba, coffee jelly, or rainbow jelly to the smoothies at additional price), but not overly sweet, with a strong lychee taste.I will definitely order again and try other menu items!!> I came here after going to the JFK museum, and this was maybe a 30 minute walk away. The store has a lot of different food items pretty much everywhere: on the right I remember seeing dessert and drinks, on a table in the middle there were groceries, on the right there were pastries, and a place to order drinks, and in the back, a hot food bar and cashier. There were a few people (white people) who I stood in line with at the hot food counter, until being told by someone else in line that, if we wanted to order sandwiches, we had to go straight to the cashier. Keep that in mind if it's your first time here!I got the specialty banh mi and an avocado smoothie with boba. The banh mi came out super quickly, and although I waited maybe 15 minutes to eat it, it was super crispy, the vegetables were super fresh, and the meat (I don't remember what it was) was delicious as well. It was very cheap and filling too. Super good and definitely worth the walk.The avocado smoothie was also really good, and I don't know why it's so rare to find them on the east coast. The boba was soft and very sweet. However, and this might just be because avocadoes grow in Hawaii, where I usually drink my avocado smoothies, I think the smoothie with boba was like $5, which is twice what I'd usually pay, and also more than the price of like Jamba Juice and other overpriced chains. Maybe avocadoes are just more expensive in New England? Very good and comforting taste, but it was on the smaller side and kind of expensive.> I've had Banh Mi all across America and this one is definitely one of the top. The ingredients and the bread  is so fresh. I ordered the grilled BBQ beef option and I'm glad I did because apparently it's their best option. The portion size and flavor were both good for a $5 price.I also ordered the Thai tea, the tea is more on the not-sweet side but it's still refreshing. I'm also super excited to try their sugar cane juice. You have to find street parking to go here. The employees are nice but speak limited English so use hand gestures and speak clearly. They have good variety of both food and drinks. They prefer to not use AMEX cards because of the service fee but they can do it if that's all you have. There's no bathroom and no seating. This is a buy and go operation.> Part fast-food take out, part cafe, part grocery store with prepared foods. This place has it all!I came for the Vietnamese iced coffee (only $3.50, cash only) and left wishing that I ordered 2 more. Oh, and I also told my boyfriend to order me a spring roll and summer roll (both rolls come with 3 in an order). He ordered a banh mi sandwich and it was prepared so quickly and stuffed with meat and all the toppings. I was pretty jealous of his sandwich and regretting purchasing a bagel at another place.I really wanted to get the coffee again before we left Dorchester/Boston, but sadly never got the chance. Luckily 2 sets of friends live in this area so I imagine I will make this a must-stop place when I'm back in town!

cusine_types: Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion, Jazz & Blues
reviews: Jazz | Wings | BarJazz: my friend Gil and I arrived at 7:30 and they had a live jazz trio (bass/chelo, piano, singer). The music was classic jazz as well as some original pieces that reminded me of Diana Krall. Overall, the music really added to the vibe and made the overall experience super enjoyable. Wings: I had the Teriyaki Wings. There are 6 in the order. They have a savory glaze with a crisp exterior. They are the perfect small bite or shareable plate for a date. I was looking for something to hold me over and absorb the drink we had, and they hit the spot. Bar: the bar is small but well staffed. There were two individuals behind the bar and the shrink menu was pretty deep. I had a simple glass of Prosecco because it was a celebration of a new RFP My friend closed.  Pro tip: like most of central square There is no parking so definitely walk or Uber. Pro tip: make a reservation between 6-8:30pm. Pro tip: if you don't make a reservation there is a bunch of turnover at the bar so if you are a group of two, you can probably roll through.> I love going to Monkfish for sushi, great thai dishes and excellent atmosphere. I got grubhub delivery as I am trying to support local businesses during this time of difficulty.  However, I am not sure why restaurants are literally ignoring the notes and or not providing proper food. I ordered a yellow curry with chicken, with specific directions for "no bell peppers and extra spicy."  I got a curry w/extra bell peppers and super sweet. Anddddd they sent me pork as the protein--not sure how you screw up so badly?   I REALLY REALLY want to support our community, but am not sure why they feel they can simply just ignore the actual order.> Approx. Date/Month of Visit: September 2019No. of people: 7Reservation Recommend: YesLive Music/Performance: Yes, on some daysCuisine: Asian FusionService: Could have been better. We had to wait to get our checks for almost 15 minutes.Must Try:Tom Yum Goong Magic Teriyaki Wings Don't Try:Coconut Curry Fries> I really wanted to like this restaurant. It has a nice ambiance, cool decor, beautiful ceramic serving dishes, surprisingly delicious cocktails, but unfortunately sub-par food.I got the Penang curry with seafood. I know, given the fact that there's "seafood" in the dish, it's supposed to smell fishy.. but man that dish smelled real fishy. Also the curry didn't have enough actual curry so I was basically eating dry rice and vegetables with seafood about halfway through. I will say though that the vegetables were cooked well.My friend got pad Thai which I thought tasted disappointing, but my friend enjoyed enough. Other friend got the vegetable tempura udon noodle soup and it was a little bland, but still decent. We got coconut fries to share, which I thought were really good!> Unfortunately I did not love it here. Was really excited to try their sushi but it was just alright. The rice seemed to have a little too much vinegar and the texture of it was a bit off, like it wasn't fresh. The fish itself tasted as it should but i just wasn't impressed. There is definitely better sushi nearby. I will say that our service was great and the place looks really nice. Maybe I just came on an off night, but again I was a little disappointed that we spent so much on what wasn't very good in my opinion.

Tender chicken, plenty of flavor and generous veggies!The mini chicken lunch from 11 am to 3 pm is a steal at $5 for a full lunch of a chicken leg, rice and vegetables. The jerk BBQ is tender and vinegary, while the sweet and spicy was intensely spicy yet fragrant. Beef patty ($2.50) is flaky and delicious. Will be back!> Had the "small" curry goat plate. Would be considered a medium or even a large at other places. So I was happy with unexpected leftovers!Super flavorful and the right amount of spice. Great family run spot and probably my favorite Jamaican food in Boston.> Had a taste for Caribbean food haven't been here in years wish I would have skipped all together. Ordered a small rice and peas with steak and vegetable. 10.75 was the price I think that's a little pricey for a small but ok. The rice and peas were flavorless the steak was really dry and flavorless the cabbage was actually the best thing on the plate. I will never eat here again. So disappointed! I should have honestly just tried the newest only one location on river st.> Best Jamaican food around..I give this food a 5star..straight authentic...prices are good and the food portion alot> Had the small jerk chicken plate with rice n beans And veggies. Wow was it tasty. I'd say the best Jamaican food I've had in Massachusetts. The chicken was rich, juicy and flavorful. The jerk has a very potent and tasty blend of spices. It is also quite spicy once you finish eating, it creeps up on you. The small portion was huge, but I guess it should be for 9$. The chicken deff had bones and a good amount of small ones so I know some people wouldn't like that, but it adds to the flavor. The veggies were also very good, almost like a slow stewed collard green, but maybe w some other veggies and chopped up, a good side to cut the spicy meat. I will certainly be back for more jerk chicken plates.

Can't say how happy me and my cohosts were to have found the View and their A++++ team!! Can you imagine 4 girls scrambling to find a venue to hold a 40+ baby shower in 3 weeks?? Well the folks at The View did an AMAZING job! The food was well priced, the set-up was done before I even arrived at the restaurant that morning. Lyal, Billy and his team the day of were on top of everything. It couldn't have been more perfect! And our mommy and daddy to be were so happy!!The place itself is very unique. I opted for the outdoor seating. They have something I call their "terrace". It basically overlooks their golfcourse and since we were expecting rain Billy just took down a few see through panels to keep us dry. We also had a section inside and the folks inside had panoramic windows/doors that slide open so they were never left out and they could see us and we could see them. It's definitely a unique space for sure.After this experience I would recommend to all my friends and fellow yelpers to visit the View for future large and small functions.> I recently had a time there for my son's State Police graduation.  Chris Lisa and Mike could not to enough to accommodate us!  All our guests raved about the food.  The roast sirloin carving station and baked stuffed chicken were tender and delicious. The service was exceptional.  It is called The View for a reason.  The tables were nicely set for an outdoor patio function (although they can also close the patio in for rain), overlooking the serene hills of the golf course.  I would not hesitate to use The View for a function again, and highly recommend it.> The view is the only thing that makes this place worthwhile. My wife and I came here a few months back and will not be returning. The shrimp cocktail appetizer was rubbery and the sauce that came with it was awkwardly sweet and pretty nasty. After this I declined to eat dinner but my wife was equally upset with the fish she had ordered. The other issue is how expensive these two items were. I would say the food was about 30% over what you would get at a normal restaurant but with about 1/2 the quality. This place will live on though as that view IS truly amazing.> Have been to the View several times now.  Once for lunch, and twice for breakfast.  It is a very pretty and relaxing outdoor spot.  With that being said... I have not been here when it's anything but a beautiful day to sit out.  The inside is little to be desired.  The food and drinks are very good.  The service can be on the slow side, but if you have the extra time... just sit back and take in the scenery.> Checked this place out tonight looking for a low key last minute casual father's day dinner. Definitely much more casual thank the Quarry hills restaurant referred to by other reviewer. It's basically like a small sports bar with indoor and outdoor seating.  There are flat screens all over the place; tonight they were showing - what else - golf!! The after golf crowd was pretty rowdy watching it too.Service was pleasant and cheerful but food was quite slow to come up especially if you have a hungry pre-schooler with you, which we did. Her hot dog/fries/chicken fingers were good, my salad was fine and my husband's burger looked awesome. Dinner for 3 (including two cocktails) in the $40s. not bad.

This is genuinely the most delicious food I have eaten in ages. We picked up some basic red olives at the Hingham farmers market and after eating them in the car went straight back to get some mexican hummus and back again for Tabouleh and couldn't stop eating it. Each recipe was the best version I have tried of everything. We are planning to make the trip from South Boston to the restaurant in Hull especially to try their Falafel. I cannot wait!> What a pleasant surprise. Never knew this place existed. Friendly operators talk a big game, and deliver. Incredible Greek Salad. Kabobs are monstrous and tasty. If you're looking for clean, tasty take out in Hull, you aren't going to do any better.> WOW WOW WOW!!! I've lived in Hull for seven years and never knew this gold mine of delicious food existed until a year ago. Now I'm in To Dine For every week!  Imagine this. Chocolate hummus, red beet hummus, quinoa salad, delicious bread and anything else Mediterranean you'd expect for takeout. The owners Rafca and Paula make everything fresh and it's absolutely delicious!  They always offer a free sample to let me taste-test it first. So far, they're batting 1000%! Service you ask?  You'll get treated like family when you visit. These ladies are really wonderful, love what they do and appreciate their customers. To Dine For is located in downtown Hull, directly across from the Post Office and Weinberg's, where I get my desserts. Enjoy!Neil Wood> Mediterranean Mix is AMAZING! I haven't been to the location but I got the last Mediterranean Mix at the Cohasset Farmer Market and I've never been so happy. What a great mix of flavors. The chocolate hummus is very good as well. I wish I lived closer to get something every week.> The food is so good here. The hummus is real. The vegetarian selections are great. Best falafel in town. Everything homemade. Select prepared foods to take home from the cold display case.

menu_dishes: 1. Seaweed Salad, 2. Takoyaki, 3. Crispy Chicken, 4. Gyudon Bowl, 5. Crispy Chicken Don Bowl, 6. Pork Char Siu Don Bowl, 8. Karaka Men, 9. Miso Ramen, 10. Spicy Miso Ramen, 11. Tonkotsu Gyokai, 12. Spicy Tan Tan Men, 13. Tomato Veggie Ramen, 14. Spicy Tonkotsu Gyokai, 7. Isshindo Ramen, Canned Soda, UCC Japanese Canned Drink, Calpico
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: What a hidden gem. It's on the side entrance of the Super 88 market. I've passed it a couple times, but finally decided to try it. I think this place is better than the Ganku Itteksu ramen place in Brookline because the broth is SO much more rich in flavor. I got the Kakara Men ramen on the menu, and it was probably one of the best bowls of ramen I've had. The noodles were cooked perfectly, the soft boiled egg was delicious and creamy and the broth was perfect. I am extremely happy to have found this place because it's so good and reasonably priced. The bowls ranged from $11-14 depending on what kind of ramen. The atmosphere: the place itself is quite small, it gives me a hole-in-the-wall vibe. The service was excellent and quick. The only thing I thought was weird was that they couldn't substitute different toppings although they were the same price...> This was the second time we came to this ramen shop. The first time we came here the menu was only 1 page front and back but now they offer more options to choose from. The staff are very attentive and nice. Food comes out fairly quickly and hot. Over all, a good spot to get ramen in the Allston area. -spicy chicken - the chicken here is so good, is well seasoned and fried perfectly. It's paired with a spicy mayo sauce that's a little more on the sweet side with a little citrusy taste- ika geso - fried octopus that aren't chewy at all. They are fried in a light batter and served with a side of lemon and mayo which-Isshindo ramen - my go to ramen choice here. Portions here are very filling. The egg tastes so good. The only thing I don't like is that they char the pork and it becomes a little dry -spicy paitan ramen - new ramen option. Pretty spicy and is served with fried chicken. Good combo but chicken does get soggy if you don't eat fast enough> Ganko Ittetsu's Tan Tan ramen is my personal favorite.  However, Isshindo's Tan Tan is a close second.  In fact Isshindo wins with the larger serving size, including a full egg (two halves).  Take note, Ganko Ittestu!  That being said, it was a packed house and everyone's soup looked great.  People were smiling and slurping away, luxuriating in their ramen umami on this raw and rainy February day. I struck up a conversation with the lovely couple next to me who ordered the spicy miso ramen and the spicy tonkatsu ramen.  They were regulars who ate there once a week who couldn't stop raving.  You know the ramen was great when you are sad to finish it.Isshindo is a worthy addition to Boston's ramen scene.> Great lunch place to stop by for a few minutes. We went here for a dinner from a friend's recommendation. The ambiance is quite uninviting. Many restaurants like this are tight but this one just felt extra claustrophobic, dated decorations, very uncomfortable chairs & tables, I really doubt anyone would choose to stay longer than 20 minutes. Not a big deal for a quick lunch, but for dinner, not off to a good start.We ordered a hot tea, their signature Isshindo ramen dish, and the miso ramen dish with chicken instead of pork. Let me say this first- prices are AMAZING, $11.50 for each bowl, (which really does fill you up)! However, you get what you pay for. Firstly, my hot tea is served in a plastic cup (which you would serve water or soda in) and it was one measly 10 cent paper teabag of some really cheap stuff. Slap in the face. The soup portions were really great, but it was just too simple. The flavors are all there, broth has amazing body, noodles great, pork was thick and juicy, but that's all you get. The most interesting thing on their signature dish was the egg, which stood out among the other flavors and brightened things up, but it's gone in 1-2 bites. To their credit, you can add other ingredients like extra egg, bamboo, etc... but don't you think at least their signature dish should be a display of their best culinary creativity + finesse? Why should it be up to the consumer to decide what toppings are NECESSARY to turn a good dish to a great dish? I would rather pay $15 and have a fantastic bowl than $11.50 and have it be "almost-there."Another small detail- they charged us $3 extra for the chicken substitute. Now, given that the prices are already so cheap, I would have been OK with this charge if they told us BEFOREHAND. However, we did not find out until the bill came. ouch.If I eat here again, it will likely be on a quick lunch break if I'm in the area. I think it will be an awesome spot for that application.> After hot yoga at the Corepower across the street, you might find yourself venturing over to Isshindo Ramen for a hot, steamy, and scrumdiddlyumptious bowl of ramen. This ramen promised land is conveniently located next to the Super88 Market and Kung Fu Tea with parking available for their customers. Upon arrival, as I was browsing the menu, I noticed many of the options contained pork broth, but have no fear there was couple vegetarian and chicken options- shout out to those with dietary restrictions! I ordered the Spicy Paitan Ramen- a six-hour chicken broth with onion, bamboo shoot, wood ear mushrooms, fried crispy chicken & soy egg. This was a meal that I can compare to ambrosia, the food of the gods. I'd highly recommend it to anyone! Now, I completely understand why this restaurant has such great Yelp reviews.

Tasting CounterWalking in, I immediately knew something special was happening with all the ferments and vinegars brewing on the shelves, that completely fill up one side of the wall. I ended up with the non alcoholic pairing. I honestly didn't want the pairing, but was forced to get it since there was no option to exclude it from my reservation.  The crab "cake" with pickled beets mushroom and mascarpone was delicious! Savory yet refreshing in texture and taste.The harimasa tartare torte was satisfyingly in its crunchy texture and fresh fish taste.The foie gras in the macaron was divine! It hit the tspot in full force!! The texture of the macaron was a bit gummy. Perhaps too much xantham gum?? Its forgivable with the delicious foie gras taste.The langoustine dish transported me to a cold winter seafront that playful takes local ingredients and superimposes a japanese vibe without being obvious. The use of apple in this dish further enhances a sweet yet refreshing profile. The toasted rice vinegar was a wonderful contrast of a dark low tone that still comes off light like an old man dipping tea by his winterside window.The harimasa dish was a wonderful two punch combo of lemon and eggplant. The yuzu koshu was just enough to feel like an alley hoop, followed by the slam dunk of the pine lemonade. I love the liquid presence of a nut in this pairing!!The gremolata dumplings dish was a symphony of flavors that stimulated my mind, satisfied my tongue, and comforted my soul. Light in texture, while firm in its sensual profile. Like a multi layered platform, overarching and overlapping in structure and form, the familiar lemon and garlic, tossed in a delicious sour cream, engulfed by a literal cloud of uni foam - this was heavenly.The branzidino looks like it was dressed like pepto bismal, but its actually purple radish. Its the more adventurous aspect of the meal, where some people may be taken back by the sour pickled flavors. This wasnt my favorite, but the fish was cooked just right. Also the drink pairing of apple and thyme vinegar was delicious!!The trout dish was like no preparation of trout ive seen. The best way i could describe it is a northern take on pimento cheese and Chipotle peppers. Low toned, slighty astringent, and funk thats not sharp but hangs like fog. In a strange way, a mild cranberry is a kindred spirit. The hibiscus and smoked maple syrup tonic was an amazing combo that stretches the horizon of this dish. This dish wins me over for such an unusual presentation that speaks my imagination and peaks my curiosity.The squab was solid. Although I would have liked for the texture be c cooked just slightly more, the compromise of a bloody robust punch of the squab is delightful. What really took me by surprise was the squash piece on the backend. Its as if the squash looked at itself in the mirror and saw a reflection of the squab. The squab smiles menacingly as it takes it hooks its talons into the squash to transform it slowly into a squab!! The squab pate crumbles at its foot side hit the t-spot! The lemon ginger drink was ok but I get it was suppose to contrast.The venison dish was a homerun. What a great way to end the savory dishes. The combination of flavors seem odd but end up working well. The acorn puree really hit it home with its fermented power, harnessing this woodsy feel along with a heartiness I would get from a squash. The chef masterfully infuses chocolate into this dish, honing in on the earthy, acidic nuttiness of the cacao bean, while feeling sultry as a chocolate liquor at times. The cranberries were a great choice, further enhancing the chocolate notes, as well as the "north American" foraged feel.The lettuce sorbet was a sight to behold, as it pulls off what I couldn't do at home myself: take lettuce and make it into ice cream. I wonder if this place as a pacojet, cause otherwise I don't see how they masterfully removed all the fiber and grit of lettuce for this ice cream. Earthy and "green", while still being a sweet, creamy custard ice cream. The cucumber celery granita felt like a drink I would receive from a juice counter at the health food store. The main dessert was quite fascinating in its overall approach. Rather than using chocolates, caramels, or super sweet fruits, the chef here concocts a dessert that seems quite different yet familiar. A pastry puff, with a separate side of ice cream and sauce on the surface, but a beautiful marriage between all three. The hibiscus has the right amount of sweetness to elevate, yet not feel overwhelming. The herbal quality ties well with the pear and rhubarb. The goats milk offers the necessary tang while being easier to digest on the stomach. Everything about this was so satisfying!This is one of those places where it feels like the big leagues, yet the head chef is so humble and nonchalant. If you have the opportunity, I highly recommend you book this first over any other restaurant in town.> Tasting Counter is so far ahead of the curve that it's hard to know where to begin. The somewhat pedestrian name does little to reveal the many wonders that Peter Ungár and his team have created, but the unassuming frankness is a refreshing trait that extends throughout the meal.For $250 all-in, you get 12 courses comprising one of the finest meals you can find in this part of the country. The food at Tasting Counter isn't so much  about rapid-fire seasonality as it is exploring each storied ingredient to its fullest, often in surprising ways. Lobster broth will be gently foamed and infused with Uni to create an effect not unlike pure umami injected directly into your veins. Kuri Squash will provide a formidable partner to its delicate partner in Peking Duck-styled Squab. Rest assured that every experiment thrown your way is delicious from first bite to last. My personal favorite of the evening was a preparation of Nantucket Bay Scallop, Salsify, and Chestnut blanketed in a torched Tonka Bean Custard that was breathtakingly good.If you drink, go with the wine pairing. The natural wine selection looked fantastic and was so lovingly explained that it was often competing with the food for attention. I went for the juice pairing, which was great but a bit heavy on the fermentation and vinegar for my liking. By the end I felt like I was drowning in Beet Kombucha, and would have preferred something a bit lighter and more refreshing. Tasting Counter may not have the Old World class you might expect at this price point, perhaps to its benefit, but there's no question that Ungár has cemented the start of a very promising legacy right here in Boston.> Tasting Counter has been on my list for a long time. I added it when I found out guests were able to watch the chefs prep some of the food and plate it right in front of you - that was an experience I hadn't had before (until I went to Table at Season to Taste). My husband and I were lucky enough to be treated to lunch this past Saturday by friends who were thanking us for our help with their recent move. (An amazing way to celebrate a friend or say thank you, btw)! The seating is all pre-planned, so when the host or hostess seats you, you get seated where they decide you should go. (Given that the seating is very limited, this makes sense). They are also diligent about food restrictions and allergies, and mark the counter where you are seated so that all the chefs preparing the food are aware if you are seafood averse, dairy free, gluten free, etc.My husband was not eating seafood for this lunch, so there were a few dishes that he got that were, quite honestly, far better than ours. The lobster dumplings we got were tasty, but his gremolata dumplings legitimately stole the show. We all sampled a little bit, and had SERIOUS food envy. The flavor was like nothing else! We also enjoyed the foie gras macarons.The reason why I am not giving 5 stars is because this experience felt quite rushed. I can't imagine being at the 12pm seating, since our seating began right at 1pm and everyone from that seating had to make room for us to come in. We ended around 2:10 or 2:15, so we had extra time, and I don't know what we would have done without it! (I assume the dinner seatings may be a bit less hurried with 2 hours of time allotted, but they also have more courses).The food with the wine pairings was hard to fully enjoy because you couldn't take your time. There were a few times I had to sort of "chug" my wine because more had already arrived. Also, when we were completely finished with our meals, there were people still eating, but the chefs and waitstaff were cleaning up all around them, so I think they might have needed to finish up quickly. All in all, a great meal and I enjoyed the whole experience. I'd definitely come back if I needed a place to celebrate something really special, or impress an out-of-towner with fancy tastes.> Lunch here was divine. Each dish was so creative from the welcoming bites (see pics)to the herby ice cream at the end with the moist olive oil cake and crisp pizzelle .Our fave was the lobster dumplings with uni cream. There was also a trout dish with creamed vegetables that surprisingly had no cream and a hazelnut crunch, and dessert mentioned above. The closing bites were also intriguing. A peppery chew, bonbon, and mini canelle was served. The peppery chew was my favorite as it was great to cut through the sweetness of the bonbon. Each course had a wine pairing which was included in our ticket price of $85.Service was impeccable and each plate was presented well. To be able to see the chefs working and garnishing makes this an entertaining dining experience! At the end of the meal I was happily full despite what seems like small portions.> I had high expectations of Tasting Counter based on customer reviews and all the press, but I found the experience surprisingly disappointing.ONLINE TICKETING INPUTS DID NOT TAILOR THE PRODUCTION OF ANY OF OUR DISHES- I had pre-paid for tickets/reservations on the website -- taking time to fill out their forms noting the occasion we were celebrating, as well as dietary restrictions and food preferences.-  While the website touts the online ticketing system and its ability to keep track of food allergies, restrictions and preferences -- there was no acknowledgment of those things when we arrived or as we were given menus.- For my first course, I had to request a modification based on my dietary restriction. For my second course, they also ended up replating it since it didn't take into my dietary restrictions. - We were there on a Monday night, and there was only one other couple there when we arrived. So there was ample space and time to tend to our reservation and food notations.SERVICE WAS ODD, COLD & DISJOINTED- From the moment we walked in, it was strange. A woman was sitting near the entrance, at a computer, but she didn't get up when we walked in. So we found our way into the dining area on our own. - After standing around for a moment, a guy came out from behind the food counter and we gave him the name on our reservation. He seated us. - We were given a prix fixe menu to choose from. It was very cut and dry. ATMOSPHERE WAS FLAT AND LACKED ENERY- The chefs inside the counter looked or acted nothing like the ones in the Google photos wearing white chef coats and hats. They each wore different versions of black, one in a jacket and one in a polo type shirt. They moved quietly and methodically, almost robot like. They were focused, but didn't appear to be enjoying what they were doing. That's how it felt to me anyway. - Later in the evening, the woman who had been sitting by the computer up front came and joined them inside the counter, helping with plating. She wore a floppy fuzzy sweater and had dissheveled hair, and she kept pushing her sleeves up with her hands while she was prepping. For some reason, it struck me as unprofessional and not very sanitary.FOOD WAS WELL-PRESENTED AND INVENTIVEThe food was by far the best part of the night. While I was a little surprised that I wasn't asked how I preferred my lamb loin cooked, it was perfectly medium rare. The desserts were delicious and The appeal of a Michelin calibre menu was a big draw for me to Tasting Counter, but the service didn't deliver on a top-notch experience. I probably wouldn't go back.

Sekali Boston's delivery pop-up has been a bright light in these uncertain times. Our lunch today of Hainanese Chicken, Pork Bao, and Seri Muka, plus surprise complimentary(!) chicken broth and chili crisp, was absolutely delicious, well-packaged/labeled/prepared, and felt very healing (both physically- with all the ginger and garlic- and soulfully- comforting and made with love). I was especially thrilled with their chili crisp condiment- I'm not really a big fan of spicy, and usually only enjoy it within dishes like coconut-based curries, but this condiment had so much flavor and complexity, and didn't overwhelm my tastebuds with heat but instead complimented what I was eating wonderfully. Also worth mentioning that the team has been very communicative and pleasant to deal with, in ordering delivery- a calming presence in the otherwise chaotic world we find ourselves in. Awesome food, awesome service, awesome people- do not hesitate to order the next time they offer!

Went here last night and tried the chef's vegetarian tasting menu. Was a really nice selection of about 10 different vegetarian items. It also came with generous helping of Za'atar covered bread, a creamy brussel sprout dish, and then an eggplant dish at the end. We were stuffed at the end, but glad we tried so many things.The ambiance is really nice and the waiter was very friendly and helpful.> The ambience is really good. It does get noisy as people start pouring in and the space is kind of cramped up too. We orderedBENDENJAL MECHOUI, Chicken Bastilla and Lamb Tajine.Bendenjal Mechoui : Served with three thin breadsticks and eggplant side. I think it was OK.Chicken Bastilla: it is Chicken filling in fried wrap. Rating: Good. Lamb Tajine: Lamb Shanks in a sweet syrup. The lamb so sooo soft and the syrup/gravy was sweetened by dates and tastes yum. This was the best of the three. Rating: Great!Service was good however the food came in late.Overall: It was a good experience.> We had great fun in this boutique and artsy restaurant. The interior decoration is unique and luxurious style. With comfortable pillows and curtains, you feel like sitting in an exotic palace.The food is authentic, according to friends who has been to Africa. I had two teas because it's really good! tangine pot is probably the most special dish you should try.> Truly a disappointing overpriced meal. All of the dishes sounded good on paper, but the execution fell flat. The karantika was overly eggy, the aubergine was bland, and the zaatar coca was basically drowned in tamarind. The vegetables in the couscous were overly tart, and the whole dish tasted like someone accidentally poured in cinnamon rather than salt.All of the dishes were expensive for the portion size, except the couscous. Service was slow - it was about 10 minutes before we were given a glass of water.> Came here around 8:30pm on a Saturday night. While other restaurants on this street have tables and lights outside, open windows, and music to lure passerbys, Baraka's front door is covered with a thick black curtain that separates it from the outside world.The restaurant is very small and charming (less than 15 tables in total), so despite calling ahead, we waited 30 minutes for an open spot. Would recommend calling ahead too to minimize the wait, especially as the restaurant does not have a waiting area. On the waiter's recommendation, we ordered the Bastilla Chicken ($14), Bouillabaisse ($28), and Mkatef [lamb chops] ($27). The amount was just right for two. The highlight was the Bastilla Chicken -- deliciously crisp filo pastry with a great balance of savory and sweet. Perfect to share. The bouillabaisse was alright, maybe thick and too salty for my taste. While the lamb (Mkatef) was cooked excellently, the sauce that spread throughout the dish was slightly too sweet for a dish of that size. Overall, I'm glad we tried this place as it does seem to be a romantic hidden dinner spot, but the dinner dishes left a bit to be desired. Not high on my list of places to return to, but I would recommend skipping the entrees and trying a variety of the small plates.

This place is really good. It was weird walking in at first because it's quiet and no one was there. This place should have more people. It needs to re-do their interior but don't let that bias into the taste of the food.I got lamb briyani, palak paneer, chicken tikka. All good> I've seen and been wanting to try Zam Zam since I moved to Medford about 1.5 years ago and FINALLY got a chance to try it. My boyfriend and I ordered online and picked up. We ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Palak and Garlic Naan. My Palek definitely packed some secret lingering pro-longed heat, but it was SO GOOD. It lasted me 2 meals - though PROBABLY should have been 3, but shhh. I definitely wish I asked for Mild, but Grubhub didn't have a "heat level" option and I didn't process that I didn't request it until after, but it worked out fine. It was a tiny bit oiling, but do a bit a mixing and it's fine. The Garlic Naan was delicious, even reheated.Something important to note is the dishes DO NOT come with Rice, so if you want rice you'll have to order a side of it. We ordered rice and it's a good sized container, that is probably 4 regular serving sizes worth - but 2 big sized meals worth. This place is reasonably priced and though I had no interactions with the folks at the establishment, they seem like nice folks, according to my boyfriend who went to pick up the food.I DEFINITELY plan on coming back. I love Palek or Saag (depending on location) and look forward to eating it again...it makes such great leftovers.> I was looking for a business to support during these tough Corona times and fell upon this gem. I got the Lamb Nehari with plain naan. It was nothing short of amazing. Generous portion, spiced perfectly (it's very spicy), lamb was tender, naan was crispy yet pillowy in the inside. 5/5. I will be back.> We got some takeout from here to support a local business in a time of crisis and couldn't have been happier. Great food. I'd heard and read very good things about the food and they weren't wrong. Will have to try a few more times but definitely among the very best Indian food I've had in Boston.> This is my favorite go to Indian/Pakistani restaurant in the Greater Boston Area. It's all about the delicious food it has to offer. We do take out and dine-in all the time. It's authentic and a must must must try. I highly recommend to check it out!Must Try:Beef NihariTilwale NaanChapli Kebab Chicken Tikka Boti Chicken Biryani Chicken Cholle Chana MasalaDon't Try:Shami Kebab

Excellent service. The son of the owner was our waiter. We didn't find out until we had paid the bill. He was nice and knowledgeable. He recommended food and wine when we asked, but was patient when we said we needed more time. Great service. The quality of the food was amazing. The food wasn't rushed out while we were having the apps. Nor were we  rushed through dessert. The staff were all very pleasant and attentive throughout. The owner even came and checked on us as we paid. We didn't get rushed ouNo complaints for the taste or quality of the food. Il cibo era delizioso. Pretty sure everything was made fresh or as close to.The owner even came and checked on us as we paid. We then quickly realized we were the only ones left and we weren't even pushed out the door even though I'm sure they were closed. Definitely coming back. They made us feel like famiglia. Grazie!> Our go to for local italian dining!! Amazing food, family owned and operated and a great staff!! A hidden gem!> I've lived here in Norwood for over 10 years and didn't know about this place. Had the fig & prosciutto appetizer and the Beat salad  for an appetizer and while those were good, they couldn't compared to the farfalle dish with truffle oil, I had for a main. Our service was great, the atmosphere nice and cozy, but keep in mind that you should make a reservation because from what I've been told it gets busy and you might have to wait over an hour.> Stopped by Vico tonight while in the area visiting  after reviewing a bunch of yelp reviews in search of a great spot. Atmosphere seemed nice with white linen table cloths and an upscale feel; though quaint interior.Ordered a vodka and club and quickly was told that they only serve beer and wine. Not a deal breaker but disappointing.Menu was not huge but had some nice options and descriptions. Ordered appetizers of fried calamari with a chili sauce, and eggplant stack.Appetizers came out quickly. Calamari was decent but lacked real flavor and nothing special. Sauce was a creamy pink sauce and had an overpowering mayonnaise taste; not very good, especially with calamari.The eggplant appetizer came out in a small cast iron dish and looked more like a mini eggplant Parmesan than an eggplant appetizer. It was bland and needed salt immediately, and was very mushy and lacked consistency. Sauce was tasty.My entree was the pork rolled with prosciutto, cheese, and spinach covered in a creamy mushroom sauce. The pork was good by itself but the prosciutto combined was overpowering and did not go well together. The mushroom sauce was an odd addition in my opinion. A friend with me got the lasagna special that had meatball and sausage inside. It too came out in a small cast iron dish. The consistency was all mushy and very soupy with no consistency and couldn't even tell there were noodles inside. Flavor was good but more like a soup than a lasagna.Finally ordered the molten chocolate lava cake with vanilla gelato. Flavor was good but the cake was not at all molten, firm and lacked the quintessential flowy chocolate you expect from a lava cake. Really wanted to score this place high, but missed the mark.> Vico hits it out of the park with great food, service and music..Everyone love the food and desserts..We all left full and very happy..I Highly recommend this Gem of a restaurant

Cesarias in Dorchester is ny favorite Cape Verdean restaurant in Boston. Whenever I go j enjoy my meal. Yes, I know the wait time is no joke but theh never disappoint with their food. The flavors are out of this world. The atmosphere is also great because you really bask in the Cape Verdeam culture. The prices are affordable and you do get your money's worth of food. If you have not been you should and must check it out. Food: 5Customer service: 5> This was my first experience here. It will also be my last. I wasn't pleases with the establishment at all. We had reserved a party of 14 for a friends birthday dinner. They put us in a half booth half table type setup. We were extremely close to the speaker and the restroom. One of my friends hit the speaker tryjng maneuver by to go to the restroom. I feel that there were many other places our table could have been setup. The music and base were so loud we couldn't any longer have conversations with each other.The service was extremely slow. I literally felt myself getting sleepy as the night got later waiting on drinks, waiting on appetizers and then waiting on our dinner. It took 30 minutes for drinks. Another hour for appetizers. 2.5 hours before our dinner was served. We were in the restaurant for almost 4 hours. With such a long wait I was hoping the food was delicious. It was only OK. I had the Canja Soup as an appetizer. It was mostly a broth with small grain rice and chicken bones. We had chicken wings and they came out incorrectly. We ordered half spicy and half no spice. They only served us spicy and said they put it in correctly. Though they never corrected the order. We never received the non spicy wings. The French fries was only ok because there were still raw fries in the batch that wasn't cooked thoroughly. The cajun chicken scampi wasn't a traditional scampi. It had more of a creamy scampi sauce but it was delicious and a nice proportion of food.While using the restroom an employee also used the restroom. She didn't wash her hands before leaving the restroom. She was busy text messaging on her food that she forgot to wash her hands. Yeah, this was not a good moment for me. I am huge on cleanliness and service when I go out. This place definitely dropped the ball.> I had my Portuguese friend who wanted to  try some "Portuguese African" food. I guess I was mislead as I thought it was Portuguese food, but it's more from the island of Cabo Verde (Cape Verde islands).The interior is big. A great place to eat, drink and watch live music.We had two appetizers - the steak bites and the linguica. Then for entrees we had the Cape Verde style chicken (Franco) and Mozambique (steak, shrimp, mussels, eggs, rice and potatoes).> Restaurante Cesaria peeked my interest because they offer "Traditional Cape Verdean cuisine cooked up in a colorful, casual setting with occasional live music." (restaurantcesaria.com)Street parking was sparse, but we fortunately noticed a public parking lot a short walk away.Cesaria was surprisingly roomy inside, and white table clothes dressed the tables.  Walls were painted a cheerful yellow and chandeliers, glass bottles, Christmas decoractions and mirror balls hung from the ceiling.A small buffet is set in a corner consisting of salad, fruits, and five hot buffet stations (some single and several divided), all off menu for the most part, with the exception of the katchupa  Two of us opted to go with the buffet for $12.47 ($13.34 with tax) on a Saturday.  If one has any dining restrictions, however, it is best to order off the menu.Not sure what happened, but it took nearly 50 minutes for our a la carte orders to arrive (though yes, we were warned it would take 20 min for the chicken dish to be cooked).  Fortunately, my DCs were happy with their meals, both the veggie garden (though we noticed that the listed spinach fettucine had mysteriously been converted into regular joe ziti) and the frango assado.From the buffet line up that day, the ribs were my favorite.  And I found the a la carte fries much crisper than those from the buffet.  I'd be up for another meal at their buffet, but am also interested in ordering the Cabritada $12 (stewed goat) or a number of their seafood dishes if I can manage to find a non-spicy version.> Cesaria is a great authentic Cape Verdean restaurant in Dorchester. I go here whenever I want cachupa refugada. It's only $9 and you will always have tons of leftovers since they give you so much. It's always cooked perfectly and leaves me full. I've also had their drinks and would highly recommend the house tea (hot) and their pina coladas. This is one of the few places where I always order a drink because they're so delicious. I've had a few of the appetizers and all are good. The shrimp is incredible and they Cvs fries are fried perfectly. My only gripe with cesaria is that it takes a long time to get your food and also they are often out of menu items. Everything is cooked fresh, but it's frustrating when you really want something and find out they don't have it. Also you should call ahead at least 30 minutes if you want take out. I come here every month or so and I plan on keeping with that tradition. The owner is great, the people are great, and the food is great.

Hands down the best all around restaurant I've found in the Greater Boston area. First off, the number of options here are crazy. I've been ordering from here for the past few years and haven't  worked my way through half the menu yet. What I can tell you- Best and sweetest chicken tikka masala around and the chili cheese naan is The mo-mo is 6 bucks for 8 dumplings The Salmon dinner is an absolute win if you want to get your health onAnd the ribs & pizza are just as good as whatever famous pizza or bbq spot your friends rave about. 10/10 would recommend the Himalayan Kitchen.> We came here twice now and the food is absolutely delicious, especially the Tikka masala and garlic naan!  We also tried the bombay chicken and momos (dumplings) and chai tea.  You can sit down and eat inside but I'd say they do more take outs and they are super friendly!> This unassuming restaurant failed to live up to my expectations, but it was still okay. The bell dinged as I entered the venue, and I looked around to see a beautiful painting of the Buddha etched into the wall. The cashiers were busy taking what seemed like multiple online and phone orders from customers, so I figured this place was going to be good. I ordered garlic naan and chicken tikka masala to corroborate the  other glowing reviews of it. It comes with rice.The food took around 20 minutes to arrive. I was unexpectedly faced with an abundant basket of garlic naan, and unfortunately, my food was placed in plastic containers and came with a paper plate and plastic utensils. I was hoping they would place it in porcelain places and silver utensils. The naan was nice and fluffy but didn't really taste like garlic. The chicken in the chicken tikka masala was surprisingly moist, unlike most chicken tikka masala I've had. However, the usually deep tomato taste was lacking here. I did like the consistency, though. Finally, the rice was fine, but it wasn't the basmati rice I love. But I still scarfed it all down.> Tastiest Nepalese food I've had in MA so far! & The service was great.My friend's spicy chicken momos were my favorite! Awesome sauce!We also got this delicious nan with mozzarella and garlic  inside. Nothing like fresh bread out of the oven.I had the vegetable fried rice. It had basmati rice, and Nepali spices. For dessert we had a kind of donut/spherical cake that came in a syrup. It was warm and lovely.> Wandering around union square and saw this place and decided on a whim to walk in! I ordered spicy pork momos as per the cashiers recommendation. Pretty good flavor. Their momos are fried. also I admit I've never had momos before but I enjoyed these. A few complaints - the "fry" was a bit much and the thickness of the dough made it a tad hard to bite through but over time the sauce softened it up. also as a spice enthusiast I was meh on the sauce which was a very bearable amount of spicy, and had a tang to it that wasn't my fav. They served it in a foil container despite me saying I was eating in... They also don't serve tap water (have to buy a bottle) and most of their tables are for two. Was good but not sure if I crave enough to come back, though it appears from the other reviews that I should also try garlic naan before I pass complete judgement. Not bad for a $7.50 meal.

Amazing food! Amazing service! Wonderful ambiance and everyone is so welcoming! Definitely coming back. Thank you!> Good service , mediocre food is the jist of it.  I liked the table - side guac and Queso fundido.  But my fish tacos had no flavor.   Bummer.  If I go back I would try something else.> This place is the real deal. They don't cut corners, everything seems homemade. The pork is unreal and you can get it on almost anything. Best fajitas and nachos I've ever had. -- it's turning into one of those places rhat you crave to go back.> I've lived in Weymouth for a year now, only a couple days ago did I finally make it in here. Mind you, I have an ongoing quest to find the best tacos in Boston and greater Boston area. What I go as far as to called he's the best tacos I've ever had? No, but, all things considered this place is top-notch, and the tacos are pretty dang good!I have to start with my "guilty" pleasure: chips and salsa. The chips were nice and warm. Not overly greasy, and had a very pleasant flavor. Too many times I come across chips that are bland other than the salt.  On that note, I would like to add just a pinch of salt would have done wonders for these. To be fair, there was salt and pepper on the table.It was the sauce that I found weird to be quite honest. It was served in a decanter which was nice, but rather than what I'm used to, the salsa tasted more like some nice tomato juice with ingredients added. I personally like salsa to have much more chunkiness, much more ingredients other than pure tomato, and to have a little bit more salt and acidity than this one had.I had the opportunity to try the Sopa de Albondigas. A quite surprisingly, incredibly pleasant soup!  I can tell you this with certainty, it was most certainly fresh! The tell is always the potatoes, and they weren't glassy in the slightest! Likewise the meatballs were extremely flavorful! (I'm overusing exclamation points aren't I?). My only critique about the soup is that for my taste it had a bit too much salt.Staying consistent with the overall theme, the Tacos Juanito were fresh, tasty, and just overall wonderful. They absolutely did not skimp on the meat, and the combination of grilled chicken and chorizo gave a nice balance between textures spice, and overall flavors. In retrospect, having the onion and cilantro on the side is actually a brilliant idea. Food is all about balance, and having them separate keeps them from being cooked were they on the meat.  While I'm sure they would not have hesitated to bring out a little more, I did feel the amount provided was just a teeny bit small. I will say this though, in the tacos they did not skimp on the meat!I also found that the lettuce provided was a nice touch, I know man people who prefer lettuce on their tacos, even though that is not traditional (only onion and cilantro traditional, as I understand it).  The rice provided was pleasant, cook perfectly and seasoned nicely, and the refried beans were surprisingly nice.In terms of food I got to finish off with the Margaritas. I was able to try the Top Shelf Margarita and a Cadillac Margarita. Both were strong,  though I have to say I found the Cadillac stronger than the Top Shelf.  The flavors are also balanced in terms of sweetness and savoriness. Additionally while the tequila was visible, it didn't overpower. The location is clean, the service was nice, and for the freshness of the food the speed was good as well> We saw all the good reviews and had to try it out.   We love Mexican and we were not let down.  The margaritas were yummy and the food was delicious. If we are back in that neighborhoods are sure to go again

We are so grateful to have this Market in our building. It is extremely convenient, carrying everything from cleaning supplies to a great selection of beer and wine. Everyone that works here is unbelievably nice- they take the time to get to know you (especially the frequent flyers) and are very dog friendly! I highly recommend the deli counter- their sandwiches are amazing. Also, if you need a quick sandwich and can't wait in line, their pre-made  cranberry chicken salad is a huge favorite. We pretty much stop in here everyday!> This market is sorely needed and appreciated in Marina Bay!Be advised that they primarily carry nice stuff, at nice stuff prices.  If this bothers you, there are plenty of low end stores in Quincy that you can drive to to get something cheaper.  If you're going to compare their prices against Wal Mart 20 miles inland, you're not going to br happy.However, Marina Bay Market is all about the convenience and saving time, for those who want someplace walkable and with quality goods in Marina Bay.For the likely audience, being Marina Bay residents and boat owners, this place is priced and positioned perfectly, open 7 days a week with long hours.  Support this market and our neighborhood infrastructure!> Great selection of beer, wine, snacks and pre-made foodstuffs, but they're recalling honing in on a largely captive audience. Even for a convenience store, everything is selling at theme park prices and I'm sorry but I just can't ignore the fact I spent $6 on Hot Fries and a diet Dew. Skip the muffins esp after the afternoon - they're dry. But totally Do the Dew™.> This market has such a great selection of beer and wine, an outstanding deli, and even a nitro cold brew tap! It is an expensive market but the convenience for Marina Bay residents its great. I had a delicious turkey sandwich made fresh from the deli and it was excellent. The ingredients were very fresh. Everyone working in the market is very sweet too! They even gave our dog treats!> Pricy but decent quality lunch for those work, living or boating at Marina Bay.  They sandwiches are taste and great soup selection.  They have a sushi chef onsite making fresh sushi and custom orders and fairly priced.   Coffee and breakfast selection is excellent as are the wine and beer selection.  A welcome addition to Marina Bay community

menu_dishes: Chopped Salad, Charred Eggplant Salad, Spicy Carrot Salad, Marinated Beets Salad, Marinated Beets, Grilled Carrot Salad, Crispy Hen of the Woods, Chopped Salad, Roasted Brussel Sprouts, Spicy Cauliflower, Cheeseburger, Crispy Chicken, Fried Hake, Grilled Salmon, Campanelle in Brodo, Beef Short Rib, Duck Sausage, Roasted Porchetta, Grilled Colorado Lamb, Sea Scallops, Spiced Duck Breast, Feather Brook Farm Chicken, Smoked Sea Trout Dip, Branzino Crudo, Sour Cream and Onion Donut, Chickpea Panisse Fries, Scotch Olives, Pimento Feta, Black Bean Hummus, Kohlrabi Tzatziki, Piquillo-Almond, Campanelle in Brodo, Squid Ink Fusilli, Semolina Gnocchi, Radiatore di Grano Arso, Spaghetti, Citrus Sorbet, Almond Cake, Apple Galette, Chocolate Semifreddo, Apple Galette, Citrus Sorbet, Chocolate Semifreddo, Almond Cake
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, Yes, Yes, No, No, No, No, Yes, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: Came in for brunch right before the shutdown and was blown away. I'd be willing to say that its the best brunch going, especially now that Townsman is gone. Even still, it might be better. I'll definitely be coming back for dinner, whenever Covid-19 is over.My wife and I split the divine meyer lemon doughnut. The filling wasn't too sweet, which made for a perfect balance w/ the sweet glaze. I went with the steak & eggs, which was literally perfect. My eggs were expertly poached, just as my steak was executed flawlessly. The truffle vinaigrette didn't overpower the rest of the dish, neither did the lardon; everything was well balanced and extremely flavorful. I didn't need to eat until later that night, as this isn't exactly a dish for the faint of heart. To cut the rich, fatty flavors, I knocked back a delightful bloody mary. They produce their own mix, which had a nice kick, a lot of flavor, and was a great consistency. My wife's cavatelli was equally as good as my dish, although I'd rather have it for a dinner course, to be honest. But that being said, it was creamy, salty, bitter (in the best way) from the greens, and overall luscious. I cant wait to come back.> I'm in love - I had such a memorable lunch at Chickadee! My friend and I ordered the black bean hummus, which came with really tasty pita on the side, and the carrot salad, which was lovely and refreshing and also super visually appealing. For my entree, I ordered the grilled salmon (perfectly cooked and so tender!), which was served with the most incredible squash + leek + vadouvan sauce. Our server even offered us quite a bit of extra pita on top of what was served with the hummus, so I could mop up the extra sauce with it! Truly a *chef's kiss* moment. For dessert, we tried the Baked Alaska, which was so pleasant to eat and look at. We left feeling so satisfied and happy :-) Already planning to come back to Chickadee to try their dinner menu soon!> Great spot for a post work drink, dinner or even a dinner date... at the far end of Boston seaport. Food was good, service was great. Our server Ashton was amazing!The Chickpea fries (5/5): AMAZING!! melt in your mouth good. Must order!!Grilled carrot salad (4.5/5): Loved this! Very unique but delicious dish. Shaved carrots with avocado hummus and hazelnuts.Scallops (4/5): cooked perfectly and served with a curry sauce bursting of flavor. Delicious!Squid ink fusilli (3.5/5): tad disappointed with this one. Too salty with that seafoody taste for my likingHen of the woods (3/5): fried mushroom with mashed potatoes. Flavor and texture didnt hit the spot> From the cute table setting to the delectable food to the mind blowing dessert, this place really outdid itself! We had such a wonderful, cozy date and tried so many new things, and the bill didn't come out to anything outrageous. What's more, we actually left full and satisfied, which I feel like is hard to do at a small shareable plates restaurant. My absolute favorite were the chickpea fries- crunchy on the outside but somehow soft on the inside, and with an amazing dip! I didn't have high hopes for the potato skins but wow, they are so good with lobster and steak tartare! We good 3 half potions of the grains, but we couldn't finish them all (paranoia from previous small plates places perhaps). I really loved the farro risotto, which was creamy and came with super tasty smoked chestnuts. My husband's favorite was the gnocci with rabbit; the pasta was pillowy and the squash and rabbit such a great combination! The radiatore di grano arso was pasta with BBQ pork, and that's the only dish that wasn't amazing- a bit too heavy on the BBQ flavor. But let me tell you about dessert. The chocolate semifreddo is this chocolate explosion ice cream ball covered in chocolate sauce with some chocolatey and halva bites on the side. I could come here for just this alone! It wasn't overly sweet or decadent, just so chocolatey and a hint of salty? Wow!> Located in the quiet end of seaport but the little restaurant was poppin' on a Sunday afternoon. Cute interior with a bar in the front. We came here for brunch and the menu was the perfect size: not overly extensive but still with plenty of options for our group. The donuts were a little pricey ranging from $5-7 for one donut - our friends said they were good but not $7 good. I decided to go with the French toast as my 'appetizer' and it was delicious - super soft and topped with walnuts and blueberries and whipped ricotta and syrup on the side which I emptied the whole thing over my waffles. For my main I went with something from the savory side: black truffle cavatelli it had a egg in it so made it brunch appropriate hehe - it was a small portion but filling! My bf got the fried chicken pita which I took several bites of and the chicken was fried beautifully, the pickles and the pickled veggies paired so nicely with the chicken. Not to mention, the pita was also nice and fat, just the way I like them! The chicken to pita ratio was also on point. I got the Mimas (forgot how it was spelled but I think it's their make of a mimosa) as a beverage with the grapefruit and it was very yums - docked a star for the Irish coffee; not sure what it was exactly it was but the coffee flavor came through very bitter. But nonetheless, great service and experience and the food was delicious just wish they didn't charge that much for the donuts or it's more than just one donut for the price. The dinner menu looks delicious so I do want to make another visit!

menu_dishes: Chicken Parmesan Eggrolls, Burrata, Arancini, Anna Maria's Famous Stuffed Meatballs, Capellini con Gamberoni, Bolognese, Rigatoni Affumicata, Ravioli Aragosta, Spaghetti & Meatballs, Parmesan, Marsala, Piccata, Eggplant Parmesan, Old School Lasagna, Pollo Santino, Vitello Milanese, Salmone Mediterranio, Vegan Ravioli, Truffled Caesar Salad, Italian Chopped Salad, Tresca Salad, Margherita Pizza, Bianco Pizza, Siciliano Pizza, Vegan Pizza, Pizza Kit only, Pizza Kit & Alcohol, Tiramisu, Gluten Free Chocolate Cake

reviews: Came here for restaurant week/dine out Boston with another couple and we all thought the food was fantastic. I had a Cesar salad and chicken parm. The pasta seemed homemade and the chicken parm itself was very good and a perfect amount of cheese.For dessert we got chocolate cake and the Tiramisu which both look delicious But we haven't tried them yet because we were so full from all the delicious bread they give out with oil. All in all we all loved everything we tried and would definitely go back again. (two people had the meatballs and said they were delicious)I would definitely go back there again for a regular dinner to try other things on the menu. Only weird thing to note was 1. You don't really get a set waiter I think we had a total of 7 different people come to the table all night taking orders and filling water so confusing when we wanted to flag someone for something. 2. We did valet and after we walked around and came back to the car it was unlocked which I found strange. (Not the restaurants fault but to be noted to make sure they lock your car)  Great spot in the north end- might even say my new favorite Italian spot in Boston!> From start to finish this has to be the best dinner since we left Italy a week or two ago. The bolognese was to die for, the nacho bolognese and the antipasto (I had it for dinner) along with the sexiest piece of chicken parmigiana I have ever seen. There was two finished plates at the table out of 5 and the others couldn't wait to get theirs wrapped to go. The donut holes and gelato were devoured in about 30 seconds from their arrival to the table. Our newest favorite place to dine.> Great birthday dinner with my family. Very friendly staff and atmosphere. Also I like that the second floor was comfortable. I cannot stand an awful draft of cold air while I enjoy a meal. Minor concern: The portion sizes can vary based on the dishes and plat Some plate styles held plenty of food others not much. One member of our party received a black rim bowl with a deep middle (rim bowl for soup or cereal) everyone else received a white plate for pasta. This made for a tiny portion and unusual presentation and challenge for eating pasta and salmon. Also the kids meal had 2 meatballs?  I would like to see more consistency.> I took my parents in here for their wedding anniversary while they were in town and they didnt disappoint! We had a lovely table right next to the fireplace. Our server Matty took great care of us. Chef Rich came out and greeted us and made his way around to the other tables. I've never seen such a personal inviting touch from any other restaurant. Lobster stuffed mushrooms, veal chop, lasagna, and scallops were all delicious! The Italian donuts with gelato and honey with crushed pistachios has to be my favorite dessert when the pumpkin cheesecake isnt on the menu! Thank you to everyone at Tresca for making my parents feel like VIPs on their anniversary!> Cozy and quaint, delicious food and outstanding service, dining at Tresca is a treat!   From vegan to veal, they've got it all, and fabulous desserts as well!

menu_dishes: Island Creek, Howlands Landing, Rocky Nook, Ichabod Flat, Sippican, Beach Point, Spring Creek, Moon Shoal, Chatham, Sunken Meadow, Wellfleet, Chilmark, Northern Cross, Fluke Crudo, Striped Bass Ceviche, Jonah Crab Claw, 1/2 Maine Lobster Cousin Mark, Littleneck, Shrimp Cocktail, Shellfish Platter, 2012 Pascal Janvier Jasnires, 2012 Domaine Jacques Maillet 'Autrement Rouge' Savoie, 2011 Chteau De Rontets 'Clos Varambon' Pouilly Fuiss 750ml, 2010 Hugel Pinot Noir Alsace 750ml, Faroe Island Salmon Tartare, Smoked Bluefish Pt, Pan Fried Jonah Crab Cake, Crispy Oyster Slider, Steamed Littleneck Clams, Head on Stoughton Shrimp, Salt Cod Brandade, Skip's Grilled Razor Clams, Boston Bibb Lettuce, Baby Arugula, Fish Sandwich, Fish & Chips, Fried Clams, Salt Cod Fritter, Clam Chowder, Lobster Bisque, Ethel's Lobster Roll, Lobster Roe Noodles, Roasted Chicken, Grilled New York Strip Steak, Colorado Angus Burger, Cape Cod Bluefish, Grilled Faroe Island Salmon, Mrs. Bennett's Seafood Casserole, Grilled Line Caught Swordfish, Herb Crusted Gloucester Cod, New Bedford Monkfish, Montauk Striped Bass, Buttermilk Biscuit, Hand-Cut Fries, Old School Baked Beans, Cole Slaw, Brown Butter Cauliflower with Sage, Roasted Crimini Mushrooms, Herb Roasted Fingerling Sweet Potatoes, Yukon Mashed Potatoes, Baby Brussels Sprouts
