reviews: Came here as a party of six for Restaurant Week and had a great time. We had made a reservation for a Monday night and I'm glad we did because it was packed.We started off with getting some starters from the buffet before getting into the all-you-can-eat meat experience. The waiters came by consistently with different kinds of meat. By the end of the night I was comfortably full, especially with dessert on top of our meal. There's the option of cheesecake, a chocolate cake, and key lime pie.I would recommend if you love meat, but I'd probably only come during Restaurant Week.> **Restaurant Week review**The sad truth is that Fogo is just a hype. The waiters carrying the meat all come out at the same time, so you barely have time to enjoy each piece. The weird thing is even if your card is red, they'll still ask if you want any (lol). I think I would've enjoyed the meats more if they offered steak sauces and sliced them in MUCH smaller portions. I was literally not expecting a slab of meat. The salad bar is great, but I feel like the options weren't anything special (except for the roasted cauliflower!).Pro: the cheese bread is definitely yummy> We went last week and this wasn't our first time. The restaurant is always busy. This time though the service was truly impacted it would take our server about 20 min to come back and impossible to get anyone attention. Even the meat going around took so much longer than the usual we had to keep getting their attention. We had to ask for dessert to go because we had gotten so frustrated towards the end. The mango caphirana is generally good there and the salad bar is huge. I don't know if I would go back after the experience last time I generally used to like this place though> I was pleasantly surprised with my experience here. I made reservations online prior to arriving which gave us quick seating so I highly recommend making reservations! Inside, everything is nicely presented and very clean. The market table & feijoada bar had tons of different things. It ranged from salads to smoked salmon and cheeses to fruits and more! The stuff from the bar was so refreshing and complimented the unlimited amounts of meat that arrives to your table side.After being settled at the table, the waiter brought over cheesy bread, mashed potatoes, sweet plantains and some fried corn thing. The cheesy bread tastes the best when it's warm and has a yummy chewy texture inside. The mashed potatoes were super creamy. The plantains were a bit too sweet and the corn thing was really good.As you continue eating, waiters come around with fresh meat on a stick which they cut at your table side. Since you can decide when you want them to come to your table and when you need a break, it made the experience even better. All of the cuts of meats were warm and delicious. I especially loved the top sirloin and pork ribs! Some cuts were especially tasty since it had a nice char on the edges. My experience here was definitely great. I loved all the fresh cuts of meat and the huge selection of market table items! The service was also great! When I wanted to try a certain cut of meat that I noticed had not come to my table, I was able to request it and they brought it out when it was ready.> This place is perfect for meat lovers. They have a wide variety of meats going around such as sirloin steak, chicken leg, sausage, pork ribs, and other meats covered in bacon or Parmesan. I also love that they give you so many complementary dishes such as the cheesy bread, caramelized bananas, and mashed potatoes. The market table was nice, there was a large selection of foods there, my favorite being the sweet potatoes covered with marshmallows. Those are a must try.The service was good, it wasn't spectacular given the price point, but we also had a large party so it was pretty good. The meat was yummy as well and I enjoyed the time spent at this restaurant. Sometimes you won't exactly get the meat how you like it done because they have to cook it all on one slab of meat, so it's hard for the server to slice the meet exactly how you like it. All in all I'm really glad that I got to try this restaurant because it has a lot of hype surrounding it, but because I'm not the biggest meat lover it probably wouldn't be my first choice to go. However if you do know any meat lovers out there I would definitely recommend this restaurant to them, although keep in mind that it is quite pricey. With the large party I came with, including wine and the desserts we ordered, and the churrasco (full experience) menu selection, it cost us around 88 per person. Though that will definitely very depending on what you order and who you come with.

The veggie combo and injera range from good to amazing as we've ordered several times. Veggies have a nice spice and texture- especially like the cabbage and red lentils. It's definitely family run and staff is always very friendly for take out and accommodating hot sauces/powders. To date, San Jose area places are our favorites but this one is very close, if not better at times. We order the injera gluten free as that is the traditional way it's prepared.If dining in, we have brought our own bottle of wine before which is a nice option.> Wholesome, heart food with great variety! This place gets packed on weekend evenings. You can BYO wine (I'm not sure I if there's a fee).> Updated review: I visited other ethiopian restaurants and their food was much better than ethiopian cafe. This one was an awful place and a mistake for having ethiopian for the first time at this place . The food was stale and old. DO NOT VISIT THIS PLACE. It seemed that no one had entered the place since ages.Old Review:When we entered the restaurant, it was empty and smelling weird as if no one has come to this place from long time. Regarding the food, it was totally bland and no flavors, so not the kind that I would like. Either the food was tasteless and bland or its just my taste that makes authentic Ethiopian food unsuitable for me. I do not have much experience with ethiopian food so I cannot comment on this but probably this was the first and last time I am visiting this place.> ***To my knowledge, this is currently one of only three legal BYOBs within Boston city limits.***A tiny ~25 seat restaurant hidden on a busy block of other restaurants and businesses in Jamaica Plain.  But well worth seeking out for eat-with-your-fingers, tasty, filling and inexpensive Ethiopian cuisine that goes well with a variety of wines or beers.And I'm sure they'll give you a fork if you insist, but what's the fun in that? The spartan interior features a sink in back where you can wash your hands before eating with your fingers.  This is of course done with the traditional spongy injera flatbread made from teff grain, which you break into pieces so you can scoop up various vegetable and meat stews (lamb, beef, chicken, never any pork no matter your religion in Ethiopia).  Apparently it is traditional to do this with your right hand only (sorry lefties lol).We started with a couple of the spinach-stuffed sambosa (sambusa?), which were very much like the ubiquitous deep-fried spanakopita triangles you see at Greek restaurants and did not seem very authentic from what I can read online.  But tasty.  Also available with lentil (and possibly meat?) fillings.We followed this up with a meat and vegetable combination plate (or you can order individual dishes), which can be customized for any number of people to share and arrives on top of several large injera (more injera on a side plate to rip up).  Each meat and veggie was delicious, but very different from each other (a pleasant surprise), particularly the modestly spicy chicken stew, which was almost American BBQ in flavor and featured a couple of legs as well as pulled meat.  Our combo featured all 6 of the available vegetable dishes, the 1 chicken, 1 of the 5 beef and 1 of 2 lamb dishes, plus a salad.  With so many vegetable dishes on the menu, this would probably be a good restaurant for vegetarians, and they offer a vegetable combo plate as well.Ethiopian meat dishes are traditionally spicy, and can be extremely spicy.  But since this is a BYOB, don't worry, none of the dishes were spicy enough to be wine destroying or requiring only the traditional spicy food wines like Riesling or Gewürztraminer.  We went with an Italianate orange wine from Pennsylvania (my favorite wine from the East Coast) and a Cali cabernet, both of which worked well.  Bring your own if you want to use real wine stems as they just have tumblers.2011 Va La Vineyards La Prima Donna2014 Daou Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon Paso RoblesThey also serve traditional, made at the table Ethiopian coffee, which smelled wonderful, although we didn't try it.No dessert offered.Service was friendly and well-meaning, but we did have to ask for explanations when they were not forthcoming.  $51 + tax for a filling meal for 3 people. And the free parking on the street was fairly easy at 5:30PM on a Saturday.  Although small, at no time during our visit was the restaurant more than half full (we had a phone reservation, but you probably don't need one unless you have more than 4 people so they can pull some tables together).  They also have a couple of traditional mesob woven round wicker basket tables, although the seating around them didn't look as comfortable.MORE ABOUT BYOB:If you are interested, I have created a Yelp "Collection" of legal BYOBs in the Boston area (I define Boston pretty liberally lol):yelp.com/collection/RL6T…In case you don't know, Boston's rules for byob are as follows:Permitted Types/Sizes of Alcohol:A. Patrons may only bring wine and malt beverages into the licensed premise.B. Patrons are prohibited from bringing distilled spirits and/or liqueurs/cordials into the licensed premise.C. Patrons may only bring malt beverages in containers no larger than 64 oz., and may bring in no more than a total of 64 oz. per person.D. Patrons may only bring wine in containers no larger than 750 ml., and may bring in no more than a total of 750 ml. per person.E. Patrons are prohibited from re-entering the premise with additional alcohol.Miscellaneous:A. Licensees shall not charge a "corkage"or any other fee or surcharge for permitting BYOB or providing any service or amenity relative to BYOB.B. Licensees are not prohibited from providing glassware and/or a bottle opener.C. Nothing in this section shall prohibit a licensee from discarding an empty or abandoned alcoholic beverage container or its content.Hours of Operation:Licensees shall only allow BYOB between the hours of 5:00 P.M. and 11:00 P.M.boston.gov/sites/default…> We ordered a meat platter for two and it was more than enough food! We called ahead to see if they had gluten free teff - and luckily, another party had ordered it that day so the kitchen had extra. If you have a gluten allergy, call a day before so they can make it ahead of time! The owner was really sweet to explain the process to us. Also, the coffee (jabela) was delicious.

Solid pizza. Quick and effective delivery.  Good service if you happen to go inside. Street parking. Preferred order: Large chicken bacon ranch - yum!> This place is the best food in the area! Come here almost daily. Wings are amazing .Buffalo Mac and cheese is the best literally crave it. Very friendly and quick service. Can't go wrong with coming here.> The website sucks! If you are ordering delivery, just call and save yourself the trouble. The website kept switching me to PayPal when I simply wanted to pay by credit card. I have asked in the past to have this corrected. Today I was informed that "only a financial institution can do that, and we are not a financial institution"!!!  WTF!!!   The staff can be quite rushed & very rude while on the phone. I gave it a two star rating.> Pretty solid pizza. Didn't taste like cardboard and is slightly better when cold. I ordered the Prom King this time around but I think I prefer the chicken, bacon, and ranch pizza.The Caprese Focaccia bread was pretty refreshing. I thought the bread was a bit too dry but outside of that I really liked the sandwich as a whole.> Boy oh boy would I rather light my hair on fire than speak to the man on the phone there. Womanizer at best. I'm disgusted by the way I was treated.

We love this place so, so much. Ambiance, service, and food are all on point. Wish we could pick it up, then pop it back down on our block!> My husband and I went to 224 last night for the first time in a long time. I wasn't impressed. The service was mediocre to basic at best. I must say, The atmosphere isn't great either. The lighting is weird and the dining room looks like it was set up that day with second hand tables and chairs. I'm not sure if they're going for a run down, rustic look inside, but it would benefit from a fresh coat of paint and newer furniture. I was not impressed with the beer selection. Very limited. I ordered a Belgian white ale and was given a can. No glass or anything, just a can. I ordered the lamb frites which was delicious. My husband, however, ordered the short rib Mac and cheese and we literally had to look for the short rib in it. It was all shells and cheese with two little pieces of short rib. For $25, it just didn't make sense. Way overpriced. The overall experience was OK, and living nearby I'll likely go back again. I suppose I'll be more selective of entree choices overall.> The smallest pasta dish ever with no sides I normally eat in Federal Hill for Italian foodSo I'm spoiled I probably received about a cupOf pasta for 18 dollars and a short pour on the wine for 11There's a lot of competition in Dot hope you read this Thanks> This homespun abode brings Back Bay prices to Dorchester. The service is fine. The kung pao calamari is more appetizing than the oven-roasted wings. And the pan-roasted salmon was divine!> This is the classic solid neighborhood two dollar sign sit-down.The lady serving us was nice, and they had a nice menu of items. The dumplings and pasta had a hint of polish flavors, and the burger was exactly medium rare. The thick bacon was also a nice touch.It's the type of $60 after tax and tip for two sit down place that you'd enjoy visiting on a weekday night.

cusine_types: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, American (Traditional), Seafood
reviews: They make some of their own unique soft serve flavors here. The orange-vanilla twist is divine. I'm warming to the raspberry-coffee twist though. The small cone is **huge** and the prices are reasonable.Their onion rings are the only kind I've ever had that kind of melt in your mouth. We try to go a couple times during the summer even though it's out of the way.> This place is a nice local ice cream shop that also sells food apparently. This review is for ice cream only tho. The fruity pebbles ice cream was good but kind of simple. It was blended vanilla ice cream with fruity pebbles. Nothing special. Tastes exactly what it sounds like - fruity pebbles with vanilla ice cream. I expected more from the chocolate chip cookie dough, but there were barely any toppings inside. It was good but not enough topping. Also, one small cup is good for two people, as it comes in huge portions! There also is limited parking and if you park at the place it's kinda hard to back up because the line can stretch far out and you don't wanna hit people. This is an outdoor ice cream parlor, so it sucks because I got bit multiple times by mosquitoes waiting outside, but the line moves fast. Would definitely come again and try out their other flavors!> First let me say that they are very generous when it comes to scoops. That is one of the main things that catches my eye. Came here to try since I moved down the street from it. The outside doesn't really catch the eye but you can't judge a place by its appearance. They serve fried seafood and regular beach food. Not sure if I would try it though (LOL). They serve basic flavors hard and soft swerve so it's nothing out of the ordinary. I got green monster which is mint cookies and cream. The flavor was really good but it wasn't as creamy. Still good for the price I paid though. They give out huge scoops compared to other places for a low price so you can't really complain. I just wish they had more unique flavors to try because nothing really stood out to me. I guess it's okay for a quick ice cream fix.> Pretty good! Ice cream was rich and creamy. Nothing to complain about besides the lack of parking.> Great local place to get soft serve ice cream. Always a long line during summer nights but it goes by fast! Employees there are friendly and fast

I came here with 2 other people on a Sunday afternoon trying to get brunch. The first place we tried to go to had an 1+ hour wait so we decided to go to a new place. While we were waiting to get seated, I noticed that they were also serving some kind of buffet which kind of confused me. We got seated near the bar and ordered from the brunch menu. We got an Eggs Benedict, the hungry man, and a rib eye steak. Yes, they served a steak for brunch (with eggs and toast). We also ordered a side of potato pancakes because I was interested in them. We didn't think we ordered a lot, but wow....it was a lot of food. The Eggs Benedict with Canadian ham came with cold home fries. It might have been my least favorite item because I wasn't a big fan of the spices on the home fries and the ham was thick. I wasn't expecting it to be that thick, maybe a good 1/2 inch thick ham.The Hungry Man came with eggs, home fries, toast, french toast, bacon, and sausages. The standard brunch items and my brother devoured everything.We asked the rib eye to be medium rare, but it came out a little more medium-well done. It was surprisingly still really juicy and it was great. It was also only...$20.The potato pancakes were delicious and huge, considering that it was a side. To me, it was like a mash potato w/veggies that was shaped and fried and served with spicy ranch. It was delicious.Our waiter was very attentive and kept checking up on us. I assume it was a family restaurant because there were several kids that came to drop off the food to our table. Overall, it was a great brunch spot and the best bang for your buck.> Had a pretty decent experience here. Ideally I would give this a 3.5 but the food gives it a little push up to 4. The place itself is really big with plenty of seating but we were quickly informed that they are currently understaffed so there was a wait. I was a little skeptical about this and it definitely showed in the service. Our server had some complications remembering our orders and what to bring to the table (Ex. My order came with an English muffin and after reminding her multiple times, I gave up and just went without it). Despite that, I still didn't get too upset because she was an extremely friendly and easy going server - might be one of the best interactions I've had at a restaurant. Plus, I get that they were understaffed that day. As for food, I got the hungry man with blueberry pancakes. Usually I get full pretty quickly and would have to take my food to-go but somehow, I ate a crazy majority of this breakfast! My eggs were cooked to order, the bacon wasn't overcooked and burnt, and the sausages were delicious. The downside of this meal were the home fries. Seasoning was all there but they were more on the mushy side while I prefer home fries a little crispier on the outside. The overall meal was also a bit cold when it got to the table but all of this was forgotten when I tried the blueberry pancakes - wow!! I don't know what it was about it but my table couldn't stop eating them. Crispy on the edges while still fluffy in the middle. It was stuffed with plenty of blueberries for extra taste yet not overly sweet to the point where you don't want anymore. Easily my favorite part of the meal. My table also had other dishes that we shared. Strawberry french toast was ok. The strawberries tasted fresh and the French toast was good but nothing out of the ordinary. We also tried their crispy potato pancakes with their special house sauce and those were good. The sauce was like a spicy ranch that added a nice kick. Excited to come back and try other items - hopefully with more staffing next time!> I came here because they offer a traditional Irish Breakfast and I love trying foods from other cultures.  That said, I wouldn't order it again.  Not that it was prepared poorly, it just wasn't for me.I'll still go back and try something else.> After seeing a lot of positive reviews, I decided to give Mad Hatter a try. Though, I find this restaurant to be average.We got The Hungry Man which came with two eggs, toast, home fries, ham, bacon, Irish sausage and a choice of two pieces of French toast or pancakes. We opted to replace the French toast for the crunchy French toast -- it was alright, but could be better as it was burnt on the sides. We also got the waffles with real maple syrup. The waffles were tough to chew and had an acquired taste. Our server was terrible. She did not check on us once! We had to flag down another server to ask for more water, coffee and bill!> Really? Guess I should not expect quality food in an area that seemingly does not prefer quality..based on the reviews. Not only the quality of the ingredients but also the preparation were so disappointing. Why is it so rare for business owners to  strive for and deliver the best? Those that do are and will be the establisments that survive the tough times. Hope this tip helps the owner rethink his/her long-term plan....but as long as people are willing to settle for mediocrity or less, I guess an improved plan won't be warranted.

menu_dishes: Island Creek Oysters, Local Squash Soup, Mary's Apples, Traditional Caesar, Caprese, Wild Boar Bolognese, Sherry Roasted Mushrooms, Scampi, Pan Seared Scallops, Chicken 'Under a Brick', Balsamic Pork Tenderloin, Angus Sirloin Medallions, Wood Grilled Scottish Salmon, Wood Roasted Cod, Whipped Potatoes, Grilled Asparagus, Roasted Mushroom Misti, Eggplant Caponata, Fresh Corn & Sugar Snap Pea Risotto, Local Squash Risotto
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: Tosca is an opera. It premiered at the Teatro Costanzi in Rome on January 14th 1900. It's based on Victorien Sardou's 1887 French-language dramatic play, La Tosca. It contains depictions of torture, murder and suicide. Tosca is also an Italian Steak House in Hingham that feels like an opera. It too came in 3 acts. And like the play, none of the characters make it to the end alive. Act 1. The bread. It arrived with trumpets and fanfare. Our waitress described all 4. I only heard double chocolate bread. It was so satisfyingly delicious that I talked to it in between bites congratulating it like an athlete. An olive tapenade dip came with. Act 2. The appetizers. Cheese on Marble and Mushroom Pate. 4 different cheeses from hard to soft were accompanied by the same exact accoutrements as the pate... odd. Carmelized fig jam, gherkins, blackberry preserves and grapes came with crostini. The pate was devine. Act 3. The Steak. Reserve Filet Mignon. It came with rosemary salt, tosca steak sauce and a whole head of roasted garlic. You had me at rosemary salt. The smokiness of the grill shined and every bite was infused with the garlic oil from said squeezed bulb. Overall the evening had it all. I laughed, I cried and I thouroghly enjoyed myself. At the end of Tosca the Opera, our heroine flings herself off a cliff crying " O Scarpia, Avanti a Dio!!!" - Oh Scarpia, we meet before God! ....I threw myself onto my couch a declared " O Tosca, Til we meet again !!!".> Down grading to a 2.3. As a local, this is about 6th visit, not much, but we only lived here a little over a year. I still like the ambience of the main restaurant seating area, but I usually eat at the small bar. BTW the back bar opens at 6pm and a nice bar.Anyway, to the food. I had shrimp box ( normally a 4.8) somehow was just a 3.0 tonight. Still a likely good bet as an appetizer. For dinner I tried a 8 oz filet mignon medium rare. The temperature was perfect but fillet cut was awful. There was a knot like at one end, and fat.. just not possible on any right filet mignon. So, sorry a 2.0. I also ordered a side dish of gnocchi. Big and puffy ( not necessarily bad)  lite, but tasteless. 1.0 they took off bill. Wife had the skirt steak panzanella. Steak was a 3.0, the bread salad, well I guess it was a bit less than hoped, but never really had it before, so a solid 3.0. So as from NYC, we are steak snobs and love Italian food. So, for us it's a steak & gnocch fail. Also suggest one asks for chard crust, I forgot to, it's needed. Arrowwood vino is a great solid dry cab.  Brian is a great bartender, excellent service and nice guy, best reason to go back actually.Tab was 187.00 ... Not good value.> Okay so I'll start by saying that I don't like to post negative reviews, but that being said I do think it's important to give feedback as necessary.  And a restaurant with this type of reputation must do better... We found out that my husband had to work on my actual birthday later this week so we tried looking for some last minute reservations to celebrate together tonight. We had been at Tosca's once many years ago, and remembered it as being a good place, unfortunately it appears to have gone down hill. Service is very big for us, and first off we had been seated for well over ten minutes (yes I was checking the time) without any water or any greeting. Meanwhile the older couple to the left of us had been checked on more than once, and the restaurant was clearly not busy as multiple waitstaff were standing around together chatting. I am typically not one to complain but I absolutely debated just walking out. When the waitress finally came over we let her know how long we were waiting and she did seem genuinely apologetic - which I appreciated so we stayed. She said she was unaware that we were seated (but again multiple waitstaff walked by us). Unfortunately, the rest of the experience overall continued to disappoint. The appetizers came out and my husband had finished his water and my glass was near empty as well. The waitstaff (not our specific waitress) walked right by us and gave other tables water (I don't understand this - is it our age where they felt the need to cater to the older crowds instead and skip us - I'm really unsure and puzzled). We had to find another waitstaff and ask her to please serve us water - I'm sorry but that's just unacceptable. Later on, our own waitress had been more attentive to making sure we had water - however there was also a time where I was just waiting for another glass of wine, most places will be sure to ask if you'd like another glass before you've finished). The food was good enough, I won't say otherwise, but not amazing either. Also, I'm a huge dessert person, and especially for my birthday I would typically get one but I really just wanted the dinner to be over with and to leave - so we asked for the check. They took off two of our appetizers leaving the bill to $100, this was for two glasses of wine and two meals. We are more than happy to really spend for a great dinner, but this was absolutely not worth that. My husband's going to make it up to me and take me out to another birthday dinner when we can find the time, because this certainly didn't suffice. We won't be back, and I would not recommend it.Update: Received a kind and apologetic email from the general manager, and although we are not likely to return, thought he had a nice gesture to make up for the experience. Hopefully was just an "off" night for them.> My family and I went here for a birthday celebration. For appetizer, we ordered the bibb lettuce salad to share. The salad came with letttuce, bacon crumbles, avocado, and gorgonzola dressing. The salad was very tasty.I liked their complimentary bread basket. The bread was very fresh. I especially liked the raisin and walnut bread. So yummy! I wonder if they sell it by the loaf?For an entree, I ordered the veal milanese special. The entree came with a big slice of fried veal with arugula and radicchio sprinkled on top with parmesan cheese. The veal was tender and juicy. It was delicious.Service was very attentive and the waitress was really nice. The only minus was that the restaurant was a bit dark. Hope to try other things next time.> Finally made it to Tosca last weekend. Outstanding meal & terrific service. Meal consisted of:Cheese plate Salad special - Boston Bibb lettuce, avocado, cherry tomatoes & bacon (delicious)Entrees were seared sea scallops over rice verde & Chicken Marsala lasagna. Chocolate molten cake for dessert...one of the best I've ever had. Looking forward to returning to try other menu items!

One of our go to places for pizza.. love their crust & pizza is always great! The large size is huge!> I knew the moment I opened the container and saw how white the sauce was that this dish was going to be bland AF. Like how can you mess up chicken Alfredo? You can tell they did not use not one hint of seasoning! No garlic, no basil, no pepper, NADA. The pasta was over cook and soggy. There was way too much bland Alfredo sauce overflowing in the dish that you could barely see the chicken or the broccoli. This was really a waste of money. I should of read the reviews before hand but didn't bc I was being lazy and ordered whatever had free delivery on UberEATS. Never again will I purchase from this place. If you like your food bland, unseasoned with no favor at all then this place is for you.Edit: Business owner keeps bashing customers in yelp reviews. This place needs to hire a business consultant. The establishment needs customer service training.Édit: This establishment is petty AF. All today I keep getting emails from yelp updating me very time the the business owner edits their comments. Listen man, if there a ton of strangers, who don't know each other, complaining about your business is it really us or is it you? Food for thought.> 4/7/2019 Update: So along with producing an embarrassing quality of food, this place also has a joke of an owner. See attached screenshot.Got to love someone who is so naive about the garbage quality of food that they make that instead of addressing his own problems he chooses to attack a reviewers personality...lmao. Your "restaurant" is an absolute joke and you are a clown. 4/7/2019 Review: To say this place is awful would be an understatement. I ordered a small pepperoni pizza, cheese breadsticks, and popcorn chicken. All three were absolutely terrible. I ended up only having 1 slice of pizza. Very cheap ingredients, greasy, and just all around bad.I would rather starve than eat from here again.> WOW!!! We  legit that had the best meal/takeout that we have ever ordered in Quincy. The pizza was incredible, the salad was fresh and HUGE would feed meFor a whole day, the jalapeño poppers were definnitely home made and amazing. The need empanadas were incrredible. Will be the only pizza we order from here on out. THANK YOU!> We always order the Antipasto from Sophias with our pizza. Other than my late mother, no one's makes an antipasto like Sophia's. The bread they give you tastes so good dipped in salad dressing. The pizza we get, mushroom and peppers have just the right amount of fresh mushrooms and sweet peppers with the crust cooked just right. Sophia's has never disappointed!

Listen to the words coming out of my Yelp mouth: the $50 Dinner for Two deal is now available Sunday through Wednesday, for curbside take-out, and it includes the bottle of wine.Two entrees, one starter and a bottle of house vin (we usually get the Kato savvy B) for $50. What a steal! I strongly suggest the shrimp scampi primavera, the chicken parmigiana or one of their pizzas - all are really decent quality and excellent values.The calamari is excellent when eaten fresh, and it does suffer a bit during longer rides post-takeout. The only mild weak spot - seriously, put BHB on your "stay in, support local" short list.> Boathouse Bistro has the most delicious pizza you can imagine all fresh ingredients a superb wine list and the appetizers are perfection walking - you must try if ever in the Hinghan shipyard area!!> I just can't, we loved this place and ordered there multiple times and this is something else.> This place is absolutely gross if your a foodie avoid.1st dish served cold2nd dish blah3rd gross> If you actually want a good meal, don't go here.  Service is good, ambiance okay.  But every dish we got was terrible, even the calamari somehow. Avoid any fish dish.  I'm sure the pizzas are okay.

menu_dishes: Nagasaki Champon, Kara - Goma Champon, Omori - Niku Champon, Nagasaki Sara - Udon, Yakibuta Ramen, Stamina Ramen, Tan Tan Men, Vegetarian Ramen, Cha - Shu Don, Yakiniku Don, Vegetarian Don, Kyu - Shu Don, Curry Don, Takana Cha - Han, Takana Mentai Don, Curry Don, Cha - Shu Don, Kara - Age, Negi Cha - Shu, Onigiri, Dashi Onsen Tamago, Noodles, Shredded Black - Wood Mushroom, Seasoned Ground Pork, Onsen Egg, Cha - Shu, Seafood, Vegetables, Yakiniku Pork, Mentai (Cod Roe), House Cold Noodles, Cold Tantan Noodles
popular_dishes: Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, Yes
reviews: I'm a Ramen snob. Tokyo, Seoul, Frankfurt, New York, you name it I've tried em all.This place is unique because in addition to regular ramen flavors they offer champon which is extreme umami taste of seafood with ramen.Pricing is also excellent> Came here on a Friday night around 6 pm. No wait at all which was great.Order:1. Pork belly buns (3/5): Was decent as the meat wasn't the most tender and was a bit dry. Had better...2. Sukiyaki Champon (4.5/5): Delicious, comes with a wide assortment of toppings including an egg, squid, tofu, a bunch of random seafood, etc. The noodles were how I like ramen noodles, thick and not too soft. The broth was delicious. The portion size is big for what you pay for.Overall, a nice whole in the wall ramen place. They specialize in champon which is pretty much ramen with seafood. My first time trying champon ramen and wa not disappointed! Would come again. Also the wait isn't like the other ramen places like Ganko, Santouka with waits up to 2 hours as Migaku hasn't caught on people's radar yet. So come here if you want delicious ramen and not wait for 2 hours...> Read this review as a 3.5 star review.In a quiet, unassuming part of Brookline, I decided to grab a quick bite at Migaku. I ordered the gyoza and sukiyaku champon. The gyoza, while presented nicely, weren't particularly notable. For the main course, I got sukiyaki champon since I have yet to try this variation of ramen. The broth was definitely thick and fairly flavorful (note the thin film on the broth). On the other hand, I felt that the vegetable to noodle ratio was strongly in favor of the vegetables. The amount of seafood was fine. I might come back to Migaku if I am already in the area to try another dish (props for introducing champon to Boston) but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here. IG: Mood4foodeatery> Told my ramen addicted, she gets 1 place a month, and we went for Migaku. I appreciate that Migaku differentiates themselves from other ramen joints. They serve Champon which appears to be Ramen, but mixed with seafood from what I understand. Slightly allergic, but always willing to risk it for food, I ordered the Nagasaki Champon. For some reason, the thick noodles didn't vibe with me here. It also had alot of veggies and a small portion of the dish was seafood. The addict vacuumed her dish, but noted that it was salty for her taste and I agreed. Side note, there's actually alot of street parking available leading up to Migaku, so I felt like I could eat comfortably without worrying about 2hr parking limits and such!> If you're craving ramen, skip Ganko Ittetsu in the Coolidge corner arcade and come here instead. The noodle broth here is so rich and they're experts at serving beautiful onsen soft eggs and delicious chashu pork.They have a spicy, citrusey sauce as well as dried chili flakes on the table, both of which complement the noodles so well!I've been here a few times and tried something different on the menu each time.Yakibuta ramen $12.50: pretty simple toppings on this one, but it features their chashu pork and onsen egg. The broth is very rich and they give a good portion of noodles. A great item to try if you're craving ramen but I personally would go for the spicy miso ramen.Spicy miso ramen $13.50: missing the onsen egg (add for $2.50) but they also have ground pork, corn, and bean sprouts in addition to the chashu. The ground pork kind of gets overshadowed by the chashu but it complements the broth very well! My spice tolerance is super high so the broth wasn't spicy at all to me, but the miso made the already rich broth even richer. Nagasaki champon $12.50: the champon is what makes Migaku unique, since not many restaurants (if any) in the area serve champon noodle soup. You'll notice the difference in the presentation (since it's a heap of pork and vegetables on top of your noodles) and the broth. Whereas the ramen broth is pork based, the champon broth is more fishy but equally umami. The noodles are topped with a mountain of nicely seasoned pork, vegetables, and seafood. The portion is huge and I can't finish it on my own.There aren't many tables in this restaurant since it's a pretty small space. Very clean interior and the service is quick. I've never had a bad experience here! I always look forward to the next time I eat here.

menu_dishes: ROMAINE*, ARUGULA ºº, ARTICHOKE CARPACCIO, MOZZARELLA DI BUFALA, OYSTERS*, CRUDO* ºº, TUNA*, SALMON TARTARE*, POLPO, FOIE GRAS, STEAK TARTARE*, GNOCCHI, ORECCHIETTE, RISOTTO, MACCHERONCELLI, SCALLOPS* Maine, BRANZINO Greece, SALMON* Faroe Islands, Denmark, CHICKEN Feather Brook Farms, MA, MILANESE* New York, VEAL* Perigueux, France, LAMB CHOPS* Colorado, FILET MIGNON* Greater Omaha, Nebraska, RIBEYE*Greater Omaha, Nebraska, TRUFFLE FRIES Parmigiano, chives, EGGPLANT ROLLATINI ricotta, mortared pesto Genoveseºº, EXOTIC MUSHROOMS black garlic, black truffles, BROCCOLI RABE crispy garlic, Calabrian chilis, WHIPPED POTATOES Vermont butter, SOFT POLENTA Parmigiano
popular_dishes: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: I visited this great restaurant two nights in a row for company events.Super happy with good, service and variety of dishes. Solid wine list as well.Dishes tried:- Polpo/octopus appetizer (5 stars, best dish)- artichoke carpaccio with black truffles appetizer (4.5 stars)- oyster appetizer (4 stars, too many items added, hid true oyster flavor. Still solid dish)- branzino entree (4.5 stars. Cooked perfectly! Simple and tasty)- scallops entree (4.5 stars. Great flavors, slightly small portion with only 4 scallops)- filet mignon entree (5 stars. Cooked to absolute perfection - medium rare)- broccoli rabe side dish (4.5 stars)- mushrooms side dish (3.5 stars, tasted all garlic)- bombardino/ Italian donuts dessert (4.5 stars. Super fresh, still warm and light)Would rate 4.5 if I could, but closer to 5 than 4 due to  prime service.> I came here on a Friday night according to my friend's recommendation. We had Foi Gras and oysters for our appetizers. The Foi Gras came with fruits on the side. The fruits perfectly neutralized the oily taste. In addition, the raw oysters came with lots of ingredients. The fishy taste was completely avoided by the sour taste of lemon juice and the bitter taste of the ingredient. As for the main course, I highly recommend the veal. This course was not like normal veal dishes which come with a side. This course used mashed potato as the sauce at the base which completely enhanced the soft taste of the veal. I ordered a Japanese whiskey for my dessert. The best thing for it was that they used a perfect rounded ice ball inside the drink so the drink didn't get diluted swiftly.> Review #1040One of the best meals I've had in Boston! My friend and I got to try these dishes:- Salmon tartare $27- MACCHERONCELLI (Feather Brook Farms meatballs, Montepulciano sauce, Parmigiano) $20 as an appetizer- FILET MIGNON* - Greater Omaha, Nebraska (8 ounce, beech mushrooms, pearl onions, whipped potatoes, Montepulciano sauce) $44- RIBEYE* Greater Omaha, Nebraska (prime, 14 oz, king trumpets, broccolini, bone marrow, and garlic vin cotto) $48I liked the salmon tartare a lot! My filet mignon was a little too dry, even as I asked for a medium. The meatballs were good, but both my friend and I felt like it tasted a bit funny for some reason? We also enjoyed the molten chocolate cake, which was a solid dessert choice.I love the decor and the table set up on the inside. For once, I don't feel like I am so crammed sitting at a Boston restaurant or continuously have to make ways for waiters to get by the aisle. My server was friendly but as always (as I said in an earlier review), in my limited experience at high-end restaurants, I don't believe I've encountered anyone yet where I was like okay this person entirely deserves a 20% tip. In fact, it is always these family-run businesses where I'd feel welcomed and be willing to tip 20% wholeheartedly.Their bathrooms are unisex and located by their entrance. They are clean and have both paper towels and hand dryers available. Overall, I enjoyed my dining experience here. Next time, I'd definitely order the ribeye!> Whether you're having oysters and cocktails at the bar or dining experience at a table, you will be no less than impressed by Sorrelina. The service is professional and top notch. I will personally vouch that Sorellina has some of the best oysters in Boston - convince me otherwise. Every meal I've ever had has been incredible and doesn't taste mass produced like some restaurants. If you're taking someone here they will not be disappointed and you will look like you have great taste. Perfect for dates, probably too intimate for coworkers UPDATE:I just had dinner at Sorrelina tonight and am really disappointed by my experience. While the food remains amazing, our server lowered our dining experience. He told us about the ravioli special but failed to mention that it included mushrooms. When I ordered it, I was surprised by the mushrooms and the fact that he never even asked if we had allergies or dietary preferences. He also didn't come back once during the meal to see if we were enjoying it. It wasn't busy at all when we were there so I'm curious as to why he slipped up or if the overall service has gone down. I'd like to come back to see if this was a one off experience but I'm nervous to waste a dinner out again.> I honestly expected a lot more based on reviews. The food was great, but portions were extremely small. I ordered the cod fish, which was good but could have had more flavor. The menu stated it also came with lobster and gnocchi. There was probably 1 bite of each on my plate. However, I tried the lobster gnocchi main dish was tasty. Apps I enjoyed were the tuna tartare and salmon tartare. I didn't enjoy the wasabi on the tuna tartare though as I am not a fan. The burrata was alright, nothing special. We also ordered the eggplant side dish which was decent. Truffle fries were pretty good too! For dessert, we ordered the cioccolato, bombolini, and gelato and sorbet. I loved the cioccolato. It melted in my mouth. We also ordered ice wine which was delicious! It was sweet with an amazing flavor to it. It was pretty pricey at $35 per glass but I'd say it was worth every penny! Service was absolutely impeccable. Great place for a business dinner or dinner for a special occasion. Just make sure you order enough apps and sides due to the extremely small portions!

Looks can be deceiving, and when I first saw Matteo's I was a little skeptical. Now it's my go-to pizza place.Not far from a literal hole in the wall, Matteo's does business from a counter WITHIN the Atlantic Liquors' shop (as does the Coffee n Cream cafe). But from this modest establishment comes a solid menu and amazing pizza. While normally I prefer more Italian style pies with thin crusts, Matteo's Greek style pizza gives excellent quality at reasonable prices. I'm also a big fan of their gyros, fries, and chick parm calzones. Good hours, wide delivery radius, and some of the best pizza in Quincy, Matteo's has never let me down.So if there's ever a Friday night where you want to go pick up some beer and pizza to go in some one-stop-shopping, go here.> I ordered a small hawaiian and absolutely loved it!!! Also go mozzarella sticks, pretty decent and the boyfriend got a chicken parm sand. It was ok.  Will definitely be ordering a pizza from here again!> I would give LESS than one star if possible!! Placed an order for DELIVERY. After over one hour, and no call and/or delivery of food, I checked online. Matteo's listed as CLOSED. As it is Easter, I considered this was most likely and internet holiday glich, so I ordered from somewhere else. About 20 minutes later, a call from Matteo's... They have had food for a long time.They refuse to deliver and/or refund my $$. BUYER BEWARE!! This place is a RIPOFF. I will be pursuing with my bank tomorrow.> Worst place in Quincy I've ordered from. 2 hours for delivery and the food stinks. Look at this salad. This is how it came!> 5 stars for the extra crispy buffalo chicken wings!! Most places give you soggy/non crispy chicken for take out orders, but this restaurant did not disappoint.

menu_dishes: Lobster and Corn Chowder, The Chop, Simple Caeser, Fourth Wall Grilled Cheese Sandwich, Fourth Wall Grilled Cheese Sandwich, The Burger, Portobello Sammy Sandwich, The Brat Sandwich, Wings, House Made Fries, Buffalo Cauliflower, Fourth Wall Nachos, Sweet Chili Chicken Bites, Sweet Potato Fries, Buttermilk Onion Rings, Deviled Eggs, Bourbon Barrel Hanger Tips, Ribeye Steak Frite, Sweet Heat Seared Salmon, Chicken Broccolini Alfredo, Lobster Mac and Cheese, Buttermilk Fried Chicken
popular_dishes: Yes, No, No, Yes, Yes, No, Yes, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No
reviews: What a perfect place to stumble upon after a beerfest. We needed some comfort food and boy did we get it.I got the burger special, which included some sort of creamy spread on the bun. It was perfection for after three hours of beer sampling. Fries were fine.The bar itself is not too big. we grabbed a spot near the front at a table and pretty much kept to ourselves. We quickly got our food and pints from the bartender, although most of us barely finished the pints. Nothing was wrong with them, we just couldn't stomach any more beer! Then we all ate in silence as we devoured our food.Thanks for the wind-down to our night!> my first time in Boston and after that 4hours++ bus ride from NYC my sister was starving. this place happens to be located just across our hotel and my sister was craving fries hence we just went it. everything about this place turned out so much better than expected! great ambience! casual, chill, and relaxed. amazing and very pleasant service too! the guy was really amiable and he was attentiveI ordered Portobello Sammy, my sister got the Fourth Wall Grilled Cheese Sandwich and we shared the Lobster and Corn Chowder..- the Lobster Chowder was amazing! it has the most generous pieces of lobster I've ever had in a chowder and the crouton was actually corn bread, which blends really well- both sandwiches came with massive amount of fries. I switched mine to sweet potato fries. Fluffy brioche bun, sharp savory cheese, the portobello has strong acidic taste to it.. Overall it was really good. the sweet potato fries has amazing texture but both fries were kind of bland for unknown reason. there were so much fries we had to pack the leftovers to go. they'll make a good bus ride snack I suppose.for the quality of the food, the size, service, and atmosphere I think they charge decently and was well worth it.. it was overall a very enjoyable lunch> Tried this place out on a weeknight before heading to a show at the Wang Theater. It's a weird mix between a lively bar and restaurant but I appreciate the effort at a nice full menu in a place like this. I had a couple gin and tonics which were quite good and strong. Their menu is limited but has some really nice dinner options. I chose the hanger steak cooked medium. It arrived quickly but was overdone and chewy. The side of street corn was just okay. My partner's meal was also mediocre (burger). Our waiter was exceptionally nice. He was trying his best but it became too busy for him to keep up with tables. It took a while for the second round of drinks. After the meal he initially brought back a bill which was not ours. We waited patiently for him to return the correct bill which charged us for an extra we never had. We sucked it up, paid and got out of there. Overall great people with great intentions. It's just not working yet.> Very good. Went here for lunch today. We got there at the perfect time because it really filled up. I had the burger and a salad. No complaints but the burger could have been cooked a little longer for medium. If you're really picky about your red meat I would have them cook it longer than usual. The sweet potato fries were also a hit! The service was very friendly and the food came out relatively fast. I would definitely stop in here for lunch!> We were looking for a casual spot to get burgers and beers and this spot was perfect. You can expect all the classics of a bar menu. Wound up getting the burger with fries. It is served on a buttered brioche bun - yum! The place is on the smaller side and tends to get packed pretty quickly with the after work crowd on weekdays.
